fields.headline: Welcome to the world's biggest bank
fields.standfirst:
Formation of Mizuho Financial Group symbolises Japanese hopes of rebirth
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Is bigger really better? That is the trillion-dollar question hanging over the launch in Japan today of the world's largest bank amid renewed fears about the health of the country's bloated financial sector.
fields.body:
Is bigger really better? That is the trillion-dollar question hanging over the launch in Japan today of the world's largest bank amid renewed fears about the health of the country's bloated financial sector.

The formation of Mizuho Financial Group is supposed to be a symbol of the changes that Japan has undergone in the two years since its banking crisis threatened to bring down the entire global financial system.

With assets of ¥134.4 trillion (£853bn), the group dwarfs it closest rival, Deutsche Bank. The company's president, Katsuyuki Sugita, says it can become one of the five leading instititions in the global financial community and a pioneer of new businesses in the domestic market.

The launch comes against a backdrop of declining bank stocks, falling asset prices and growing concerns among politicians and investors that the problems of bad loans and poor profitability faced by Japanese banks are merely being swept under the carpet.

Mizuho is a holding company formed by Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, Fuji Bank and the Industrial Bank of Japan as the first step towards a full reorganisation of their operations by 2002. The group's shares were listed for the first time yesterday on the Tokyo stock exchange. In October, the three banks' securities arms and trust banking affiliates will merge their opera tions. It is the biggest in a wave of mega-mergers engineered by the government to shore up the Japanese financial system after a decade of lax lending led to the collapse of three major banks and the near bankruptcy of several others.

The government strong-armed the banks to accept the alliances in return for trillions of yen in public cash to stabilise their precarious finances. It justified the cost to taxpayers by arguing that the move would force the banks to clear up their bad loans and improve their profitability.

But this is proving easier said than done. Despite huge write-offs over the past eight years by its three member banks, the Mizuho group begins life with ¥4.7 trillion in bad debts, the biggest burden among the four Japanese major banking alliances. It must also repay the ¥2.8 trillion it received from the government for recapitalisation.

Like other banks it is suffering on the other side of the balance sheet, where its assets continue to decline as a result of falling land prices and a slump in the stock market since the start of the year.

According to analysts, the outlook is not much brighter. A recent rise in interest rates is expected to push many firms into bankruptcy, which will mean more uncollectable loans.

"There is a great deal of concern about bad loans," said Paul Migliorato, a broker at Credit Suisse First Boston. "And it's not likely to get better any time soon."

As well as this tough business environment, the painful but necessary reform needed at Mizuho and other banking groups is not likely to have been helped by a change of political climate.

With the end of the crisis, the sense of urgency in the government has dissipated. Since April, a new administration led by conservative prime minister Yoshiro Mori has taken a cautious stance towards financial sector reform that has alarmed many in parliament. It has supported weak construction companies, such as Hazama and Kumagai Gumi, that hold so many of the problem loans.

"Two years have passed since we started trying to clear up the financial system, but nothing has really changed. If anything the situation has deteriorated," said Yasuhiro Shiozaki, one of the legislators who drew up the banking reform plans two years ago. "We are just postponing the difficult decisions."

Investors have been rattled by similar concerns. Banking shares have lost more than 18% since August, compared to a 3% average decline by all stocks on the Tokyo stock exchange.

Although Mizuho made a smooth debut on the Tokyo bourse yesterday, analysts have given a mixed judgement on plans to turn the company around. The group's executives have promised to improve profitability by diversifying into more lucrative areas of business, making better use of information technology and cutting 7,000 employees, 20% of the workforce.

By 2005, the company said it will improve its return-on-equity ratio - the main measure of profitability - from 4% to 12%. Analysts have complained that this is slower than rival banking groups and still short of the 15% to 20% ratios usually offered in Europe and the US.

"The decision to merge was radical but the strategy for the bank is not as radical as the merger was," noted David Atkinson, a banking analyst at Goldman Sachs.

Merging institutions is clearly only the beginning of the modernisation process.

fields.headline: Day trading firm shut down
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: City regulators yesterday shut down one of the first "day trading" companies to be set up in Britain, prompting fears of hefty losses for scores of professional traders and investors.
fields.body:
City regulators yesterday shut down one of the first "day trading" companies to be set up in Britain, prompting fears of hefty losses for scores of professional traders and investors.

The securities and futures authority said it had issued an intervention order against International Clearing Associates (ICA) - halting its business - after establishing that it had "insufficient regulatory capital" to continue.

Most of ICA's business is thought to have come from many of the former traders on the London International Financial Futures and Options exchange, who needed new ways to deal after the exchange shut its trading floor and adopted an electronic system.

In addition to providing the behind the scenes mechanisms necessary for the traders to execute their deals, ICA also set up an online service named daytrader.co.uk with a view to replicating the day trading phenomenon which spread through the United States last year.

Only one of the directors of ICA, company secretary Michael Birch, could be reached last night. He said he only learned of the intervention order when contacted by the Guardian.

The SFA, which is in the process of being consumed into the new financial services authority regulatory body, said that ICA itself had notified it of the problems. The firm had told the SFA that it was seeking additional capital from existing shareholders and new investors.

But, the SFA said, ICA had "failed to obtain additional capital and SFA believes that there is no reasonable prospect of the firm having sufficient capital to satisfy requirements for the immediate future". Its intervention order instructed ICA to cease trading yesterday.

Last night, as sketchy details of the collapse began to emerge, there were fears that up to 80 former Liffe "locals", so-called because they used their own money to trade, risk losing huge deposits lodged with ICA to enable them to trade.

These traders are believed to have been dealing across a range of financial markets, including Eurex, the German equivalent of Liffe.

Documents filed with Companies House list three directors for ICA: Julian David Jesson, Paul Hegarty and Simon Tobias Durrant. None of them could be reached last night.

Mr Jesson is understood to have been one of the front runners in establishing so-called arcades - office suites housing banks of trading screens set up after the Liffe trading floor was closed, in an attempt to replicate the old camaraderie of the trading floor.

Liffe refused to comment but is expected to issue a notice this morning about the fate of ICA and its traders.

The episode follows the collapse two years ago of Griffin Trading, another firm which specialised in Liffe locals.

webTitle: Online bank goes live - but by phone only

fields.headline: Online bank goes live - but by phone only
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Net news
fields.trailText: Halifax's much-hyped telephone and internet bank Intelligent Finance promises to open this morning, more than two months later than planned.
fields.body:
Halifax's much-hyped telephone and internet bank Intelligent Finance promises to open this morning, more than two months later than planned.

IF, which has bought the rights to Fatboy Slim's hit Right Here, Right Now for advertising purposes, claims to be able to save each household taking out its products £500 a year.

The Edinburgh-based operation, into which Halifax is ploughing £120m over two years, will permit customers to open accounts and buy products only through its call centre at first. Its internet service will be opened to the public later on.

It is the Halifax's version of Abbey National's cahoot, which launched earlier this year and was immediately dogged by technology problems.

The advertising campaign, which began in July when it was supposed to have launched, will resume after the weekend. IF, which has been concerned that it could be swamped by customers, said that the first accounts had been opened yesterday, even before its official launch. IF is starting with a range of products, include current accounts, savings accounts, mortgages, credit cards and personal loans as well as insurance.

Jim Spowart, chief executive of IF, lured from Standard Life last year, calculated that 6m people could quality for a nil interest rate on their credit card.

fields.headline: Rock with attitude and a dusting of chaos
fields.standfirst:
Pere Ubu
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Pere Ubu
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
You could never argue that success has spoiled Pere Ubu. Twenty-five years after they emerged from the industrial desert of Ohio, Ubu continue to plough a perverse and eccentric furrow, with commendable enthusiasm. "There are so few of you, yet your appreciation is so precious to us," deadpanned David Thomas, still tethered to the helm half a lifetime later.

It's Thomas who supplies Ubu's ballast, in every respect. The freakish pitch changes of his voice give warning that no song is safe when he comes near it, while his cryptic introductions have become part of the performance. Scornful of dietary fads, Thomas is still a massively bulky presence at the microphone, a perverse mixture of Orson Welles and John Goodman.

Despite creating an illusion of cacophonousness, Ubu play what is basically rock with attitude, with a light dusting of chaos to remind us of their surrealist origins. Thomas spent the first few minutes striking dramatic postures while blowing down what looked like the kind of horn cyclists attach to their handlebars. Then he adorned himself with a red plastic apron covered with electronic gadgetry, enabling him to conjure weird sonic effects from the amplifiers. Even weirder, in fact, than those already coming from the theremin on the opposite side of the stage.

Ubu aren't exactly armed to the teeth with "hits", but their version of Final Solution was like an explosion in a scrapyard and quite epic in its way. They kept resisting shouts for Non-Alignment Pact but relented at the end, as fans stormed the stage and even ventured a spot of mild pogoing.

Ubu were joined for the encore by MC5 veteran Wayne Kramer, whose set earlier in the evening showed he hasn't abandoned hope that rock music has some value as a polemical medium with a political message. As his trio crunched out punkish riffs, Kramer rasped lyrics about sexual exploitation, drugs and bomb-making terrorists, punctuating his bulletins with screaming lead guitar. It was a salutary reminder of a time when people really did believe rock'n'roll could change the world.

Dance

Ariadone

Linbury Studio, Covent Garden ***

Ever since Nijinsky premiered his notorious Sacre du Printemps in 1913, the ballet has become a rite of passage for other choreographers. Artists as varied as Béjart, Pina Bausch and Michael Clark have all felt moved to recreate the work in their own image. How they handle it becomes a defining statement of their style. So it's no surprise that Carlotta Ikeda and her company Ariadone should produce a Rite which bears all the hallmarks of the Japanese expressionist form butoh: its seven female dancers masked from head to toe in white make-up, their bodies scrunched earnestly into slow moving postures of extreme visceral emotion.

What is surprising is that this sisterhood of keening, witchy dancers should also look back to 19th century ballet for their inspiration. The work certainly starts in classic butoh mode as the dancers appear wracked by the forces unleashed in Stravinsky's score. With their bodies curled into foetal self-protection and their faces frozen into howling screams, they seem maddened by the intensity of the primal, physical world. At other moments they seem to become nature itself as Ikeda gathers them into churning groups of movement, then lets them disperse into finely drawn tendrils of dance, suggesting flecks of foam on the water or rogue sea breezes. It's a vision of ancient terror and power, a very female vision of death and birth.

But then Ikeda seems to be calling up ghosts of older dancers to elaborate her vision, using fragments of Stravinsky's original Rite mixed with sounds of wind and sea, industrial machinery and distant wisps of song. A trio of women in ratty tutus, limbs contorted with savagely subversive humour, become mad little cygnets from Swan Lake. There are doll like Coppelias whose marionette cuteness is underscored with erotic mischief. Best are the Wilis (the ghosts of jilted women from Giselle) who cross the stage with a haunting off-kilter craziness.

The work also neatly turns around the final sacrificial solo in Rite - with Ikeda herself performing a dance of survival, and apparently containing the world's forces within her own inscrutably slow movement. It's a fine image, as fine as many which appear in the work. But its power is diluted by Ikeda's overall failure to pace and build her material. Butoh is always slow, but at best it sustains an intentness, a focus which staves off our restlessness. Ikeda's Haru No Saiten slips in and out of focus too readily within its 80-minute duration. It induces moments of wonderment but whole sections, unfortunately, of boredom too.

Theatre

Rumble Fish

Theatre Royal, York ***

The world premiere of the adaptation of SE Hinton's cult novel is something of a coup for Pilot Theatre Company. If it turns out to be less satisfactory than the company's last production, Lord of the Flies, it is not for want of theatrical daring - more to do with the fact that, for all its pseudo- Greek grandeur, Hinton's tale of brotherly love and hate in smalltown USA is big on teenage angst but small on more pressing world issues.

Adaptor and director Marcus Romer attempts some updating and there is a passing nod towards the connection between alienation, loneliness and the Columbine High School massacre. But there is little in the script that isn't conveyed more eloquently by his production, in which digital projection and live action are combined to quite brilliant and dislocating effect.

The overall impression is of something extraordinarily liquid, as if the entire performance is taking place in a giant goldfish bowl. A goldfish bowl which - as teenage tearaway Rusty James becomes increasingly obsessed with his brother, Motorcycle Boy - appears to fill with swirling patterns of blood. The sense of tension is added to by a continuous soundtrack that becomes a comment upon Rusty's increasingly agitated emotional internal world.

As in Francis Ford Coppola's movie version, the setting is almost timeless, maybe even futuristic, an impression added to by Ali Allen and Marise Rose's set, an urban concrete canyon complete with climbing wall. The actors use every inch of the space, both vertical and horizontal.

The increasing isolation of Rusty is cleverly done. This is a soul cut adrift: abandoned as a child by his mother, ignored by his drunken father, dumped by his girlfriend and rejected by his best friend. Romer's production places him in creasingly apart, bound only by an invisible umbilical cord to the brother who tolerates him but cannot embrace him.

Playing Rusty, Ari James is impressive on the boy's broken physicality, but vocally monotonous - particularly when conveying internal thought. These might work better as voiceovers. Most of the other characterisations are too skimpy to really make you care, although Ryan McClusky as Motorcycle Boy has a self-contained, detached glamour.

But for all its flaws, as with Lord of the Flies, there is a genuine sense of theatrical enquiry as it explores the relationship between theatre and digital technology, and triumphantly proves that they can be equal partners. And you can't complain about a show that gets 800 teenagers into the theatre on a wet Wednesday afternoon and generates the kind of rapt attention in which you could hear a pin drop.

Until October 7. Box office: 01904 623568. Then tours.

This is a soul cut adrift: abandoned as a child by his mother, ignored by his drunken father, dumped by his girlfriend and rejected by his best friend. Romer's production places him in creasingly apart, bound only by an invisible umbilical cord to the brother who tolerates him but cannot embrace him.

Playing Rusty, Ari James is impressive on the boy's broken physicality, but vocally monotonous - particularly when conveying internal thought. These might work better as voiceovers. Most of the other characterisations are too skimpy to really make you care, although Ryan McClusky as Motorcycle Boy has a self-contained, detached glamour.

But for all its flaws, as with Lord of the Flies, there is a genuine sense of theatrical enquiry as it explores the relationship between theatre and digital technology, and triumphantly proves that they can be equal partners. And you can't complain about a show that gets 800 teenagers into the theatre on a wet Wednesday afternoon and generates the kind of rapt attention in which you could hear a pin drop.

Until October 7. Box office: 01904 623568. Then tours.

If it turns out to be less satisfactory than the company's last production, Lord of the Flies, it is not for want of theatrical daring - more to do with the fact that, for all its pseudo- Greek grandeur, Hinton's tale of brotherly love and hate in smalltown USA is big on teenage angst but small on more pressing world issues. fields.headline: Markets brace for impact
fields.standfirst:
Analysts rule out long-term effects
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Denmark's cliff-hanging referendum on the European single currency was being closely watched by global financial markets after last week's intervention to halt its plummeting value against the US dollar.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Copenhagen and  Mark Milner  in Paris
fields.body:
Denmark's cliff-hanging referendum on the European single currency was being closely watched by global financial markets after last week's intervention to halt its plummeting value against the US dollar.

But beyond the short-term effect on the credibility of the euro, the Danish result could have significant implications for the future political development of the EU. There is also its potential knock-on effect on both Britain and Swe den, the other two EU members which still have to commit to the single currency.

The outcome also means that the next countries to adopt the single currency could be the relatively poor candidate countries of central and eastern Europe, such as Poland and Hungary, which are expected to start joining around the middle of this decade.

And it still leaves in the balance whether the EU will develop at two different speeds, with more integrationist-minded members forging ahead.

With pressure already growing to formalise the role of the eurogroup - composed of the current 11, plus Greece, joining next January - moves to coordinate national economic policies more closely will not be far behind. Ecofin, the forum of all 15 EU finance min isters, of which the chancellor, Gordon Brown, is a member, could find itself being increasingly marginalised when key decisions are made.

On the foreign exchanges, the euro traded nervously in a narrow range against the dollar, with dealers glued to screens showing the latest opinion polls, though last week's heavyweight intervention to prop up the single currency has limited the scope of foreign exchange market reaction. "People are concerned about the big US beast lurking round the corner so that will limit the impact," said one analyst.

Others were dismissive of any fallout from the Danish referendum. "Are we seriously asked to believe that the votes of a few thousand Danes [the difference between No and Yes voters] will alter the fortunes of an economic area of 275m people?" asked Nick Parsons, currency analyst at Commerzbank.

Denmark continues to face a long-term problem over its other Maastricht treaty opt-outs, on defence and justice and home affairs, which are likely to be the main growth areas of European integration in the coming years.

Last night's results were being watched closely in Stockholm, where the prime minister, Goran Persson, who unlike Mr Blair or Denmark's Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, does not have a formal opt-out on the currency, has to decide whether to call a referendum.

The narrowness of the result will give little comfort to Europhiles, already concerned about an increasing trend towards cooperation among member states and a move away from the supranational European Commission in Brussels. The Danish message to an ambitious elite project could feed into long-standing concerns about the democratic deficit, expressed in the low turnout in elections to the European parliament.

Across the continent, governments are already smarting from being taken by surprise by the recent protests over fuel prices, which the EU proved powerless to influence.

The vote comes before December's EU summit in Nice, already due to debate a so- called "flexbility" clause which countries like France and Germany want to be able to form what President Jacques Chirac calls a "pioneer group."

Mr Chirac, whose country holds the union's rotating presidency, warned Mr Blair last June that if integration-minded states were not able to move forward within the EU, they would do so outside it.

fields.headline: Sanderling's perfect Shostakovich
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia/Sanderling
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Philharmonia/Sanderling
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
Shostakovich's 15th Symphony is, for many, one of the composer's most perplexing works. Written when he was seriously ill, it was his last statement in the genre - and, far from taking the form of a self-conscious Mahlerian farewell, it's characterised by an enigmatic inscrutability.

In some respects, it pre-empts post-modernism: the music suddenly defines itself by becoming endlessly refer ential. A plethora of quotes and allusions - to Shostakovich's own music, to works by Rossini, Wagner, Glinka and Mahler - are woven into a spectral texture that sounds like a collage of vague reminiscences. Throughout its course, you sense time running out, and the symphony closes in a percussive miasma of ticking clocks and chronometers. The passage derives from Shostakovich's 4th Symphony, suppressed by the composer at the height of Stalin's purges when time was running out in a very different sense.

Veteran Kurt Sanderling has long been regarded as one of the work's finest interpreters. Eighty-eight this year, he left Germany for Russia when the Nazis came to power and subsequently worked closely with Shostakovich. He still uses a score of the 15th inscribed and annotated by the composer, and his version consequently has a powerful claim to authenticity.

He pares the sonorities down to a sparse, yet sweet clarity. The barrage of quotes is indelibly worked into the symphony's fabric rather than emerging as a sequence of brain-teasing puzzles. Throughout, you feel on unsafe ground as emotions are stirred then quashed by irony. The Philharmonia clearly adore him and the playing was outstanding. Definitive stuff.

In some respects, the 15th could be dubbed a "Sinfonia Concertante" since it derives much of its dynamism from the contrast between the full orchestra and a series of recitative-like instrumental solos that break in upon the texture.

Sanderling tellingly couples it with what is arguably the greatest of all works in the genre: Mozart's E Flat Sinfonia Concertante for violin and viola. A piece of almost operatic resonance, it consistently flashes forward to Cosi fan Tutte, involving its soloists in a sequence of dialogues by turns amorous, argumentative and reconciliatory.

The great Gidon Kremer and the brilliant young Latvian viola player Ula Ulijona were the protagonists, with Kremer's exquisite poise and silver tone by turns melding and conflicting with Ulijona's more romantic, rhapsodic approach. Sanderling uses larger orchestral forces than is common in Mozart nowaday, though he more than justifies his decision since the Philharmonia sound was ravishing throughout.

fields.headline: Manchester's Asian Pulp Fiction
fields.standfirst:
Revelations
Contact, Manchester
**
fields.trailText:
Revelations
Contact, Manchester

**
fields.body:
When Dum is born, his grandfather names him Dharma, meaning duty. But 20 years later, the noose of duty begins to loosen as Dum travels with his friends up the M1, the backbone of England, to scatter his grandfather's ashes over Hadrian's Wall. The third part of Tara Arts's Journey To the West trilogy, which maps the passage of three genera tions of 20th-century Asians from India to Africa to England, Revelations looks at what it means to be young and Asian in Britain today.

Jatinder Verma's story-within-a-story production, devised after extensive interviews with young British Asians, takes its cue from other great storytelling epics such as the Ramayana and Pulp Fiction. But the one it most closely resembles is that most English of storytelling journeys: the Canterbury Tales.

As Dum and his friend travel north, they are entertained by ancient stories and encounter fantasy versions of England such as Caxton Gibbit - where Greensleeves plays endlessly, hard-working middle-class Asians are welcomed, and blacks excluded and murdered.

When it is not succumbing either to a Goodness Gracious Me-style jokiness or an urge to create youth appeal with its DJ mix soundtrack, the piece plays cleverly with ideas of national identity without exploring them in any depth. It is at its most potent as it looks at the pressures faced by young people like Dum, who have seen their parents work long hours and suffer racial harassment running the cornershop to provide them with private educations and the opportunity to become lawyers, pharmacists and accountants. What happens if your parents' dream is not your dream?

The conflict between one generation and the next has been charted more persuasively and entertainingly in plays such as Ayub Khan-Din's East is East. Despite the extensive research, which makes compulsive reading in the programme, there is a scrappiness about how it has been translated into drama. The piece only really comes alive in the final 10 minutes as grandfather, mother and son come to blows when the gulf between their individual desires and hopes becomes startlingly apparent.

But this is an evening that talks a good show rather than delivers one, and Verma's production doesn't do itself any favours by mixing theatrical styles that never meld into a satisfactory or coherent whole.

Until tomorrow. Box office: 0161 274 0600. Then tours. Details: 020 8333 4457.

fields.headline: Close pledges to stay independent
fields.standfirst:
Winterflood sale speculation dismissed

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Close Brothers pledged to remain independent yesterday in the face of takeovers sweeping through the investment banking sector.
fields.body:
Close Brothers pledged to remain independent yesterday in the face of takeovers sweeping through the investment banking sector.

The largest of the few remaining stock market-listed British investment banks will also resist any sale of its Winterflood Securities arm, where profits trebled last year as private investors clambered to buy dot.com stocks. As a result bumper bonuses are expected at the broking firm.

Rod Kent, chief executive of Close Brothers, described Winterflood as "one of our crown jewels" and dismissed speculation that a sale of the business was planned as "ill-founded and completely wrong".

"In 25 years we have built up businesses and never sold them," Mr Kent said.

In the face of the scramble by the leading investment banks to become even bigger, Mr Kent said: "We're not global and we don't want to be."

He insisted Close benefited when rivals were taken over, pointing to a team of Middle East specialists recruited by the bank from Robert Fleming after its sale to Chase Manhattan of the US.

A "fantastic period" for Winterflood allowed Close to report a 103% rise in pre-tax profits to £155m. Of that profit figure, £50m was generated from the explosion in share dealing between November and March during the height of the frenzied buying of hi-tech shares.

The bank admitted that these hectic stock market conditions were unlikely to return during this year and lead to such a fast rise in profits. But, it insisted that the new trading year, which began in August, had started well.

Winterflood has now expanded from its origins of executing trades in the UK stock market for private client stock brokers. It is offering share dealing services for European stocks and later this year will be able to buy and sell shares in the United States.

Mr Kent also pointed to strong growth in Close's corporate finance and asset management operations, boosted by the acquisition of Rea Brothers last year. The bank has made its mark in advising smaller and medium sized business on mergers and acquisitions and on creating investment funds in niche markets such as hi-tech stocks.

The once core business of Close Brothers, its asset finance business, was one of the poorest performing areas, hit by the falling prices of cars. It makes hire purchase arrangements for secondhand cars and will reveal in its annual report next week that profits fell from £4.2m to £800,000.

Mr Kent, who has run Close Brothers for the past 25 years, showed no signs of being ready to hand over the reins to a colleague. Despite the rapid rate of growth of Winterflood, he was determined to highlight the 31% rise in operating profits in the other parts of business to deflect criticism that the business was too reliant on the potentially volatile stock broking business.

Close shares ended the day 5p lower at £12.25. It will pay a final dividend of 17p, which takes the total for the year to 25p.

fields.headline: Ariadone
fields.standfirst:
Linbury Studio, Covent Garden
***
fields.trailText:
Linbury Studio, Covent Garden
***
fields.body:
Ever since Nijinsky premiered his notorious Sacre du Printemps in 1913, the ballet has become a rite of passage for other choreographers. Artists as varied as Béjart, Pina Bausch and Michael Clark have all felt moved to recreate the work in their own image. How they handle it becomes a defining statement of their style. So it's no surprise that Carlotta Ikeda and her company Ariadone should produce a Rite which bears all the hallmarks of the Japanese expressionist form butoh: its seven female dancers masked from head to toe in white make-up, their bodies scrunched earnestly into slow moving postures of extreme visceral emotion.

What is surprising is that this sisterhood of keening, witchy dancers should also look back to 19th century ballet for their inspiration. The work certainly starts in classic butoh mode as the dancers appear wracked by the forces unleashed in Stravinsky's score. With their bodies curled into foetal self-protection and their faces frozen into howling screams, they seem maddened by the intensity of the primal, physical world. At other moments they seem to become nature itself as Ikeda gathers them into churning groups of movement, then lets them disperse into finely drawn tendrils of dance, suggesting flecks of foam on the water or rogue sea breezes. It's a vision of ancient terror and power, a very female vision of death and birth.

But then Ikeda seems to be calling up ghosts of older dancers to elaborate her vision, using fragments of Stravinsky's original Rite mixed with sounds of wind and sea, industrial machinery and distant wisps of song. A trio of women in ratty tutus, limbs contorted with savagely subversive humour, become mad little cygnets from Swan Lake. There are doll like Coppelias whose marionette cuteness is underscored with erotic mischief. Best are the Wilis (the ghosts of jilted women from Giselle) who cross the stage with a haunting off-kilter craziness.

The work also neatly turns around the final sacrificial solo in Rite - with Ikeda herself performing a dance of survival, and apparently containing the world's forces within her own inscrutably slow movement. It's a fine image, as fine as many which appear in the work. But its power is diluted by Ikeda's overall failure to pace and build her material. Butoh is always slow, but at best it sustains an intentness, a focus which staves off our restlessness. Ikeda's Haru No Saiten slips in and out of focus too readily within its 80-minute duration. It induces moments of wonderment but whole sections, unfortunately, of boredom too.

fields.headline: Rex Levitates
fields.standfirst:
Dublin theatre festival fringe
***
fields.trailText:
Dublin theatre festival fringe
***
fields.body:
Although more used to playing outdoors in Temple Bar, the young Rex Levitates company score considerable theatrical kudos in staging two rather mysterious pieces of contemporary dance, collectively titled Blush, and created by 25-year old choreographer Liz Roche. The first, Shhh, is a dramatic duet for two female dancers, who patrol and nudge each other into self-awareness, falling into and away from each other. Lisa McLoughlin dances a waifish, wallflowerish character who wants to escape into the torpor of her private world; while Roche's statuesque dancer-sister Jenny powerfully overarches, amuses and protects her.

There's enormous fluidity and dynamism to the rhythms, which are occasionally accelerated or dramatised by ragtime, French fatale chanson or tango. They provide the tone and vocabulary of the second, more substantial piece, To Time Taking Blush. Once again, the piece emerges through the dangling belch of a smoke machine, and benefits a lot from Nick McCall's lighting and costumes originally designed by Phyllis Byrne of Dundee - hoop dresses worn by the four women and, curiously, one of the two men.

Supposedly inspired by Fauvist painters, it starts and finishes with a dramatic, red-against-blue image of a doll-like ballerina, revealed by the opening of back-curtains so vast they make the dancers resemble music-box miniatures.

Despite the constant flurries of movement, the dancers seem to battle against inertia, huddling into sleepy piles, until the pinching games begin, and they pull each other into drowsy wrestling, lifting, rolling, pulling, pushing and trading weight. There is something gently hypnotic and oddly affecting about the images: the woman disturbed while her male partner sleeps; a beautifully sticky sexual encounter; two women dancers coming downstage into white light with their arms outstretched and calmly regarding the audience, before being forced down by other dancers.

I have seen more energetic work by the Roches (Liz's brother Denis provides electronic music) but they are developing an extraordinarily subtle gestural language here, although it is hard to know what they are getting at dramatically. You sometimes wish they would be bolder with their visual statements - but, heck, this is certainly auspicious.

 At the Samuel Beckett Centre, Dublin, until tomorrow. Box office: 00 353 1 608 2461.
fields.bodyText: Although more used to playing outdoors in Temple Bar, the young Rex Levitates company score considerable theatrical kudos in staging two rather mysterious pieces of contemporary dance, collectively titled Blush, and created by 25-year old choreographer Liz Roche. The first, Shhh, is a dramatic duet for two female dancers, who patrol and nudge each other into self-awareness, falling into and away from each other. Lisa McLoughlin dances a waifish, wallflowerish character who wants to escape into the torpor of her private world; while Roche's statuesque dancer-sister Jenny powerfully overarches, amuses and protects her. There's enormous fluidity and dynamism to the rhythms, which are occasionally accelerated or dramatised by ragtime, French fatale chanson or tango. They provide the tone and vocabulary of the second, more substantial piece, To Time Taking Blush. Once again, the piece emerges through the dangling belch of a smoke machine, and benefits a lot from Nick McCall's lighting and costumes originally designed by Phyllis Byrne of Dundee - hoop dresses worn by the four women and, curiously, one of the two men. Supposedly inspired by Fauvist painters, it starts and finishes with a dramatic, red-against-blue image of a doll-like ballerina, revealed by the opening of back-curtains so vast they make the dancers resemble music-box miniatures. Despite the constant flurries of movement, the dancers seem to battle against inertia, huddling into sleepy piles, until the pinching games begin, and they pull each other into drowsy wrestling, lifting, rolling, pulling, pushing and trading weight. There is something gently hypnotic and oddly affecting about the images: the woman disturbed while her male partner sleeps; a beautifully sticky sexual encounter; two women dancers coming downstage into white light with their arms outstretched and calmly regarding the audience, before being forced down by other dancers. I have seen more energetic work by the Roches (Liz's brother Denis provides electronic music) but they are developing an extraordinarily subtle gestural language here, although it is hard to know what they are getting at dramatically. webTitle: Schmeichel shows Spartak the way back

fields.headline: Schmeichel shows Spartak the way back
fields.trailText: Two goals by the Brazilian substitute Marcao and one by his compatriot Luis Robson gave Spartak Moscow a 3-1 win over the Portuguese side Sporting in their Champions League Group A tie last night.
fields.body:
Two goals by the Brazilian substitute Marcao and one by his compatriot Luis Robson gave Spartak Moscow a 3-1 win over the Portuguese side Sporting in their Champions League Group A tie last night.

Marcao, a mid-season purchase to beef up Spartak's attack, scored in the 67th and 81st minutes to help the Moscow side to one of their best wins in European competition, boosting their chances of reaching the second phase.

It all looked very different when Sporting's Sa Pinto silenced the capacity 70,000 crowd at the Luzhniki stadium with a 24th-minute goal after the Spartak goalkeeper Alexander Filimonov had dropped the ball following a corner.

It was Sporting's goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel who was at fault for Spartak's equaliser in the 43rd minute. He failed to clear the ball and Robson pounced to send his shot over the Danish international.

Marco Simone scored a hat-trick as Monaco beat Austria's Sturm Graz 5-0. The result saw Monaco leapfrog the Austrian side into third place behind Galatasaray and Rangers in Group D.

Steve McManaman was a spectator on the Real Madrid bench as the Spanish giants came back from 2-1 down to win 3-2 away to Bayer Leverkusen. Roberto Carlos scored twice in the Group A fixture and Guti added another.

Zlatko Zahovic, the Slovenia captain, scored the only goal of the game for Valencia to secure all three points at home to Lyon in Group C.

fields.headline: Jardel drowns bumbling Rangers
fields.standfirst: A Bulent 51, Unsal 57, Jardel 69 | Kanchelskis 71, Van Bronckhorst 90
fields.trailText: A blistering left-foot volley from Jardel confirmed Galatasary's ascendancy as Rangers shuddered to a halt on a torrid night in Istanbul.
fields.body:
Rangers have finally shuddered to a halt in Group D, though given their previous bold antics, this result might not seem such a calamity once a torrid night in Istanbul has cooled in the senses. Galatasaray are gradually finding resolve and are now comfortably poised for a winter offensive in Europe.

The memory of this night will remain a stupendously lashed left-foot volley from Jardel, a Brazilian who had previously looked a shadow of his £18m transfer ticket, which blew past Stefan Klos and confirmed Galatasary's ascendancy on the night. Rangers puffed away as the Turks pierced them but could draw little blood.

This was nothing like Dick Advocaat and Rangers experienced in Monaco last week. On the Cote d'Azur everything that could have gone Rangers' way happened; their Turkish hosts weren't so welcoming. Galatasaray played this match with a degree of pent-up aggression which was hardly a surprise given the Turks' fate recently. The rain bucketed down on the Ali Sami Yen Stadium, rather appropriately, for Mircea Lucescu, Galatasaray's embattled manager, has drowned in a critical storm in recent weeks.

This team's raucous supporters still crave the presence of Fatih Terim, the man who brought Galatasaray a championship, a Uefa Cup and a European Super Cup last season, but who in the summer grabbed his CV and scarpered to Fiorentina. Patchy league form and a stumbling Champions League start hasn't helped poor Lucescu.

Last night the Romanian wasn't helped by the further loss of four key players, including the suspended Gheorge Hagi and Suat Kaya, as well as the injured Okan Buruk and the ill Brazilian, Capone. Hagi, when he behaves, is a loss to any team, though since Euro 2000 the little genius has been acting like a delinquent. Nor can the constant drumbeat of this stadium do anything for any player of brittle temperament.

Rangers, by contrast, were buoyed by Monaco, though Advocaat's tactical decision to play precisely the same team in the same shape proved stillborn the moment Belozoglu Emre began dropping off behind Jardel for Galatasaray.

None of this, though, takes account of Lorenzo Amoruso, the Rangers captain, whose defending is always a mix of bravery and buffoonery. Amoruso had already let Jardel escape his clutches to scuff a shot wide in front of Stefan Klos before, moments from the interval, the Italian ballooned a clearance high and spinning in the direction of his goalkeeper, who frantically palmed it onto his own crossbar.

On these occasions it is always heartening to witness Amoruso's reaction - this time, like every other time, it wasn't his fault, the Italian's finger angrily wagging in his team-mates' direction.

The game abruptly disintegrated for Rangers from the 51st minute. On the balance of play Galatasaray probably deserved their lead, though Rangers will rage at the way they conceded the goal. Hakan Unsal's short corner to Ergun caught the Ibrox side napping, and when Ergun's cross arrived, Bulent whacked into Klos's right-hand corner.

Within minutes Rangers fell fell further behind, this time to something exquisite. It didn't seem to matter from whom or how Davala Umit gathered the ball 25 yards from goal - the next seconds deemed these details irrelevant. Rarely can poor Klos have faced a shot of such suspended, dipping menace as Umit's effort arced towards him and loped into his net.

Jardel was finally allowed to apply his golden touch to these proceedings with a majestic left-foot volley from Umit's high cross after 69 minutes. Rangers fought back two minutes later with a header from Andrei Kanchelskis, while Giovanni Van Bronckhorst drove in a direct free kick in the final minute. It was, however, too little, too late.

Galatasaray (4-4-1-1): Taffarel; Fatih, Popescu, K Bulent, Unsal; Umit, A Bulent, Ergun, Hasan (Ahmet, 88min); Belozoglu (Faruk, 75); Jardel.

Rangers (3-4-3): Klos; Amoruso, Tugay, Konterman; Reyna, Ferguson, Van Bronckhorst, Numan; Johnston (Kanchelskis, 58), Mols (Dodds, 67), De Boer.

Referee: P Collina (Italy).

fields.headline: Lazio cop a lacing from Ljungberg
fields.standfirst: Ljungberg 43, 56
fields.trailText: A fabulous display and two goals from Arsenal's Swedish midfielder Fredrik Ljungberg stunned Lazio, the favourites to win Group B, and left Arsène Wenger's team with maximum points from three matches.
fields.body:
Arsenal looked like true Champions Leaguers here last night. Two goals from their Swedish midfielder Fredrik Ljungberg, both set up by Dennis Bergkamp, stunned Lazio, the favourites to win Group B, and left Arsène Wenger's team with maximum points from three matches and an outstanding chance of reaching the second round.

The victory was a reward for a positive approach by Arsenal and their manager. From the outset they took the game to Lazio, who were never allowed to settle and eventually found themselves outmanoeuvred and outwitted by Bergkamp's skill and vision and Ljungberg's finishing.

Yet only a week earlier the Gunners had scared Highbury out of its wits by going 2-0 down to Shakhtar Donetsk before recovering to win 3-2 by the skin of their teeth. Wenger's players knew that against Lazio similar generosity was less likely to be similarly redeemed.

Not that Wenger approached the match in a defensive frame of mind. Up front, Nwankwo Kanu and Thierry Henry were closely supported by Bergkamp, ostensibly playing on the right but with licence to roam.

Such a bold plan risked Arsenal's midfield being outnumbered in an area where Lazio were particularly strong and at risk from quick Roman counter-attacks. But the willingness with which Arsenal's central defenders Tony Adams and Martin Keown stayed in an attack after a free-kick or corner re-emphasised the team's positive frame of mind.

Patience, however, had to be foremost. Against players of the quality of Pavel Nedved, Diego Simeone and Juan Veron, Arsenal could not afford to give the ball away through undue haste. So they constructed their movements with care, seemingly prepared to play 10 passes or more as they searched for an opening.

No simple matter this, with Alessandro Nesta, arguably the best defender of Euro 2000, guarding the heart of Lazio's back four while alongside him stood the Yugoslav Sinisa Mihajlovic, wearing a face mask either to protect a recent injury or because he had voted the wrong way in the Serbian election.

For much of the first half Lazio were content to absorb Arsenal attacks which tended to break down on the final pass. After 20 minutes, when Kanu did at last find Henry in space, the French striker's shot was weak and wide.

Just past the half-hour Patrick Vieira found Silvinho on the right and while Nesta's head intercepted the Brazilian's hard, dipping centre Keown followed up with a volley which did not trouble Luca Marchiegiani but reminded Highbury that Arsenal could still shoot straight.

In fact the Lazio goalkeeper's best save of the half came from one of his own men, Simone Inzaghi, whose attempt to nod clear an inswinging free-kick from Bergkamp became a sharp downward header which Marchegiani stopped on the goal-line.

That was in the 40th minute. Three more minutes and Arsenal were in front with a goal of delightful invention and simplicity. Kanu's crossfield lob was met by Bergkamp, who nodded it square for the incoming Ljungberg to meet the ball first time and give the goalkeeper no chance.

Lazio's response was to replace a midfielder, Dejan Stankovic, with a forward, Attilio Lombardo, at half-time. Stankovic had been cautioned towards the end of the first half for fouling Silvinho and risked dismissal two minutes later for upending Henry. So the change was as much prudent as tactical.

Either way this did not seem important as Arsenal needed only 11 minutes of the second half to increase their lead. Again Bergkamp was the provider, Ljungberg the scorer.

Gathering a ball from Oleg Luzhny, Bergkamp ran at an oblique angle towards the Lazio defence before slipping a pass through the legs of Paolo Negro. The pass coincided perfectly with Ljungberg's sprint from the left and the Swede beat Marchegiani with a firm shot.

Given the difficulty Arsenal had had in breaking down the Lazio cover for most of the first half, the ease with which they had gone 2-0 up was remarkable. But the footballing brain of Bergkamp has long since been accustomed to picking the locks of the tightest defences.

Now of course Lazio were much more inclined to attack in large numbers, yet their vaunted midfield still could not gain the grip its quality had suggested. Vieira and Ray Parlour continued to break up their movements before they gained a decent momentum.

Just past the hour Parlour brought down Nedved to get a yellow card. The Czech's swerving free-kick might have caused David Seaman a problem had it not been unwittingly blocked by Negro before it could reach the goalkeeper.

Free-kicks looked Lazio's best chance of getting back into the contest. With their midfield neutralised, neither Inzaghi nor Claudio Lopez were getting the sort of service they needed to disturb Adams and Keown.

Arsenal (4-3-1-2): Seaman; Luzhny, Keown, Adams, Silvinho; Parlour, Vieira, Ljungberg; Bergkamp; Kanu, Henry.

Lazio (4-4-2): Marchegiani; Negro, Nesta, Mihajlovic, Pancaro; Stankovic, Simeone, Veron, Nedved; Claudio Lopez, Inzaghi.

Referee: J M Garcia-Aranda (Spain).

webTitle: Euro opponents celebrate early results in Danish euro referendum

fields.headline: Euro opponents celebrate early results in Danish euro referendum
fields.trailText:
The beleaguered euro faced a tight race to the end, but the nay-sayers
pulled ahead in initial results from a referendum on whether to replace the 125-year-old krone with the EU's common currency.
fields.body:
The beleaguered euro faced a tight race to the end, but the nay-sayers pulled ahead in initial results from a referendum on whether to replace the 125-year-old krone with the EU's common currency.

With 40.7 percent of the vote counted, it was 52.5 percent against the euro and 47.5 percent in favor, according to the Interior Ministry.

Euro opponents were starting to celebrate as early results showed their side ahead in the Scandinavian country's fifth referendum on EU-related issues since it joined what became the European Union in 1973.

Despite a reputation as EU skeptics, Danes have only said no in one of those referendums - in 1992, when they rejected the Maastricht treaty for a common currency and a common defense.

"It looks great. It'a a victory for democracy, for the Danish people, Pia Kjaersgaard, the leader of far-right Danish People's Party that opposes the euro said, as she walked up the main staircase at parliament smiling and holding flowers - surrounded by reporters and photographers.

Danish radio reported that turnout among 4 million eligible voters was above 86 percent, near the record 90.1 percent of October 1972, when membership in the then-European Community was approved. The Interior Ministry had yet to issue official figures.

The Social Democratic-led government, which has strongly supported the euro, sounded glum but pointed to the narrow margin in results so far.

"I'm not disappointed, but I admit it looks difficult," said Economics Minister Marianne Jelved.

French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, whose country holds the six-month rotating EU presidency, said that a rejection would not pressure the euro because Denmark's economy makes up only a small part of the EU's economy.

"I have a lot of respect for this country but its size for the European economy is not major," he said in Paris. "I do not think (a rejection) will be a problem for a currency which must be a stable currency at the appropriate level."

The euro took effect in 11 of 15 EU countries in January 1999 for corporate and investment transactions, with coins and bills to be introduced in January 2002. Denmark, Britain and Sweden opted out, while Greece, initially barred from membership because of high inflation and a budget deficit, will join on January 1.

EU officials, who also said a 'yes' vote in Denmark would help the euro but a rejection would have no effect, planned to meet Friday in Brussels, Belgium, to discuss the currency after the Danish.

Yesterday's vote was also being closely watched by Sweden and Britain, whose governments support joining the EMU but plan to let the public decide in as-yet referendums. Even non-EU member Norway was watching as it undergoes renewed debate on whether to join the trading bloc at all.

British Prime Minister Tony Blair played down the potential impact on a future vote in his country. "Denmark's got its own decision, we've got our own decision," he said.

Denmark already ties its fiscal and monetary decisions to those made by the 11-member euro zone, which forms the bulk of its export market. Supporters say membership in the European Monetary Union will give it more influence. Many opponents say the euro threatens Denmark's extensive welfare state and will lead to an erosion of sovereignty, as more powers are ceded to EU headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, and the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany. The outcome of the race was unpredictable as daily polls this week and exit surveys during the voting showed a statistical dead heat, prompting longtime anti-EU campaigner Jens-Peter Bonde of the grass-roots June Movement to call it "the worst thriller." German Finance Minister Hans Eichel said it was in Denmark's best interest to adopt the euro, but Europe would survive a rejection.

"Europe will go forward. European integration is a historic process that isn't reversible," Eichel said in Berlin. "But the earlier one is there, the better."

Social worker Fritz Olsen said he made up his mind to reject the euro as soon as the government announced the referendum in February.

"If you say yes, you change to a central bank where you haven't got any more democratic influence," Olsen, 59, said as he waited for a bus on a street named after Danish fairy tale writer Hans Christian Andersen.

Danes stunned fellow EU nations in 1992 by rejecting the Maastricht treaty for a common currency and a common defence. A year later, voters approved a revised treaty with clauses allowing it to initially stay out of the currency and the defence cooperation.

Recalling the violent riots that followed the 1993 referendum, police stepped up patrols in downtown Copenhagen, but no troubles were reported.

The euro-zone countries are Germany, France, Italy, Finland, Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Ireland, Portugal, Spain and Austria.

Many opponents say the euro threatens Denmark's extensive welfare state and will lead to an erosion of sovereignty, as more powers are ceded to EU headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, and the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany. The outcome of the race was unpredictable as daily polls this week and exit surveys during the voting showed a statistical dead heat, prompting longtime anti-EU campaigner Jens-Peter Bonde of the grass-roots June Movement to call it "the worst thriller." German Finance Minister Hans Eichel said it was in Denmark's best interest to adopt the euro, but Europe would survive a rejection. "Europe will go forward. European integration is a historic process that isn't reversible," Eichel said in Berlin. "But the earlier one is there, the better." Social worker Fritz Olsen said he made up his mind to reject the euro as soon as the government announced the referendum in February. "If you say yes, you change to a central bank where you haven't got any more democratic influence," Olsen, 59, said as he waited for a bus on a street named after Danish fairy tale writer Hans Christian Andersen. Danes stunned fellow EU nations in 1992 by rejecting the Maastricht treaty for a common currency and a common defence. A year later, voters approved a revised treaty with clauses allowing it to initially stay out of the currency and the defence cooperation. Recalling the violent riots that followed the 1993 referendum, police stepped up patrols in downtown Copenhagen, but no troubles were reported. The euro-zone countries are Germany, France, Italy, Finland, Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Ireland, Portugal, Spain and Austria.

webTitle: Ferry disaster: what the Greek papers say

fields.headline: Ferry disaster: what the Greek papers say
fields.standfirst: Sunken ferry's captain charged with murder
fields.trailText: The Greek media has reacted with a barrage of questions amid mounting speculation as to the causes of yesterday's shipwreck, in which at least 65 people died when a packed ferry collided with a clearly visible rock outcrop.
fields.body:
The Greek media has reacted with a barrage of questions amid mounting speculation as to the causes of yesterday's shipwreck, in which at least 65 people died when a packed ferry collided with a clearly visible rock outcrop.

"After the tragedy, will there be catharsis?" asks national daily Kathimerini. Like many papers, it focuses on accusations that crew members had been arguing over who would watch the Panathinaikos-Hamburg soccer match. But this does not imply that the crew on the bridge was watching the game, the paper says.

Crew member Panayiotis Gastaglis, who had been on helm duty, tells the Athens News Agency that although all instruments indicated the boat was sailing in the right direction, the wind threw the boat off course. By the time he saw the outcrop appear "there wasn't even one chance in a million that I could have done something to prevent the collision," he says.

Crew members told Rhodes' Demokratiki tis Rodou there was no human error. One told the paper: "Usually we pass the Two Portes at a distance of 300 to 400 metres, depending on the conditions at sea. From seeing the beacon a long way off, suddenly we saw it in front of us As soon as we saw the rocks, the collision happened. Immediately the engines cut out, and the boat began to sink."

Athens News points to the confusion over the response of the merchant marine ministry - saying the ship's distress call took eight minutes to reach the ministry, and that the rescue operation was delayed. It focuses attention on a Puma rescue helicopter, allegedly ready for use but never sent to aid passengers. While the defence ministry said the crew had not completed training, other reports said the pilots were ready and that the merchant marine ministry took almost five hours to respond to the offer.

Kathimerini's English edition devotes much attention to the 1966 disaster in which the passenger ferry Iraklion sank with the loss of 226 lives after an unsecured truck punctured the hull. "Thirty-four years later, history has repeated itself," the paper says.

webTitle: Patients to be offered operation booking system in some hospitals

fields.headline: Patients to be offered operation booking system in some hospitals
fields.standfirst: Patients to get more control over timing of operations
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn, the health secretary, promised patients more control over the timing of their operations in a speech which launched a raft of NHS reforms.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, promised patients more control over the timing of their operations yesterday in a speech which launched a raft of NHS reforms and further details of the long-awaited national cancer plan.

By March next year, all NHS hospitals are to start offering an appointment booking system to give at least some of their patients more control over the timing of operations. By March 2002, 43 hospitals should be able to offer every day surgery patient a booked appointment allowing them to pick a time to suit their family, caring work or holiday needs.

While Mr Milburn was on his feet in Brighton, Mike Richards, the cancer tsar now reborn as national cancer director, was putting flesh on the bones of his national plan, some of which was revealed by the prime minister on Tuesday.

An extra £50m is to be invested in palliative care and hospices and GPs are to be helped and supported to diagnose cancer and help those who leave hospital after treatment by designated cancer GPs. One of these will be funded in every primary care trust, jointly by Macmillan Cancer Relief and the government.

Prof Richards revealed a new smoking target - to cut smoking rates in manual classes, among whom cancer and heart disease is highest, from 32%in 1988 to 26% by 2010. A new healthy eating campaign will be launched to encourage fruit and vegetable consumption, and patients will be given more information about the risks as well as benefits of cancer screening.

Mr Milburn got a standing ovation after his first conference speech as health secretary. Delegates cheered his promise to abolish compulsory competitive tendering for catering, cleaning and other hospital services.

Since 1983 hospitals have been obliged to offer private sector firms an opportunity to compete for these contracts. Mr Milburn said this resulted in a race to provide the cheapest service, lowering standards of cleanliness.

"Compulsory competitive tendering has... damaged the NHS for too long. It will now go," he said.

Instead hospitals will be required to demonstrate value for money, with greater emphasis on satisfaction and quality as well as cost. Other announcements included £50m more for carers looking after relatives at home. Up to 75,000 more of them will get grants to provide cover when they take a break from minding older, infirm, disabled and sick people.

Mr Milburn promises to increase the number of chest pain clinics to diagnose patients with suspected heart disease from 50 to 84 by next April. Appointments will be arranged within a fortnight.

He recalled how his close friend Ian Weir, a photographer on the Northern Echo, died last year at 35 while waiting for a heart operation. "The NHS let down Ian Weir... there were far too many waiting just like him. In governments you listen and you learn. We will end long waiting in cardiac and cancer services, across the health service."

Delegates responded enthusiastically when Mr Melburn promised more power and more pay for nurses and doctors.

Aides later explained that he was not calling for a general above inflation settlement but wanted to reward those taking extra responsibility and pay a "market forces supplement" to staff in regions experiencing particularly high cost of living increases.

 £50m for hospices and palliative care, including more support to help the terminally ill stay at home.

 Maximum wait of one month from diagnosis to treatment for all cancers by 2005 and for breast cancer by 2001.

 Smoking among manual groups to be cut from 32% in 1998 to 26% by 2010.

 Campaign to increase fruit and vegetable consumption.

 Better information for patients about the risks as well as benefits of cancer screening programmes.

 Improvements to cervical screening, breast screening extended to age 70 (and over 70 on request)

 Testing for prostate cancer available in the spring, trials for colorectal and ovarian screening underway

 New National Cancer Research Institute to focus efforts where progress most likely

webTitle: One in 10 web dates ends in bed

fields.headline: One in 10 web dates ends in bed
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: One in 10 women using the internet have made love to a man they first met online at work, according to a survey.
fields.body:
One in 10 women using the internet have made love to a man they first met online at work, according to a survey.

Nearly 25% of the 2,000 secretaries, executives and students asked on the website newwomanonline.co.uk had formed a "romantic friendship" over the web.

The women, average age 27, would typically devote 102 minutes a day chatting online to their love mates at work.

Most of them eventually met, with Londoners being most likely to have sex with their web lovers.

Some met strangers in chatrooms, others would eye colleagues at work and strike up relationships by email. The website creators posted the survey, for workers aged 18-40, online. They believed young workers, whose private lives had been squeezed out by longer hours in the office, had been forced to seek romance at their terminal.

A spokeswoman for Newwomanonline, Carmel Hayes, said the explosion in internet romance "took the fear of rejection out of meeting people".
Press Association

fields.headline: Combative Prescott cheers party faithful
fields.standfirst: Full text of John Prescott's speech
fields.trailText: John Prescott roused the Labour conference this afternoon telling delegates the party would "take the Tories to the cleaners" at the next election.
fields.body:
John Prescott roused the Labour conference this afternoon telling delegates the party would "take the Tories to the cleaners" at the next election.

The deputy prime minister praised Tony Blair as a "top-ranking" leader respected throughout the world.

He joked about the prime minister's speech to the conference, saying: "It will take sacrifice, effort: yes, blood; yes, tears - and perhaps we won't mention the sweat, Tony"

To laughter from party delegates, he added: "You should worry - he put his arm around me!"

Mr Prescott continued: "Tony has sent his suit to the cleaners. But at the next election we are going to take Mr Hague to the cleaners and win that election."

Despite the leadership's defeat over pensions yesterday, Mr Prescott said much had been achieved during the week. "We've had the odd disagreement this week, but don't lose sight of the huge range of policies we have agreed on this week for people in this country," he said. Laying into the Tories during his knockabout speech, he said: "I call them the Burger Kings of British politics - every minute another whopper."
