fields.headline: Love on the net
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about finding love on the net, and keeping it in the real world
fields.trailText: 1. One in 10 women who use the internet has had sex with a man she first met online at work, according to a new survey. Nearly a quarter of the 2,000 secretaries, executives and students questioned on the New Woman website had formed a "romantic friendship" over the web.
fields.body:
1. One in 10 women who use the internet has had sex with a man she first met online at work, according to a new survey. Nearly a quarter of the 2,000 secretaries, executives and students questioned on the New Woman website had formed a "romantic friendship" over the web.

2. But there were wide regional variations, with Londoners proving the most adventurous when it came to sex. A quarter of women in the capital have formed a romantic friendship online; of those 73% met their web paramours, with 75% of these becoming "proper relationships".

3. The women surveyed, with an average age of 27, would typically devote 102 minutes a day chatting online with their love mates at work, an amount of time which may have bosses wondering about how to stamp out such abuse. Yorkshire women are more conscientious about using the web at work: they are least likely to use online access at work for play or personal use and 53% of them think it might be a sackable offence.

4. Along with email and chat rooms, internet love's traditional heart are the online dating services that have mushroomed over recent years. Practically all tastes and prejudices are catered for, from vegans to Christians dating.

5. Many of those who use such services have come away with stories which prompt second thoughts while other tales may make you hanker for the days of the ZX Spectrum.

6. As ever, where there is love, marriage lurks close by. Many users, mostly men, scour the web for possible matrimonial prospects. But, contrary to popular belief, not all spouse hunters are desperate middle-aged western men.

7. For some communities the web has created a modern medium for traditional matchmaking. Indian marriage sites offer the widespread South Asian diaspora the opportunity to find love across the world rather than just relying on mother's second cousin's best friend's son. And of course the Jewish community, with similar traditions, also have their own sites.

8. The blossoming of internet love has been followed by a proliferation of - what else - internet agony aunts. Teen pop queen Britney Spears was recently taken on by BBC Online to provide a wise word to adolescent worriers.

9. While the respondents in the New Woman survey were still interested in pursuing romance in the real world, internet users have eschewed flesh and blood for the new pleasures of cybersex, which allows participants to forgo the messiness of bodily fluids for the purity of electrons.

10. Adding yet another dimension to the great game of love, just as picking up in bars can lead to a drink problem, online dating can lead to internet addiction. If you fear you may be suffering from this malaise, there are, of course, online resources to help you through it.

fields.headline: Stretching their wings
fields.standfirst: With encouragement pre-teens can tackle a range of styles and some difficult subject matter in their reading, says Lindsey Fraser
fields.trailText: With encouragement pre-teens can tackle a range of styles and difficult subject matter
fields.body:
A quick overview of the books voted their favourites by children as part of this year's Blue Peter Book Awards reveals articulate and thoughtful enthusiasm for a vast range of titles. Yes, Harry Potter appears, but he is less dominant than one might imagine,which indicates that young readers develop eclectic tastes, given choice and encouragement.

Marcia Williams' popular cartoon retellings of Shakespeare plays verge on the irreverent, evoking the hectic mood of the crowded Globe Theatre. She brings the same humour to Fabulous Monsters (Walker Books, £4.99), unveiling such fearsome creatures as The Bunyip, Grendel and the strangely appealing, very smelly Isikukumanderu.
Buy it at BOL

True to life?

Polly's Running Away Book (Bloomsbury, £9.99) recreates the world of your average, truculent, broccoli-hating pre-teen. Frances Thomas' diary-style comedy skips along, incorporating scrap-book style illustrations by Sally Gardner. Polly's preoccupations and inventive spelling will be touchingly familiar, but the book steers clear of sentimentality, taking everything seriously but retaining a sense of proportion.
Buy it at BOL

There is also visual interest in I, Jack (Yearling, £3.99) a daft but inoffensive examination of family life from the point of view of a dog. Patricia Finney has had great fun with the story, and especially with Jack's undisciplined passion for next door's pedigree chump.
Buy it at BOL

Pat Moon is an excellent writer. In Do Not Read This Book (Orchard Books, £3.99) she tells the complicated story of Finch Penny. There is great comedy in this lightly illustrated diary, but also revelations which shake Finch to the core. Her beloved Nolly takes seriously ill; friendships are threatened; her unhappiness at her mother's relationship proves all too justified. Not as unrelentingly jolly as it looks, but a terrific read nevertheless.
Buy it at BOL

Philip Ardagh's Awful End (Faber, £4.99) is one great joke-soaked romp. It's as if, freed from the strictures of his more familiar non-fiction territory, he has been allowed to let off steam, most of it hitting the page in the form of puns, word play and general hilarity. Eccentric, anarchic and engagingly written, this is a guaranteed winner with the sniggering classes.
Buy it at BOL

Thought-provoking and utterly fascinating, The Genius Of Leonardo (Barefoot Books, £9.99) is also a stunningly beautiful book. Giacomo, da Vinci's young assistant, tells of his time with the artist, subtly drawing attention to the extent to which he was so startlingly ahead of his time. Given the level of technological advance with which children are now comfortable, reminders of the limitations of the fifteenth century are vital. But above all, we are introduced to the artist as a man - vulnerable, passionate and brilliant.
Buy it at BOL

Extraordinary families

Thomas Bloor's The Memory Prisoner (Hodder, £3.99) is a first novel, the winner of The Fidler Award. The distinctive jacket encloses a distinctive book, the story of the vast Maddie who hasn't left her house in thirteen years. 'I can't forget. So I can't leave the house,' she tells the doctor, but when asked what it is that she can't forget, she says that she can't remember. Only when her brother is in mortal danger is she forced to face her terrors, and to act. Bizarre, original, rewarding.
Buy it at BOL

The headline-grabbing story of a sperm whale that took a wrong turning was the starting point for Lynne Markham's Deep Trouble (Mammoth, £4.99). The whale in her story becomes an object of fascination for Jimmy, whose Dad has suffered a stroke. This is a touching but robust novel about family life under terrific pressure.
Buy it at BOL

One of the most delightful 'finds' of this year's Edinburgh International Book Festival was a charming German polymath - Hans Magnus Enzensburger. A talk about the million copy-selling The Number Devil (Granta, £12 - Buy it at BOL) in which he shares his delight in maths through a story he wrote for his daughter, led to the discovery of Where Were You, Robert? (Hamish Hamilton, £14.99).
Buy it at BOL

Oldies but goodies

Tom's Midnight Garden, A Dog So Small, Minnow On The Say - Philippa Pearce's novels have marked the literary histories of thousands of readers. Her new collection, The Rope And Other Stories (Puffin, £4.99) is as elegant and poised as ever, every word carefully placed, each story paced to perfection.
Buy it at BOL

Don't overlook books from another era. Harper Collins and Oxford University Press have brought the wonderful Diana Wynne Jones back into print, and Egmont has revisited such stalwarts as Dodie Smith's 101 Dalmatians and the Laura Ingalls Wilder Little House On The Prairie novels. OUP has reissued Beverley Cleary's entertaining Ramona stories along with a brand new adventure, Ramona's World (£3.99).

And finally Leon Garfield's Jack Holborn (Oxford Children's Modern Classics, £6.99), as vital today as it was in 1964. Don't believe those who insist that young people won't read historical novels. They will if they're this good.
Buy it at BOL

Audio books by Valerie Bierman

Go for the unabridged ones if possible, they're more expensive but worth it. Stephen Fry's brilliant reading of Harry Potter And The Chamber Of Secrets (Cover to Cover) gives nine hours listening - it's £21.99 and worth every penny.
Buy it at BOL

"This is the story of what happened when we sailed away from Whitegates that Friday night. Some people will tell you that none of these things happened. They say it was just a dream that the three of us shared. Everything is true. So listen..." That's the beginning of Heaven Eyes by David Almond (Hodder £7.99), a writer whose imaginative, powerful and haunting stories have enriched readers these last three years. Heaven Eyes, the strange, web-fingered child whom January, Mouse and Erin meet on the mud of the river, lives in a world of shadows and mystery, in the rotting riverside warehouse. Is this the real world or the imaginary dreams of disturbed children? Listen for yourself. Imogen Stubbs reads this brilliant story for older children and adults. Slightly abridged, three hours listening time.

Kevin Crossley-Holland's entrancing tale, The Seeing Stone (Orion £8.99) provides a new twist to the Arthurian legends. Merlin gives young Arthur de Caldicot, a would-be knight, a shining stone "made of fire and ice..." Looking into its shining depth, he sees another Arthur whose story enfolds in the stone. A brilliantly crafted story about growing up, weaving in the legends of King Arthur; but, most of all, it's a rattling good tale read by Samuel West. Almost 4 hours listening time, The Seeing Stone is also in book form (Orion £9.99).
Buy it at BOL

 Lindsey Fraser is executive director, Scottish Book Trust

But above all, we are introduced to the artist as a man - vulnerable, passionate and brilliant. Buy it at BOL Extraordinary families Thomas Bloor's The Memory Prisoner (Hodder, £3.99) is a first novel, the winner of The Fidler Award. The distinctive jacket encloses a distinctive book, the story of the vast Maddie who hasn't left her house in thirteen years. 'I can't forget. So I can't leave the house,' she tells the doctor, but when asked what it is that she can't forget, she says that she can't remember. Only when her brother is in mortal danger is she forced to face her terrors, and to act. Bizarre, original, rewarding. Buy it at BOL The headline-grabbing story of a sperm whale that took a wrong turning was the starting point for Lynne Markham's Deep Trouble (Mammoth, £4.99). The whale in her story becomes an object of fascination for Jimmy, whose Dad has suffered a stroke. This is a touching but robust novel about family life under terrific pressure. Buy it at BOL One of the most delightful 'finds' of this year's Edinburgh International Book Festival was a charming German polymath - Hans Magnus Enzensburger. A talk about the million copy-selling The Number Devil (Granta, £12 - Buy it at BOL) in which he shares his delight in maths through a story he wrote for his daughter, led to the discovery of Where Were You, Robert? (Hamish Hamilton, £14.99). Buy it at BOL Oldies but goodies Tom's Midnight Garden, A Dog So Small, Minnow On The Say - Philippa Pearce's novels have marked the literary histories of thousands of readers. Her new collection, The Rope And Other Stories (Puffin, £4.99) is as elegant and poised as ever, every word carefully placed, each story paced to perfection. Buy it at BOL Don't overlook books from another era. Harper Collins and Oxford University Press have brought the wonderful Diana Wynne Jones back into print, and Egmont has revisited such stalwarts as Dodie Smith's 101 Dalmatians and the Laura Ingalls Wilder Little House On The Prairie novels. OUP has reissued Beverley Cleary's entertaining Ramona stories along with a brand new adventure, Ramona's World (£3.99). And finally Leon Garfield's Jack Holborn (Oxford Children's Modern Classics, £6.99), as vital today as it was in 1964. Don't believe those who insist that young people won't read historical novels. They will if they're this good. Buy it at BOL Audio books by Valerie Bierman Go for the unabridged ones if possible, they're more expensive but worth it. Stephen Fry's brilliant reading of Harry Potter And The Chamber Of Secrets (Cover to Cover) gives nine hours listening - it's £21.99 and worth every penny. Buy it at BOL "This is the story of what happened when we sailed away from Whitegates that Friday night. Some people will tell you that none of these things happened. They say it was just a dream that the three of us shared. Everything is true. So listen..." That's the beginning of Heaven Eyes by David Almond (Hodder £7.99), a writer whose imaginative, powerful and haunting stories have enriched readers these last three years. Heaven Eyes, the strange, web-fingered child whom January, Mouse and Erin meet on the mud of the river, lives in a world of shadows and mystery, in the rotting riverside warehouse. Is this the real world or the imaginary dreams of disturbed children? Listen for yourself. Imogen Stubbs reads this brilliant story for older children and adults. Slightly abridged, three hours listening time. Kevin Crossley-Holland's entrancing tale, The Seeing Stone (Orion £8.99) provides a new twist to the Arthurian legends. Merlin gives young Arthur de Caldicot, a would-be knight, a shining stone "made of fire and ice..." Looking into its shining depth, he sees another Arthur whose story enfolds in the stone. Almost 4 hours listening time, The Seeing Stone is also in book form (Orion £9.99). Buy it at BOL  Lindsey Fraser is executive director, Scottish Book Trust

fields.headline: Plenty to see and do
fields.standfirst: Non-fiction books for this age group appeal to all tastes, finds Jan Clements, with lots of models to make as well as a bit of horrible history and science to keep you amused
fields.trailText: Non-fiction books for this age group appeal to all tastes
fields.body:
When is a book not a book? When it's a flat-packed model just waiting to leap off the page with the help of busy hands. Rumour has it that we're not producing enough engineers, but the current choice of new publications includes enough 'don't just sit there' titles to help remedy the situation!

Crafty activity

I itched to press out the glossy coloured shapes and make up the 3-D Egyptian tomb complete with moving corpses in Mummies, and the UFO model which abducts a human at the turn of a handle in Aliens, both by Keith Newstead (Hodder, £5.99). Some young friends did complete the models and they were ace! Modestly priced for such distinctive quality, including six pages of background information and cartoons.
Buy another in the range at BOL

More 'crafty' activity in Steve and Megumi Biddle's Underwater Origami (Red Fox, £4.99), complete with tear-out sheets of coloured paper to fold when assembling the 18 aquatic models. This husband and wife team are a popular act on the book festival circuit, so don't miss their lively show if you get the chance.
Buy it at BOL

Book making

It's interesting to contrast two new titles on book-making, both successful in their differing approach to 'learning through doing'. Make A Book by Vivien Frank and Deborah Jaffe (Frances Lincoln, £7.99) has pull-out templates for six exquisite books, all reproduced from the British Library collection. This stylish and sophisticated package serves as a brief evolution of books via a Thai folding book, Japanese scroll, medieval Book of Hours, eighteenth century movable Cinderella book, flicker book and an historical newspaper.
Buy it at BOL

Making Books by Paul Johnson (Black, £10.99) is a cross-curricular resource guide for adults. There are 30 projects outlining how five-to-11 year-olds can handcraft, illustrate and write their own novelty shaped or themed books. Johnson draws on his years of practical expertise and is thoroughly convincing about the contribution of book-making activity to children's development.
Buy it at BOL

More about Harry Potter

The phenomenal success of Harry Potter will have youngsters clamouring for An Interview With JK Rowling by Lindsey Fraser (Mammoth, £2.99). It belongs to the Telling Tales series which focuses on significant names from children's publishing and includes Anne Fine, Jacqueline Wilson, Michael Morpurgo and Enid Blyton. These slim books adopt a conversational tone so are not too ponderous, and they dig a little behind the celebrity faça;ade to explore family life, early influences and what makes the authors tick. JK shares a few of her innermost secrets (read it to find out!) and there's also a useful summary of the books, so it's good value both for fans and 'author projects'.
Buy it at BOL

Teenage smoking is on the increase despite government deterrents and we get a timely reminder of the pros and cons in A Right To Smoke? by Emma Haughton (Watts Viewpoints, £5.99). It presents a balanced overview of this emotive issue backed up by a host of well-chosen quotes and photos from a range of sources, plus glossary, useful addresses and facts. There is plenty in here to stimulate discussion among young people and encourage them to form their own opinion.
Buy it at BOL

Echo bravo tango

Ever wondered how planes get off the ground and what super force keeps them up there above the clouds? Duffers like me think it's pure magic, but Ian Graham does a good job in dispelling the mystique and explaining the wonders of modern technology in How To Fly A 747 (Walker, £5.99). He addresses you, the Captain, in a direct, lively style and talks you through the excitement of taking off, keeping aloft, steering and navigating, dealing with turbulence and landing. OK, you won't be quite ready to take over the controls after reading this, but you'll be far more clued up over what's going on during your air journeys. And you also get a laminated poster of the plane and its cockpit, a booklet about aircrew and (guess what!) a cut-out model to make up yourself.

History, horrible or otherwise

The desire to build empires and dominate others is a recurring human theme and Peter Chrisp tells the tale of one of history's most successful achievers in Alexander The Great: The Legend Of A Warrior King (Dorling Kindersley, £9.99). Setting Alexander's life within the framework of Greek politics, it also gives interesting glimpses of social life at home and in the lands he conquered. The DK format still has the power to excite with its outstanding visual content and densely packed captions, with the necessary index to access specific information about his ruthless leader and his plundering exploits.
Buy it at BOL

Scholastic's Horrible Histories and Horrible Science series remind me of old time music halls. Both tap into the audience's fascination with the fatuous, outrageous and irrelevant in a most engaging way and both have built up an enthusiastic following. The 'Horribles' are deservedly popular because of their light-hearted approach, packing in masses of information in the guise of jokes and puns, helped along admirably by riotous cartoons.

Among the latest crop of new titles, look out for Ireland (£7.99 - Buy it at BOL) and Horrible Christmas (£5.99) from Terry Deary and Deadly Diseases (£3.99 - Buy it at BOL) and The Awfully Big Quiz Book (Horrible Science, £5.99) from Nick Arnold.

Meet an author

To meet some real live authors try to get along to Durham on Saturday November 18 for the Gala Day of the Northern Children's Book Festival It's a great free family day out. For a programme, contact Anne Key on 0191-477 3478

fields.headline: New books for old
fields.standfirst: It takes a brave illustrator to tackle our best-loved classics, particularly when the drawings are as well known to us as the words. Joanna Carey finds a few who succeed in bringing new life to old favourites
fields.trailText: It takes a brave illustrator to tackle our best-loved classics
fields.body:
Ever since Alice's Adventures In Wonderland was first published in 1866, Tenniel's original illustrations have been indelibly etched on the public mind (Macmillan, £12.99). But, as with all classics, each generation needs a contemporary reinterpretation, and over the years Alice has become an irresistible challenge to illustrators. The list of artists who've taken up the challenge includes Arthur Rackham, Mabel Lucie Attwell, Marie Laurencin, Ralph Steadman, Salvador Dali, Anthony Browne and Tony Ross.
Buy it at BOL

There are frequent developments in the Alice industry at all levels. While Mervyn Peake's darkly atmospheric illustrations are currently being restored to their original glory for a new Bloomsbury edition next year, Macmillan, Alice's original publishers, have brought out a Alice's Pop-Up Wonderland (Macmillan, £14.99) - a novelty book with a 3D board game, cut out figures and a brief resumé of the story.
Buy it at BOL

The very latest illustrators of Alice are Helen Oxenbury (her version won this year's Kate Greenaway medal) and Lisbeth Zwerger. To re-illustrate Alice, an artist needs a strong sense of purpose - Helen Oxenbury's aim is 'to make it accessible to today's children' and this she achieves brilliantly (Walker, £14.99). Childhood today tends to be telescoped to make way for an early adolescence - and Carroll's classic is increasingly perceived as a book for young children.

While Tenniel's Alice has a somewhat grave demeanour accentuated by the formality of her clothing, Oxenbury shifts the whole focus of the story giving us a much younger Alice, bare-legged in plimsolls, wearing a liberatingly skimpy denim shift (from GAP, probably) that allows her a much more physical involvement with her adventures. This is a perfect book for adult and child to share; there's a picture at almost every opening and children who might have difficulty with Alice's prodigious conversational abilities will have no trouble in reading her body language. She's very much a child of today, with a touchy-feely informality that's reflected in the tactile quality of the soft pencil lines and the comfortable tones of the watercolours.
Buy it at BOL

Lisbeth Zwerger's Alice, a little older, is quite different (in an edition with The Wizard Of Oz, North/South, £27.99). With her thoughtful introspective gaze, it's clear that this child is psychologically well equipped to deal with the spiralling illogicalities of the plot. Zwerger combines a delicate watercolour technique with a robust and unusual sense of composition: cropping the images with great bravado to reflect the topsy-turvy dislocations of the story; and making eloquent use of white space.

Illustrators of the classics are inevitably influenced by the characters visualised by the original artist. Most of us could recognise Ratty, Mole and Mr Toad, but artist John Burningham took advantage the fact that he grew up without knowingThe Wind In The Willows, and approached it (in 1983) with an open mind, working from a copy with the E H Shepard illustrations removed. It's out of print now, but it's curious how the wistful simplicity of his distinctive style somehow heightens the experience of reading the book. Inga Moore with an abridged text - and much larger format - addresses a younger audience: bursting with engrossing period detail and affectionate characterisation, she makes theatrical use of scale and perspective to explore in depth the warmly lit interiors and the lush, intricate textures of the English countryside (Walker, £14.99).
Buy it at BOL

The Sussex Downs are the setting for Eleanor Farjeon's 1937 fairy tale Elsie Piddock Skips In Her Sleep which Charlotte Voake has turned into a magical picture book. Voake's mercurial calligraphic pen and wash drawings have all the airy vitality of the storytelling (Walker, £10.99).
Buy it at BOL

Older classic fairy tales are repeatedly subjected to re-interpretation. Contemporary illustrators of the brothers Grimm include David Hockney, Cindy Sherman, Michael Foreman, Maurice Sendak... Political correctness has taken its toll on the traditional image of the witch, though there are one or two knobbly old crones to be found in Walker Books' handsome new collection of Fairy Tales told by Berlie Doherty (Walker, £14.99) and illustrated by Jane Ray, whose dazzlingly decorative gilded illustrations are embellished with intricate silhouettes in the style of Arthur Rackham.
Buy it at BOL

Quentin Blake has illustrated many classics, but it's as Children's Laureate that he has put together The Laureate's Party(Red Fox, £3.99), an anthology of excerpts.
Buy it at BOL

One of his favourites is the 1991 Snow White (Red Fox, £3.99) by Josephine Poole, illustrated by Angela Barrett: 'When you look at this version you feel that this is the original Snow White. It has the confidence, both in words and pictures, to behave as though no other version has ever existed.'
Buy it at BOL

 Joanna Carey is a writer and illustrator.

fields.headline: How sweet to be a cloud
fields.standfirst: From pop-up globes and lots of weather to Shakespeare, cats and cars, here's the pick of the latest non-fiction
fields.trailText: From pop-up globes and lots of weather to Shakespeare, cats and cars
fields.body:
The Wonderful World Book by Kate Petty and Jennie Maizels (Bodley Head, £14.99) presents a magnificent feat of paper engineering. There are flaps, pop-ups and wheels galore to get every page moving in all directions as young fingers explore the universe and Planet Earth in all its variations. It's a great, intriguing game and an aid to learning! But be warned - fumbling oldies like me can't get the inflating pop-up globe flat again, so once released, it trails along tantalisingly on its elastic thread!
Buy it at BOL

Let's talk about the weather

Talking of globes, Ted Dewan's fantastic creatures The Weatherbirds (Puffin, £5.99) travel from Toronto to Costa Rica in an amazing airship, experiencing the extremes of weather and climate en route. OK, the storyline is a little contrived, but it provides a fun vehicle for the scientific information and experiments. An index helps you access the facts, and the stunning illustrations are of Ted's usual high standard.
Buy it at BOL

The Let's Explore Elements series by Henry Pluckrose (Watts, £9.99) displays the sure touch you expect of such an experienced writer of information books for young children. Earth and Water worked equally well for me, offering a wide cross-section of stimulating statements on each topic. Not only do you get a very short, simple but effective text with no 'writing down' (a point made in the author's guidance notes for the adults who will share the book); you also get some stunning photos of exhibition standard - typified by the lions drinking life-giving water.
Buy associated titles by Henry Pluckrose at BOL

Children's rights

For Every Child (Hutchinson in association with UNICEF, £10.99) comes with impeccable credentials. It highlights 14 of the UN Convention's Rights of the Child, each interpreted in child-friendly language and in very different visual styles by a range of distinguished and prize-winning illustrators, including PJ Lynch, Jerry Pinkney, Rachel Isadora and Satoshi Kitamura. The full text of these UN Rights appears at the end. This deserves to be a treasured gift book for the stylish beauty of its production as well as its content.

Younger readers

Cars, Cars, Cars by Kathy Henderson (Frances Lincoln, £4.99) gives a whistle-stop tour of motor travel, from the car factory to traffic jams. It's presented as a rhyming picture story with vividly illustrated scenes by Charlotte Hard tumbling over each page. The in-your-face style carries you breathlessly along at a hectic pace, reflecting the speed of the subject.
Buy it at BOL

Another one for tinies is Hannah Roche's Have You Ever Heard A Cat Purr? (Zero to Ten, £7.99). It's one of a spiral-bound series with laminated pages about animal life cycles which gets the point over with a few well-chosen words and bold, warm pictures by Pierre Pratt. The end of the book is a new beginning - turn on!
Buy it at BOL

Two favourites by Kate Petty now issued in paperback are Sam Plants A Sunflower and Rosie Plants A Radish (Macmillan, £3.99). They are a charming combination of simple storyline, attractive pictures by Axel Scheffer and the much-loved lift-the-flap element. The gardening checklist at the end summarises the steps to successful crops!
Buy Rosie Plants a Radish at BOL

Another welcome paperback edition is The Emperor's Egg, an outstanding natural history book by Martin Jenkins with enchanting illustrations from Jane Chapman (Walker, £4.99).
Buy it at BOL

Some more maths

The advent of the National Numeracy Hour has focused us on maths in a big way and some new titles have been published to develop and reinforce number skills. The Usborne Sticker Maths series (Usborne, £2.99 each) by Fiona Watt and Rachel Wells links in closely to the national curriculum for early years and offers modestly priced personal workbooks. Children are encouraged to fill in numbers and to use the pages of stickers on the colourful puzzles and activities. The bright and cheerful contents and the Ôplay' hook should appeal to children and parents alike.

Shapes are woven cleverly into the African story A Triangle For Adaora by Ifeoma Onyefulu (Frances Lincoln, £10.99). It follows the established format of this classy series - splendid coloured photos of family life which highlight African traditions, food and social life while pursuing the maths theme.
Buy it at BOL

A lot of poems about science

The title and psychedelic cover by Harry Horse cannot fail to attract youngsters to Centrally Heated Knickers (Puffin, £4.99) - they are in for a real treat when they delve inside this poetry book! Michael Rosen has surpassed himself with these 100 poems on the theme of science, technology and the environment. Kids will chortle at his anarchic view of things while teachers, parents and librarians will love it for brightening up the national curriculum!
Buy it at BOL

And finally, Shakespeare

I was particularly impressed by Aliki's William Shakespeare And The Globe (Mammoth, £5.99) which vividly captures in few words and many exquisite illustrations the Bard's life and times in Stratford and London. Presented in five Acts, it flows along seamlessly and provides a splendid introduction. This is a truly elegant and outstanding production, thanks to Aliki's distinctive talent.
Buy it at BOL

 Jan Clements is children's library manager for North Tyneside

The full text of these UN Rights appears at the end. This deserves to be a treasured gift book for the stylish beauty of its production as well as its content. Younger readers Cars, Cars, Cars by Kathy Henderson (Frances Lincoln, £4.99) gives a whistle-stop tour of motor travel, from the car factory to traffic jams. It's presented as a rhyming picture story with vividly illustrated scenes by Charlotte Hard tumbling over each page. The in-your-face style carries you breathlessly along at a hectic pace, reflecting the speed of the subject. Buy it at BOL Another one for tinies is Hannah Roche's Have You Ever Heard A Cat Purr? (Zero to Ten, £7.99). It's one of a spiral-bound series with laminated pages about animal life cycles which gets the point over with a few well-chosen words and bold, warm pictures by Pierre Pratt. The end of the book is a new beginning - turn on! Buy it at BOL Two favourites by Kate Petty now issued in paperback are Sam Plants A Sunflower and Rosie Plants A Radish (Macmillan, £3.99). They are a charming combination of simple storyline, attractive pictures by Axel Scheffer and the much-loved lift-the-flap element. The gardening checklist at the end summarises the steps to successful crops! Buy Rosie Plants a Radish at BOL Another welcome paperback edition is The Emperor's Egg, an outstanding natural history book by Martin Jenkins with enchanting illustrations from Jane Chapman (Walker, £4.99). Buy it at BOL Some more maths The advent of the National Numeracy Hour has focused us on maths in a big way and some new titles have been published to develop and reinforce number skills. The Usborne Sticker Maths series (Usborne, £2.99 each) by Fiona Watt and Rachel Wells links in closely to the national curriculum for early years and offers modestly priced personal workbooks. Children are encouraged to fill in numbers and to use the pages of stickers on the colourful puzzles and activities. The bright and cheerful contents and the Ôplay' hook should appeal to children and parents alike. Shapes are woven cleverly into the African story A Triangle For Adaora by Ifeoma Onyefulu (Frances Lincoln, £10.99). It follows the established format of this classy series - splendid coloured photos of family life which highlight African traditions, food and social life while pursuing the maths theme. Buy it at BOL A lot of poems about science The title and psychedelic cover by Harry Horse cannot fail to attract youngsters to Centrally Heated Knickers (Puffin, £4.99) - they are in for a real treat when they delve inside this poetry book! Michael Rosen has surpassed himself with these 100 poems on the theme of science, technology and the environment. Kids will chortle at his anarchic view of things while teachers, parents and librarians will love it for brightening up the national curriculum! Buy it at BOL And finally, Shakespeare I was particularly impressed by Aliki's William Shakespeare And The Globe (Mammoth, £5.99) which vividly captures in few words and many exquisite illustrations the Bard's life and times in Stratford and London. Presented in five Acts, it flows along seamlessly and provides a splendid introduction. This is a truly elegant and outstanding production, thanks to Aliki's distinctive talent. Buy it at BOL  Jan Clements is children's library manager for North Tyneside

fields.headline: Good guys, bad guys
fields.standfirst: Early readers can deal with some difficult subjects more easily if the heroes of their tales are animals, finds Vivian French
fields.trailText: Early readers can deal with difficult subjects more easily if the heroes of their tales are animals
fields.body:
My small dark youngest daughter hated books about blonde, blue-eyed children. 'They don't look like me,' she'd wail. There was, however, instant identification with the lost rabbit or the grumpy mole. Human details can sometimes get in the way of the truth of a story - or make the story too painfully real for an under-5 to cope with.

Dealing with parents

In Good Day, Bad Day by Kathryn White (Oxford, £4.99) the subject matter is warring parents. To a young child parents are all powerful and their anger is too immediate to consider in any sort of rational manner. Looking at mother and father badger fighting provides an opportunity for thinking and talking about how little badger is feeling. It's a brave book with a powerful message; adults can learn from this too.
Buy it at BOL

Just Like You (written and illustrated by Jan Fearnley, Mammoth, £4.99) is a tender celebration of the love between parent and child, and it's an indication of Fearnley's sure and subtle touch that the delicately balanced text never goes over the top into schmaltz. Little Mouse watches the other animals putting their babies to bed and promising to care for them, and he isn't sure that Mama Mouse can offer as much. 'You're only a little mouse', he says. What happens? Read it, and find out. It's a fabulous bedtime book; allow time for poring over the fascinating detail in the pictures.
Buy it at BOL

Not just love

Too much love? Rush out and get Big Bad Bunny by Alan Durant. (Orchard, £9.99). Guy Parker-Rees' big bold pictures had all my testers whooping with laughter and wanting to hear the bouncy text over and over again. Big Bad Bunny is the best bad guy ever; he's looking for money - and he means to get it! Luckily Wise Old Bunny knows just what to do when BBB reaches the bank ... and there's a transformation. No - not what you'd expect at all.
Buy other titles by Alan Durant at BOL

The Show At Rickety Barn (David and Charles, £9.99) is a glorious romp. Lynne Chapman's exuberantly wacky pictures are a perfect partner for Jemma Beake's wickedly tongue-in-cheek story. Every adult knows an Austin the old cart horse who has 'a short poem that I have written specially', and every child knows a Sniggle the pig who doesn't want to be left out.
Buy it at BOL

Do you ever let the toast burn because you've pottered off to read the paper? This Won't Take Long (Zero to Ten, £6.99) is for you ... and for your three year old who leaves her picture half finished because she's wandered off to play with a truck. Austin McQuinn is an acute and accurate observer of how one thing leads to another, with a subtle sense of humour in both word and illustration.

Fun and friendship

'Imagine a town, in a country, where a simple thing like an Elephant had never been seen, or even heard of ...' OK, there are people in The Obvious Elephant, (Bloomsbury, £9.99) but it's the friendship between Eric and the elephant that matters. Sophie Windham's warm and witty illustrations set Bruce Robinson's tall story into the time of myth and magic; it's a gorgeous read-aloud story with a nice twist.
Buy it at BOL

Mrs Mopple's Washing Line (Written by Anita Hewitt, illustrated by Robert Bloomfield; Red Fox, £4.99) was first published in 1966. The animals are real animals and not cyphers for children, but it's such a stunner to read out loud I couldn't leave it out. No child can resist joining in with 'Blow wind, blow,' or the accumulating list that starts with 'a pig in a petticoat.'
Buy it at BOL

Animal heroes

It's back to the animal stars with Who Needs Pockets? (Adrienne Geoghegan, Little Hippo, £3.99). Buddy is a blue dog who collects things. The trouble is he doesn't have a pocket, so off he goes to find one - and meets a duck, a cat, a tortoise, a pig and a rabbit along the way. Being a generous sort of dog Buddy helps them out - and finds he's inadvertently solved his problem. It's a clever story with real character.
Buy other titles by Adrienne Geoghegan at BOL

There's another take on friendship in Mouse And Elephant (Hodder, £4.99). An Vrombaut's Mouse and Elephant want to play together, but the size discrepancy is a problem. They try all kinds of games but nothing quite works; elephant's expression when he tries parachute jumping left my testers helpless with the giggles. Great for even the very youngest picture-book reader.
Buy it at BOL

Rhymes to say out loud

Fox's Socks (Campbell Books, £3.99) is a board book, but my ancient six-year-old tester wouldn't put it down. Julia Donaldson's rhyming couplets are horribly catchy and Axel Scheffler's Fox and Mouse are a hoot. We all wanted to peep under the flaps; and an early reader read it with gusto.
Buy it at BOL

If you fancy reciting rhyming couplets out loud and maybe impressing your children beyond all belief Three Tapping Teddies (A and C Black, £9.99) could be the investment of a lifetime. It's stuffed full of rhymes, chants and stories by the fantastic Kaye Umansky. It talks about activities for a class group but works brilliantly at home, with useful tips for telling the stories, and putting the songs to well known tunes: you could end up being the most popular parent in town.
Buy it at BOL

And finally, Get Into Bed! (Virginia Miller, Walker, £3.99) Every toddler and small child knows that the small bear Bartholomew is his or her alter ego, and every Dad recognises himself in George. It's an old tried and tested favourite, and all the better for that - a wonderful book for every family that has a child of any age who just WON'T go to bed. Buy it at BOL

Five great presents for 2 - 4s

How The Whale Became and other stories
Written by Ted Hughes, illustrated by Jackie Morris
(Faber, £17.99)
"Now God had a little back garden. In this garden he grew carrots, onions, beans and whatever else he needed for his dinner."
Buy it at BOL

Time for a Rhyme
Chosen by Fiona Waters, illustrated by Ailie Busby
(Orion, £20.00)
"My age is three hundred and seventy-two, And I think, with the deepest regret, How I used to pick up and voraciously chew The dear little boys whom I met..."
Buy it at BOL

Rover
Written by Michael Rosen, illustrated by Neal Layton
(Bloomsbury, £4.99)
"This is my pet human... I named her Rover."
Buy it at BOL

The Time it Took Tom
By Nick Sharratt and Stephen Tucker
(Hippo, £5.99)
"Tom found the red paint. It took him three seconds to decide what to do with it."
Buy it at BOL

Tiger-Time for Stanley
Written/illustrated by Griff
(Tick-tock, £9.99 including CD)
"If Stanley were an animal, he would be a shrimp ... or a shark ... or an ant ... or a tiger!"

fields.headline: Good enough to eat
fields.standfirst: It's never too early to introduce books, says Vivian French. Even the littlest babies can enjoy the textures and colours of this batch of read-aloud stories
fields.trailText: Even the littlest babies can enjoy the textures and colours of this batch of read-aloud stories
fields.body:
Even the youngest babies need books. Why? Because books are one of the most exciting ways to introduce them to their brand new world. Whenever you can, grab a baby and a book and snuggle up ... you could start a life-long reading habit. Leave books around. Pop one in the buggy. Keep a favourite in the car. Learn nursery rhymes to sing (or mutter) at three in the morning. Prop a book up beside your baby as you spoon in the mashed banana, or when you change a nappy. Don't worry too much about the 'educational' content - time enough for that when your baby has learnt that books are FUN. And don't worry about smears and torn pages. There are some fabulous books that are a pleasure to read and tough enough to survive any amount of love, biscuit and dribble.

Books to squeeze

Noisy Nap (words by Harry Alexander, David and Charles, £4.99) can be left safely beside even the newest baby. It's a padded cloth book that rustles nicely when touched, kicked or rolled on. Your teeny one won't appreciate Rabbit's problems with crackling leaves, but she'll love Luana Rinaldo's bright colours and simple outline pictures.
Buy it at BOL

The Humpty Dumpty Play Book (Illustrated by Jo Brown, Ladybird, £5.99) is another cloth book with no hard corners or sharp edges. You and I may not go wild for Humpty Dumpty in slippery gold knickers, but my testers did - and there's lots for tiny fat fingers to touch and feel as you point out hey diddle diddles and blackbirds in pies in this earliest of introductions to nursery rhyme characters.
Buy it at BOL

Baby on the move

For the buggy try Rocket Bear (Katherine Redfern, Campbell Books, £2.99). It's got a natty blue plastic strap to attach it to the pram, and it's a great read. There are jolly little flaps to open, but it's not the end of the world if they fall off - Rocket Bear can still fly 'Up, up and away' (good repetitive text is ideal for the very young) to stay with the moon mice. The pages are bursting with colour, and it's exactly the right size for small hands to clutch.
Buy other titles by Katherine Redfern at BOL

For the car? What about Jack Rides His Scooter (Kingfisher, £6.99). Rebecca Elgar's Jack may be a cuddly small white dog but every toddler immediately identifies with him and the way that he behaves. My testers adored making him fall off his scooter with a CRASH, and totally sympathised with the need for a plaster. The text is splendidly noisy with Zoom zoom zooms a plenty; there are flaps to open as well as tabs to pull; the pictures are a delight - all good stuff.
Buy other titles by Rebecca Elgar at BOL

Can't tell your concrete crusher from your wheeled excavator? Another car book that delights the mechanically minded (including grown ups) is My First Truck Book (Dorling Kindersley, £4.99). If your one year old is rendered speechless with admiration at a road sweeper get this. The photographs are stunning.
Buy it at BOL

Three in the morning is a tough time. If nursery rhymes and songs are a distant memory refresh your ideas with Hey Diddle Diddle (Little Hippo, £4.99). It's a lovely large-format board book ideal for sharing. Ailie Busby's illustrations are a treat, and her farmyard animals include the best Big Fat Hen you ever saw. Don't forget to make the animal noises when you're feeling stronger.
Buy it at BOL

Animal magic
Try monsters. Not as tough as a board book but still pretty resilient, Mara van der Meer's How Many Monsters (Frances Lincoln, £9.99) is hilarious. There are flaps to peep under (always fun for readers of any age) and lots to giggle at - although sensitive aunts may shudder at monsters picking their noses.
Buy it at BOL

That's Not My Bunny (Usborne, £4.99) is a laminated board book with positively lickable shiny pages. Rachel Wells' rabbit pictures include touchy feely ears or paws or tails, and there are no distracting backgrounds - just zinging pinks and greens and blues. (Aha! Ideal for learning colours!) Babies enjoy question-and-answer texts, and Fiona Watt's simple words are just right - read them out loud even if your baby can only coo and gurgle.
Buy other titles by Fiona Watt at BOL

What babies do

Trucks, colours ... now what about the weather? And the perennial problem of Getting Babies Dressed? You can flip the flaps in Whatever The Weather (Prue Theobalds, Uplands Books, £4.99) to dress two little bears in all kinds of combinations of outfits, but there's more to this book than mixing and matching. You can talk about sun and rain and wind, hot and cold, what you need to wear and why - in fact, you might even persuade your small rebel to put on her coat.
Buy it at BOL

Babies and toddlers are delighted - and reassured - when they recognise their own everyday activities. Caroline Uff's Lulu (Little Orchard, £6.99) goes to the park, swings on the swings ('High, high, up in the sky'), splashes in puddles, and goes home for tea, bath and bed. It's a warm familiar day ideal for discussion; the illustrations glow on the extra strong pages and the small reader is irresistably drawn into Lulu's world. An ideal book for bedtime.
Buy it at BOL

And finally the most enchanting of all baby bedtime books - Husherbye (Jonathan Cape, £9.99). John Burningham's gently lyrical text is full of odd little quirks and idiosyncracies ... and his pictures are as near to magic as it's possible to get. A beautiful, beautiful book.
Buy other titles by John Burningham at BOL

Five great presents for babies

The Very Hungry Caterpillar
Written and illustrated by Eric Carle
(Puffin Books, £8.99 for book AND cuddly caterpillar)
"One Sunday morning the warm sun came up and - pop! - out of the egg came a tiny and very hungry caterpillar."
Buy it at BOL

A Child's Treasury of Nursery Rhymes
Collected and illustrated by Kady MacDonald Denton
(Kingfisher, £14.99)
"Round and round the garden Like a teddy bear..."
Buy it at BOL

Clap Hands
Written/illustrated by Helen Oxenbury
(Walker, £3.50)
"Clap hands, dance and spin, open wide and pop it in."
Buy it at BOL

Mr Bear Says Good-night
Written and illustrated by Debi Gliori
(Little Orchard, £2.99)
"sleep tight little baby till morning does come."
Buy it at BOL

Where is Maisy?
Written/illustrated by Lucy Cousins
(Walker, £4.99)
"Maisy is going to hide. Can you find her?"
Buy it at BOL

 Vivian French is author of numerous books for children and young people

fields.headline: Everything to hand
fields.standfirst: Tips with suggestions for building your home reference library
fields.trailText: Helping a child with their homework can reduce any parents to panic. Here Jerry Hurst gives some vital tips, with suggestions for building your home reference library
fields.body:
'How much have you got to do? By when? How can they possibly expect you to find enough about that? Are you sure you got it right? Fractional distillation? What did the teacher say?'

Don't panic, help is at hand. Homework can be a cause of anxiety for children and for parents, but there are lots of ways to lighten the load, make assignments less rushed and more interesting and avoid doing children's work for them.

If possible, it's a good idea to invest in a small collection of reference books for the home. You don't need huge quantities - just a good dictionary, an atlas and some reference books covering the key areas of study and in your child's main areas of interest. Reference books don't always have to be organised in the typical encyclopaedia or dictionary format, but they should be easy to use time and again, offering their content in a straightforward and accessible way, taking a child directly to appropriate information.

Looking at the crucial primary and early secondary school years (Key Stages 2 and 3), here are a few hints on what new books are around to make learning fun.

Encyclopaedias

The multi-media approach to homework is supported by Usborne's exciting new range of reference books, which exploit the natural connections between the printed word and the Internet. The Usborne Internet-Linked Encyclopedia Of World History, edited by Jane Bingham (Usborne hardback, £30) takes us from prehistory to the Internet age via the key events of history. The continuous narrative is objective and easy to follow and because of the highly visual approach, the book is really easy to use. But the 'value-added' element is the hundreds of recommended web sites, providing topic links throughout.

Companion titles include The Usborne Internet-Linked Science Encyclopedia and The Usborne Internet-Linked Introduction To Music. These are well suited to children at Key Stage 2, though the range of recommended web sites means that many older children will find the book useful.

It's good to see The Oxford Children's Encyclopedia Of Our World, edited by Ben Dupre (Oxford University Press, £9.99) re-issued in paperback. This 'quick reference' book is organised into short articles presented in A-Z order by subject and is beautifully illustrated with colour photographs and clear colour drawings. Very ambitious in its coverage, we are taken through topics from countries to climate, trade to transport. It has an atlas and a really useful data file of flags, facts and figures. The information is brief but that's fine at the level of study for which it is intended - Key Stage 2 and over. There are three further titles in the series - Science And Technology, Plants And Animals and History.
Buy it at BOL

History

The War In The Trenches, by Ole Steen Hansen (Wayland hardback, £11.99) begins with the origins of World War I and looks in detail at the factual and moral issues surrounding the horrors of the battles of Verdun, the Somme and Passchendaele. This is by no means a typical reference book, since the information is presented in the context of the human consequences of warfare. But alongside its clear, accessible text are side panels of key facts and figures which give the book lasting value as a source of reference for young people at Key Stage 3 and over. Other titles in the World Wars series are Armistice 1918, Leaders Of World War II, Germany And Japan Attack, The Great Battles Of World War II and World War II: The Allied Victory.
Buy it at BOL

Science

And to put us out of our misery, The Kingfisher Science Encyclopedia, edited by Professor Charles Taylor (Kingfisher hardback, £30) helps us very well with the fractional distillation problem. For the uninitiated, it turns out to be a process used in the refining of crude oil. The process is clearly explained and illustrated, so it doesn't take an expert in petrochemicals to glean an understanding from this book, or to make the links with other, related areas of study such as molecular chemistry or energy and conservation. Arranged thematically - Planet Earth, Chemistry and Elements, Forces and Movement and so on - and with a detailed index and clear pictures, this is very easy to use and its lively style raises the subject matter above the purely academic. Third in a series of encyclopedias intended for children at Key Stage 2 and over, this book is a companion to The Kingfisher Children's Encyclopedia and The Kingfisher History Encyclopedia.
Buy it at BOL

A little bit of everything

Dorling Kindersley's wide-ranging Eyewitness Guides are a good example of how books can adapt to reach a generation of children often more familiar with the visual approach of TV and computer. There are now more than one hundred Eyewitness Guides, covering the natural world, science and technology, history, daily life, the arts and sport. 'Bite-size' pieces of information are presented alongside excellent full-colour photographs - often of three dimensional models, original artefacts and contemporary illustrations - to show us how things work and why things happen. And because each title is so attractive and easy to use, it can be a wonderful introduction to a subject, and a reference book of lasting value. The text is simple and brief, so it is accessible to quite young children, though the more specialist titles, such as Time and Space, Watercolour and Media, might appeal more to the older child or to adults.

Whether it's Archaeology or Dance, Flying Machine or two of the newest titles - Epidemic, by Brian Ward (hardback, £9.99 - Buy it at BOL) or Football, by Hugh Hornby (hardback, £9.99 - Buy it at BOL), the punchy approach means strong 'browser appeal'. For the more purposeful user, the information is always accessible via a clear list of contents and a detailed index helps the child find their way around the book quickly and easily.

Helping with homework

 Encourage children to record their assignments accurately and understand what is expected of them.

 Don't forget that no one is an expert on everything and that includes parents! Giving encouragement and knowing where to look for information is far more important than knowing the answers.

 Lack of time can be a problem, but it's more important to be available for guidance and encouragement than to slog through hours of work with a child, which doesn't encourage interest or independent study.

 Know what resources are available - as well as books there are the internet, CD ROMs, TV, videos, newspapers and magazines.

 Many schools and public libraries offer homework support after school. This helps children to do research in their own time and at their own pace. Even if your library doesn't offer homework support, it will have a range of the newest and best reference materials, including the books reviewed here.

 Plan activities to do with your child that are relevant to topics they are covering at school. Museums, galleries and exhibitions can provide essential information and can be great for developing a child's (or adult's) interest in a subject.

 Don't forget how useful it can be for children to share ideas and information with each other - it's not cheating, it's co-operative learning!

 Jerry Hurst is young people's services librarian for Southwark borough, London

fields.headline: Cinderellas no more
fields.standfirst: The 4-8s haven't been catered for very well in the past, says Lyn Gardner. But a new generation of authors are giving them something to get their teeth into
fields.trailText: A new generation of authors are giving this age group something to get their teeth into
fields.body:
The four-to-eights used to be the Cinderellas of the children's book world, languishing in a no-man's land between the thrilling and often thrillingly tactile world of picture books for babies and the text-heavy and more emotionally challenging classics such as The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe (HarperCollins, £3.99).

But publishers have now woken up to the fact that while some confident readers in the upper end of this age range may be ready for CS Lewis or JK Rowling, most need a bridge between baby books and more sophisticated fiction.

Old treasures

This doesn't mean you should throw away the picture books. All those old favourites such as Maurice Sendak's Where The Wild Things Are (Red Fox, £5.99), Martin Wadell's Can't You Sleep, Little Bear? (Walker, £4.99) and Avocado Baby (Red Fox, £4.99) take on new meanings at this age and probably do more to encourage independent reading than any reading scheme. Those stories, as well as other classics such as Madeline, Babar and Make Way For Ducklings, are included in The Hutchinson Treasury Of Stories To Read Aloud, which costs a stiff £19.95, but could easily become a family heirloom for future generations.

It is not just that the selection of stories is so mouth-watering, but they all come with the original pictures, not always the case with cheaper anthologies.
Buy The Hutchinson Treasury at BOL

If you haven't yet got round to Not Now, Bernard by David McKee (Red Fox, £3.99), The Worst Witch by Jill Murphy (Puffin, £3.99) and The Mousehole Cat by Antonia Barber and Nicola Bayley (Walker, £4.99) now is the time to do it, but there are plenty of new titles coming out that have the makings of modern classics.

Children to relate to

Lauren Child has burst exuberantly upon children's publishing with her funny, daffy stories about Clarice Bean, a small girl who is about eight going on 88 and who lives in a very modern household that is always in uproar. The latest is My Uncle Is A Hunkie Says Clarice Bean (Orchard, £10.99). A ticklish title and a ticklish book with Child's trademark hurdy gurdy mixture of drawings, photos and typography that cleverly reflects its actual meaning - the words for driving to the hospital very fast are very squiggly.
Buy it at BOL

For sheer giggle quotient you can't beat Nicholas Allan's Demon Teddy(Red Fox, £4.99), about a talking teddy bear who teaches unpleasant, arrogant Dominic how to be nicer by saying words such as 'Knickers' or 'Bottom' at the wrong moment in class.
Buy it at BOL

Snuggling up

Marcia Williams 'No Worries! (Walker, £4.99) similarly taps into the concerns of the modern child. It is a busy and highly entertaining comic-strip style meditation on those anxiety-inducing moments when you worry whether Father Christmas will be off sick this year, or there might be a monster under your bed, or you could be turning up at the party in fancy dress when everyone else is in ordinary clothes. As appropriate for 40 year olds as four year olds - so read it and laugh at your fears together.
Buy it at BOL

For sheer snuggle together pleasure you can't beat My Dad by Anthony Browne (Doubleday, £9.99). Browne has a sharp eye that always sees the extraordinary in the most ordinary lives. Here a dad who never succeeds in getting out of his dressing gown manages to see off a wolf, dance the tango, replace one of the three tenors and do long division, all before breakfast. There is a great sense of humour at work here in these typically bold drawings that are full of the kind of visual jokes that keep small children alert.
Buy it at BOL

Something a bit different

Even at this early age satire has its place. Weslandia by Paul Fleischman, illustrated by Kevin Hawkes (Walker, £4.99) is a sly, quirky tale about Wesley, an outcast from the civilisation around him in Suburban America. Only Wesley wakes up to the fact that even a weed can take over the world, given the right wind conditions, and he founds his own alternative civilisation. This is a wholly original, very sophisticated picture book for the upper end of this age range.

If they like Weslandia they will love Sitting Ducks by Michael Bedard (Walker, £9.99), an alligator-eat-duck fable, with bold illustrations with unusual perspectives, that charts the development of a very unusual friendship.
Buy it at BOL

Or try Clever Cat by Peter Collington (Jonathan Cape, £9.99), a sideways look at our busy, busy lives told through the story of a cat who opens his own cat food, gets a front door key and starts a job but soon decides that snoozing in the sun is preferable. Children who fear that they have too many violin and dancing lessons, extra maths and infant Japanese and not enough time to play should save up and buy this for their parents.
Buy it at BOL

Nature as it really is

Michael Morpurgo's The Silver Swan (Doubleday, £10.99) is beautiful, with its heart-stoppingly exquisite, smoky blue illustrations by Christian Birmingham. This is a story about love that doesn't shirk the cruelty of nature or its miraculous capacity for renewal. We all had a jolly good cry together.
Buy it at BOL

A bit of a dog

Box Dogs' Night by Meredith Hooper, illustrated by Allan Curless and Mark Burgess (Frances Lincoln, £10.99) is barkingly good fun. It tells the story of the one night of the year when the dogs in the paintings at the National Gallery come to life, bound out of their pictures and play around the empty galleries together. Only on this particular night some of them get back into the wrong paintings. So instead of a brown, hunting dog Gainsborough's snooty Mr and Mrs Andrews end up with a small, hairy mongrel and Seurat's bathers at Asnieres don't have a little red dog with floppy ears but Madame de Pompadour's black dog with a wavy tail. The illustrations and paintings are cleverly conjoined and you don't have to know the original paintings for the story to work. A witty book that is like a wonderful game and one that won't just encourage a love of reading but a love of looking too.
Buy it at BOL

Audio Books by Valerie Bierman

Julia Jarman's delightful Jessame Stories , read by Adjoa Andoh (Cover to Cover, £3.99) encapsulate a small child's familiar world - exotic Aunt Gbee from Africa, magical Grandpa Williams and a home life which will be recognisable to the under-7s with its naughtiness, messiness and loving family.

For more anarchic happenings, try the hilarious Wilma's Wicked Revenge by Kaye Umansky (Puffin Audiobooks, £7.99) read by Sandi Toksvig. Wilma's sisters, two Wicked Queens rejoicing in the names of Frostia and Scarlatine (think Patsy and Edina!) wreak havoc at Wilma's birthday party. With a cast of memorable characters the two tapes are a joy.

For family listening, Out Of This World (Hodder Audio Books, £7.99) is a splendid anthology from the Federation of Children's Book Groups, who've come up with a selection of extracts from the best books available - including Roald Dahl's Matilda, Andrew Norriss's Aquila and Robert Swindells's Nightmare Stairs - read by June Whitfield and Sam West. The 10 extracts are odd, ghostly or from another dimension; all out of this world. Two hours playing time and there's a paperback book of the same title (Hodder, £4.99).

webTitle: Defector says most Tories are racists

fields.headline: Defector says most Tories are racists
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Shaun Woodward, the former Conservative MP who defected to Labour, yesterday launched a stinging attack on his old party, declaring that most Tories were "instinctive racists" who had stirred hate crimes.
fields.body:
Shaun Woodward, the former Conservative MP who defected to Labour, yesterday launched a stinging attack on his old party, declaring that most Tories were "instinctive racists" who had stirred hate crimes.

Flanked by Neville Lawrence, father of the murdered black teenager Stephen Lawrence, at a fringe meeting in Brighton, Mr Woodward accused William Hague of "disgraceful" behaviour when he called for all asylum seekers to be locked up.

The MP for Witney told the meeting: "What was disgraceful was when the Conservative party, seeing how good it was at winning short term political support, actually developed political strategies designed to win local election seats and councils based on stirring up these fears because of the way they used their language."

Mr Woodward added that the Tories' careless language had endangered Britain's ethnic minorities.

"Indirectly it does lead almost immediately to the promotion of hate crimes and actually the sort of appalling, disgraceful things that Stephen [Lawrence] suffered, he said. "There will have been people... who do not have white skin in Britain who after the local elections this year will have been the victims of beatings, maiming and probably murder because of the sentiment that was stirred up." Mr Woodward's remarks will come as a blow to the Tory leadership which recently appointed the former London mayor candidate Steven Norris as a party vice-chairman in charge of wooing ethnic minorities.

Mr Norris, who reached out to all communities during the mayoral election contest, has admitted that the Tories need to do more to appeal to such voters.

His private thoughts about the racism in the Tory party were voiced by a senior aide during the election contest. Ceri Evans said in a taped telephone conversation that Mr Norris's anti-racist views "cost him dear amongst the rather unpleasant core of the party".

Mr Woodward said yesterday that "decent, honest one-nation Conservatives" were being purged from influential positions in the party.

"Tragically, what was once called a one nation Conservative party is today, under William Hague, a party fast be coming only united by its collective fears and its collective prejudices and by everything that it is against and that is the identity it craves," he said.

The MP for Witney also turned his fire on his new party, saying that Labour had made a grave error by talking about "bogus asylum seekers" in the spring.

"But the question is, when it was pointed out, what did they do, and actually to their credit Jack Straw stopped using it," Mr Woodward said.

"But the question is, when it was pointed out, what did they do, and actually to their credit Jack Straw stopped using it," Mr Woodward said.

webTitle: Aer Lingus signs up new faces in UK ad drive

fields.headline: Aer Lingus signs up new faces in UK drive
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Playboy Peter Stringfellow and legendary comedian Spike Milligan are the latest stars to lend their faces to a UK press and poster campaign for Aer Lingus. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Playboy Peter Stringfellow and legendary comedian Spike Milligan are the latest stars to lend their faces to a UK press and poster campaign for Aer Lingus.

The advertisements, created by Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, break next week. They will position the airline as the obvious choice for business travellers flying to Ireland.

The ads will promote the frequency of Aer Lingus flights and the company's membership of the Oneworld airline alliance.

One ad features a photograph of Stringfellow alongside copy that reads "Being unfaithful has its benefits". This refers to the airline's frequent flyer scheme.

The second spot features Milligan with his eyes closed, while the copy reads "The late Spike Milligan?". This will be followed three days later by a second ad featuring an animated Milligan and the line "The late Spike Milligan? Not likely".

Other stars to have backed the campaign include Manchester United captain Roy Keane, singer and DJ Boy George and the actor Richard Harris.

The ads were written and art directed by Nick Worthington and Paul Brazier, with photography by Robert Wilson.

Media planning and buying is through New PHD.

webTitle: Blunkett crusade to boost adult skills

fields.headline: Blunkett crusade to boost adult skills
fields.standfirst:
Nursery places promised to all 3-year-olds
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A "national crusade" backed by an extra £150m to improve adult literacy, numeracy and computer skills was unveiled yesterday by David Blunkett, the education secretary.
fields.body:
A "national crusade" backed by an extra £150m to improve adult literacy, numeracy and computer skills was unveiled yesterday by David Blunkett, the education secretary.

In a warmly received speech to the Labour conference in Brighton, Mr Blunkett mixed praise for teachers with urgings for the country not to turn back to the Tory era, which meant that on arriving in office Labour "had to start creating a literate and numerate nation".

Seven million adults lack basic literacy and numeracy skills, he said, unable to read a bus timetable or a newspaper headline. With more money for adult education, particularly books and improved teaching, the government will be spending £403m on basic skills by 2003-4.

The Sheffield Brightside MP said: "The people of constituencies like mine are the ones for whom the Labour government is critical... If we go back to the betrayal of those 18 years it would be a crime against our country."

A much trailed promise for Labour's next manifesto, to extend nursery provision to all three-year-olds whose parents want it, was confirmed and given a 2004 delivery date and an extra £400m. Nursery education will "become as natural as primary and secondary education is today", Mr Blunkett predicted. Since the last election, 120,000 extra places for three- and four-year-olds have been created, the government says.

Opening a nursery school in Hove in advance of Mr Blunkett's speech, Mr Blair said: "We are trying to make a lot of progress in nursery education but we are very much aware of the fact that there's still a lot more to do."

Up to 7,000 schools in England will be given new roofs or classrooms as part of capital funding worth £7.8bn over three years to restore crumbling buildings. Head teachers will be given extra money directly, circumventing local authorities, for improving school fabric. A typical secondary school will receive £50,000 (compared to £19,000 this year) and a typical primary £16,000, up on £6,500 this year. Some 600 schools will be rebuilt or completely overhauled.

Like Mr Blair, the education secretary went out of his way to praise teachers and other school staff as "heroes". And he gave an implied but clear dig at Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools, who infuriated much of the profession with a call in the Guardian last month for an inquiry into exam "grade inflation".

"What's good enough for the well off, what is good enough for me and my children, what I hope for my children I want for every child in the country. No more nonsense which says if my child achieves excellence then things are fine and if your child does well standards are dropping, exams are easier," Mr Blunkett said.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said the speech was "very positive". Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters/Union of Women Teachers, welcomed "another good day for education".

Theresa May, shadow education secretary, said: "Teachers will take no comfort from this speech. Their cries to reduce bureaucracy and improve discipline have been ignored. This again shows that the government is not listening."

webTitle: United sign record deal with Nike

fields.headline: United sign record deal with Nike
fields.trailText: Manchester United have agreed a world-record deal with the sportswear company Nike that will earn the Premiership champions £300m over 15 years.
fields.body:
Manchester United have agreed a world-record deal with the sportswear company Nike that will earn the Premiership champions £300m.

The 15-year deal, to be announced on Monday, will eclipse any other in the football industry. It is due to start when Umbro's current contract expires in two years.

It will be worth an estimated £20m a year, esily beating the current world-record kit deal between Nike and the Brazilian Football Federation. That 10-year agreement is worth about £7m a year to Brazil and covers all the country's national teams, including junior and women.

Nike has taken the dramatic step in a move to gain a stranglehold of the world football business after seeing the basketball market fall. The retirement two years ago of Michael Jordan, who helped make Nike's name and fortune, hit the company hard.

Nike had already forged close links with United, most notably through its endorsement of Eirc Cantona. The current United players Andy Cole, Dwight Yorke, and Paul Scholes are all kitted out in Nike.

The company has spoken to Sir Alex Fergfson about him adopting a role as a part-time "ambassador" for Nike when he retires. A furious process of tender has been going on in secrecy at Old Trafford for several months and a plc deputation also visited Nike's world headguarters in Oregon.

Emmanuel Petit last night insisted he had no intention of leaving Barcelona despite reports in the Spanish press that Barca have asked his agents to find the former Arsenal player another club.

Petit has been a peripheral figure in his first two months at the Nou Camp, having failed to impress the coaching staff, and Mundo Deportivo reported that Chelsea were among a host of clubs alerted to his possible availability.

"I've spoken to Jose Mari Bakero [the assistant coach] and he has told me there is nothing in this story," responded Petit. "I'll do everything to stay here and be successful. I'm not a quitter."

Petit signed for Barcelona for £9m during the summer but has started only one game since the Spanish league got under way and did not play in Tuesday's 2-0 Champions League defeat by Milan.

He has since said that he would have preferred to stay at Arsenal but was sold against his wishes; and he has also said that he is unhappy to be consigned to the bench.

 David Beckham last night denied allegations that he spat towards the German referee Markus Merk near the end of Manchester United's 3-1 defeat by PSV Eindhoven in the Champions League match on Tuesday.

Although he did not deny spitting, he was adamant it was not at the official. "I did not spit at the referee at all," he said. "Things happen, you react and get headlines for it. But sometimes it looks worse than it actually is."

Merk, who later booked the midfielder for dissent, apparently failed to spot the spitting incident.

 Mark Kennedy and Phil Babb learned last night that they will not play for the Republic of Ireland until they have answered court charges of drunken behaviour and criminal damage. They are due to appear in court on November 13.

The events in Dublin city centre on August 28 are threatening to have serious repercussions for the international careers of both players after Mick McCarthy yesterday omitted them from the squad for the World Cup qualifiers against Portugal in Lisbon on Saturday week and at home to Estonia four days later.

Kennedy, of Manchester City, and Babb, of Sporting Lisbon, were sent home after being arrested by an off-duty policewoman for allegedly jumping on her car after a late-night drinking session in the build-up to the Republic's Group Two game in the Netherlands this month.

 Bayer Leverkusen's coach Christoph Daum said yesterday he would take up the post with German national team next year despite the launch of a fraud probe into his finances. Daum said he would sign a three-year contract with the German FA in the next few weeks. "I am looking forward to the job. Everything is sorted out," he told a German news agency.

 Saudi Arabia are to calling for the release of the Wolverhampton Wanderers striker Sami Al Jaber 14 days before the start of the Asian Cup in Lebanon. The Saudi coach Milan Macala wants Wolves to release Al Jaber following the First Division match against Nottingham Forest on Saturday.

Al Jaber joined Wolves at the start of September, but only made his full debut in the 3-2 defeat by Grimsby Town in the League Cup on Tuesday night. He became the first Saudi to sign for an English side when he joined on a four-year contract after leaving Riyadh club Al Hilal.

You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Bring music back to school studies, urges composer

fields.headline: Bring music back to school studies, urges composer
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: One of Britain's leading composers yesterday called for music to return to the heart of the school curriculum, saying it was "a matter of shame" that so many pupils from comprehensive schools were less involved in music than generations before them.
fields.body:
One of Britain's leading composers yesterday called for music to return to the heart of the school curriculum, saying it was "a matter of shame" that so many pupils from comprehensive schools were less involved in music than generations before them.

James MacMillan, whose prolific output includes two symphonies and a much performed percussion concerto, also said music should be restored as one of the country's core cultural values.

Mr MacMillan's comments, made during rehearsals for his first concert as composer and conductor with the BBC Philharmonic Orchestra, in Manchester, were prompted in part by local council cutbacks in free music tuition.

"Music has always been the casualty in the school curriculum over the last 20 years," he said. Now access to instrumental tuition had been restricted. Speaking of his own children he said they were the only pupils in their class learning instruments.

"That's because we pay for lessons," he said. "The involvement by pupils from comprehensive schools has decreased and that is a matter of shame which I think a Labour government especially would want to address."

His comments were welcomed by Carol Main, director of the National Association of Youth Orchestras, which represents 1,800 ensembles with 125,000 young players.

But Richard Howlett, head of Hampshire council's music service, said the government's standards fund and the national foundation for youth music, set up by Chris Smith, culture secretary, had begun to halt music's decline.

Mr MacMillan, whose comments on Scottish anti-Catholic bigotry stirred controversy at last year's Edinburgh festival, said that music was no longer at the centre of society. "A hundred years ago, there was a certain type of intellectual in western society who was completely au fait with music, and with contemporary music at that.

"Gradually that engagement has been broken. Politically, we have to make a decision to bring the arts and music back as one of the basics."

Mr MacMillan follows Sir Peter Maxwell Davies as the Philharmonic's composer and conductor. His first concert will be at the Bridgewater Hall in Manchester on Saturday.
