webTitle: Sunken ferry's captain charged with murder

fields.headline: Sunken ferry's captain charged with murder
fields.trailText:
The captain and three crew members of a Greek ferry that sank killing at least 65 people have been charged with multiple counts of
murder, a prosecutor said today.
 
Investigators were focusing on reports that the ship, carrying more than 500 passengers, was apparently on automatic pilot
minutes before it hit a well-marked rocky outcrop near the island of Paros.
fields.body:
The captain and three crew members of a Greek ferry that sank killing at least 65 people have been charged with multiple counts of murder, a prosecutor said today. Investigators were focusing on reports that the ship, carrying more than 500 passengers, was apparently on automatic pilot minutes before it hit a well-marked rocky outcrop near the island of Paros.

As investigations continued into suggestions that the crew was watching football on television when the vessel ploughed into rocks two miles from shore, the ship's owner pointed the finger of blame at Captain Vassilis Yiannakisits.

According to Greek newspaper the Athens News, he has crashed two other vessels under his command. But the paper also claims that an engineer and former employee of the ship's owners, Minoan Flying Dolphins, had asked the harbour authorities to inspect the 35-year-old ferry the day before Monday's scheduled departure.

Engineer Antonis Sorocos, a member of the Panhellenic Union of Merchant Marine Engineers, believed the vessel, due to be taken out of service in December, was unfit to sail. Mr Sorocos said the ship's security system and its instruments for controlling speed and direction were in very poor condition.

Crew member Panayiotis Gastaglis, who was on helm duty, told the paper he could not see the rock islet until it suddenly appeared 20 to 30 metres ahead because the instruments indicated that the boat was on course. Mr Gastaglis said: "There wasn't even one chance in a million that I could have done something to prevent the collision. The wind threw us off course."

Whether the accident was a result of human error or mechanical fault will be the subject of a magistrate's investigation which should be completed within the next 20 days.

The final death toll may be higher than 65. Around 12 people are officially listed as missing, but the number may increase as other passengers not accounted for may have bought tickets on board the ship, and tickets had not been issued to small children. No Britons are thought to be missing.

A spokeswoman for the British embassy in Greece said this morning that no British people had so far been identified among the dead.

Francesca Flessati said: "As far as I understand it we still definitely have 14 Britons who were rescued from the ship Eight or nine bodies of the dead remain unidentified.

"That does not end the possibility that Britons sadly may have died, but certainly we have not had any reported missing so far. It actually looks a bit more reassuring this morning from the British point of view."

She said a few of the 14 survivors had made their way to Britain, but many had stayed in Paros overnight. Meanwhile, tourists continue to arrive in Athens from Paros on extra flights put on by Olympic Airways.

fields.headline: Freeserve losses double as unmetered access takes its toll
fields.trailText: September 28: Freeserve's first quarter losses have doubled as the cost of subsidising its unmetered access service pushed it further into the red, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Freeserve, the UK's leading internet service provider, said its first quarter losses have doubled as the cost of subsidising its unmetered access service pushed the company further into the red.

The company, a constant source of takeover speculation, said pre-tax losses for the 16 weeks to August rose from £7.1m to £13.5m, with the deficit increased by a one-off charge of £6.7m for a TV advertising campaign. Europe's biggest ISPs are struggling to implement a flat rate business model, as shown by Altavista UK's decision to drop its service in August.

The silver lining came in the turnover figures, which leapt from £3.4m last year to £14.6m, while subscriber numbers rose 43% to break the 2m barrier. Freeserve hopes that the subsidy, which amounts to 250p per month per subscriber, will increase use of its portals and boost online time.

One analyst said that the share price would continue to suffer as Freeserve loses money through establishing market share in the flat rate market, but it would benefit from BT's Flat Rate Internet Access Call Origination programme. Friaco is the planned wholesale pricing scheme for ISPs, which Freeserve hopes will "make a positive margin" on its products.

He commented: "Altavista and WorldOnline have had massive problems with unmetered access, but if Freeserve can sustain the losses incurred by recruiting customers, it will lock them in when Friaco is introduced. It has 50% of the unmetered access market already."

Freeserve's position as UK market leader has made it a target of European rivals, including Germany's T-Online and Italy's Tiscali, though it has a strong relationship with owner Dixons, the high street retailer.

Nick Bubb, analyst at SG Securities, said: "Dixons is still a very good parent, though probably not the best in the long term. In the future, Freeserve will need a partner in broadband or television."

Freeserve's shares fell 2.7% to 235.5p.

fields.headline: BBC sprints to ratings victory with Olympics coverage
fields.trailText: 1.45pm overnights: ITV's Trisha trailed in behind BBC1's Olympic coverage in yesterday's daytime ratings, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC's public service obligations brought both ratings joy and misery in daytime yesterday, in the shape of BBC1's Olympic coverage and BBC2's Labour party conference programme, respectively.

In the morning, Olympic Grandstand (2.2m, 47% share from 7.55am-12.30pm) again duffed up ITV's Trisha (1m, 23%) and This Morning (1.2m, 27%). After lunch, BBC1 returned to Sydney between 1.45-3.25pm, averaging 2m/32% and romped home well ahead of the ITV opposition.

But on BBC2 yesterday, with no Tony Blair speech to attract viewers, Conference Live limped along with 0.2m/4% in the morning (10.50am-1pm) and 0.5m/8% in the afternoon (2-3.50pm).

ITV's Champions League coverage of Arsenal's victory over Lazio drew 7.5m/34% (7.30-9.45pm). Coronation Street (10.2m, 48%) came in strongly at 9.45pm and gave a useful leg-up to ITV's current affairs flagship, Tonight with Trevor McDonald (5.4m, 33%), from 10.15pm.

webTitle: Freeserve has posted a widened first quarter loss

fields.headline: Freeserve's profits continue to slide
fields.standfirst: Freeserve signs up with Bush Internet and ONnet
fields.trailText: 9am: Freeserve has posted a widened first quarter loss, due to technology spending and marketing costs, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Freeserve, the UK's leading internet service provider, has posted a widened first quarter loss, due to technology spending and marketing costs.

The company, which this summer has been subject to constant takeover speculation, said turnover for the 16 weeks to August 19 was £14.6m, against £3.3m for the same period last year. However, the company continues to sink into the red, with a loss of £14.6m, against £5m previously.

Freeserve said it now has more than 2m subscribers, and there has been a 72% increase in page impressions per active account compared with August last year.

John Pluthero, Freeserve's chief executive, said: "Our leadership of the UK internet market has been extended by the popularity of our unmetered access offers. As we extend the availability of unmetered access, we will drive more users to our portals, reduce our churn, increase time online and generate higher e-commerce and advertising revenue."

Freeserve, which is 80% owned by high-street retailer Dixons, is far behind its European rivals in terms of subscribers and continental coverage. It is seen as a prime target for Italy's Tiscali, Wannadoo of France and Germany's T-Online, which this summer tried to buy the company.

Freeserve remains the best way to break into the UK ISP market, and its share price invariably rises whenever takeover speculation sweeps the City.

Freeserve's shares rose 0.3% to 242.75p in early trading.

webTitle: Church accepts Milosevic's rival as president-elect

fields.headline: Church accepts Milosevic's rival as president-elect
fields.trailText: The influential Serbian Orthodox Church has urged opposition candidate Vojislav Kostunica to take control of the country in a peaceful way.
fields.body:
The influential Serbian Orthodox Church has recognised Slobodan Milosevic's opponent as Yugoslavia's new president-elect, urging him to take control of the country in a peaceful way.

The church appealed to opposition candidate Vojislav Kostunica for restraint during a meeting of the Holy Synod, its highest body. The church holds no direct political power in Yugoslavia, but its dictates hold great moral sway in a population which recognises it as a pillar of rectitude in a corrupt society.

It appealed to urged Kostunica and his camp to, "take over the helm of the state, its parliament and municipalities, in as peacefully and as dignified a manner, as possible."

The statement came the morning after more than 200,000 joyful anti-Milosevic demonstrators swarmed the capital's downtown district, waving banners and chanting "He's finished."

The biggest demonstration ever against Milosevic completely blocked Belgrade's main streets around Republic Square. Much of the downtown area teemed with people.

The opposition threatened widespread civil disobedience as a means to pressure Milosevic to step down after his government released final election figures showing neither candidate won a majority - the requirement for an outright victory.

Kostunica finished first in Sunday's elections with 48.96% to 38.62% for Milosevic, the State Election Commission said late yesterday. That would require a runoff on October 8.

"Milosevic cannot resort to violence... look how many people took to the streets - no one in this country has the power nor dares give orders against these people," Milan Protic of the opposition said. "I believe no one in the police or army is prepared to give his life for a man who lost the elections."

An opposition member of the electoral commission said that the head of the commission presented the 13 members with the results late yesterday without allowing them to inspect the returns.

Sinisa Nikolic said 300 of the more than 10,000 polling stations never reported, and he accused the commission of reducing the overall total by 600,000 votes.

Another opposition leader, Goran Svilanovic, said anti-Milosevic forces "will try to avoid violence but we will persist in our effort to protect the will of the people."

US President Bill Clinton and other Western leaders have dismissed talk of a runoff. "The government's official election commission has no credibility whatever," Clinton said.

The United States will move to lift economic sanctions against Yugoslavia and restore its rights as a UN member state if Kostunica is installed in Belgrade, Richard Holbrooke, the US ambassador to the United Nations, told the Security Council.

webTitle: BBC plans five new radio stations

fields.headline: BBC plans five new radio stations
fields.trailText: 10.30am: BBC Radio this morning announced plans to launch five new licence fee-funded national radio services, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC Radio this morning announced plans for five new licence fee-funded national radio services, to be available on all digital platforms including the internet.

The services will include a black music and news station aimed at young people, a music station based on the BBC's more recent musical archives, a drama and speech station, a station offering enhancements to Radio Five Live with extra sports coverage, and a network of Asian stations.

The services will be put to public consultation, and if approved, could be launched from as early as spring 2001.

The BBC's director of radio, Jenny Abramsky, said "The digital future is as vital for radio as it is for television. This announcement recognises the importance of radio to the BBC and gives us the opportunity to reach as many of our licence fee payers as we can."

fields.headline: Spellbinding realism
fields.standfirst: Philip Pullman looks to the past for inspiration and finds it among this year's crop of teenage books
fields.trailText: This year's crop look to the past for inspiration
fields.body:
As chance would have it, a number of the books that caught my eye this year deal with the past in one way or another. Perhaps the millennium has something to do with it; at all events, there's a wide variety of matter and treatment on offer.

The British imagination finds the figure of King Arthur a source of inexhaustible fertility. The latest embodiment of the legend is Kevin Crossley-Holland's splendid The Seeing Stone (Orion, £9.99). It has an unusual perspective: in the year 1199, Arthur de Caldicot is the younger son of the lord of the manor of Caldicot, near the Welsh border. There is a Merlin in his life: a presence both familiar and strange, deeply mistrusted by the village priest, and this Merlin gives young Arthur a black stone in which he sees the story of the legendary Arthur played out for him. The more he sees, the more their stories begin to overlap. This book (the first of a trilogy) is told in 100 very short sections, as bright and vivid as the pictures in a Book of Hours. Deep scholarship, high imagination, and great gifts of storytelling have gone into this; I was spellbound.
Buy it at BOL

Hans Magnus Enzensberger's Where Were You, Robert? (Hamish Hamilton, £14.99) has found much deserved praise in Europe. Young Robert, in his early teens, has a problem with his eyes: when he looks into a picture of some scene from the past, his vision draws him into it. His journeys take him first to Communist Russia in 1956, and ultimately by a series of further picture-engulfments to a painter's studio in 17th century Holland. What I most enjoyed about this, apart from the brilliantly vivid recreations of the sights and textures and smells of the past, was Robert's matter-of fact resourcefulness in dealing with his predicament. He is realistically uneasy and afraid, but it's his own courage and skill that rescue him every time. The story plays absolutely fair, and the translation, by Anthea Bell, reads beautifully.
Buy it at BOL

It's fascinating to watch an author discover where her imagination is really at home. Jamila Gavin's Coram Boy (Mammoth, £5.99) takes us to 18th century England, where a rich and almost Gothic drama unfolds, full of dastardly villains, cold-hearted aristocrats, devoted friends and passionate lovers, and set against a background of cruelty, music, murder and the neglect of children. The story sweeps along with great exuberance. I hope she gives us lots more of this.
Buy it at BOL

David Almond's past is a little closer. Counting Stars (Hodder, £9.99) is a book of short stories, some of them very short, set in a Tyneside childhood corresponding in time to Almond's own. The children in a large Catholic family face bereavement, joy, mystery, temptation, and many other experiences, beautifully preserved and delicately rendered. Almond's well-received novels have trodden the borders of fantasy: I think he is even better with this firmly-rooted realism. He has the rare gift of being tender towards experience without either sentimentalising or indulging it; he knows that raw material has to be worked on before it becomes art, and he knows how to do it.
Buy other David Almond titles at BOL

Joan Lingard's Natasha's Will (Puffin, £4.99) is a real old-fashioned family yarn. Natasha, who fled as a child from Russia following the Revolution, leaves her house to the family who look after her in Scotland in her old age - but the will can't be found, and now there's a greedy cousin claiming that the house is his. A series of delightfully literary clues lead to exactly the right sort of ending. Nothing profound here - just charm and skill, as if they were easy.
Buy it at BOL

Charm is also a feature of Because Of Winn-Dixie, by Kate DiCamillo (Walker Books £7.99). Young India Opal, daughter of a preacher living in a trailer park in Florida, acquires a scruffy dog with a winning smile. It's a tale of making friends and coming to terms with circumstances. It could easily have been mawkish; but the author judges it perfectly, and the result is delightful.
Buy it at BOL

Back to the past again with Michael Morpurgo, whose command of his material is absolute. Billy The Kid (Pavilion £12.99) isn't a Western, but a short novel in an unusual format about a footballer, growing up in the 1930s, whose great dream is to play for Chelsea. He does - but then his life, like everyone else's, is re-shaped entirely by the Second World War. The story of his subsequent decline and quite unexpected rescue is told with all the author's open-hearted clarity, and richly illustrated by Michael Foreman.
Buy other Michael Morpurgo books at BOL

The excellent Gaye Hicyilmaz's Girl In Red (Dolphin £4.99) could hardly be more topical: it's a story of intolerance and brutality towards asylum-seeking gypsies. The narrator, Frankie, discovers to his dismay that his mother is deeply involved in the protests against them: his position is even more difficult because of his feelings for Emilia, the girl in red. There are no neat outcomes; life isn't like that, this is like life.
Buy it at BOL

Readers puzzled by life will enjoy Stephen Law's The Philosophy Files (Dolphin, £6.99). He takes a number of big questions, ranging from Should I eat meat? to Where do right and wrong come from? and beyond, and examines them in a bright and mercifully non-facetious way. Curious philosophers of any age will find some basic problems dealt with in a way that genuinely illuminates them. There aren't any answers, of course, but that's not the author's fault.
Buy it at BOL

In the old days, good books were available for years. Nowadays every book has to be a bestseller at once or go out of print, with the result that there are dozens, if not scores, if not hundreds of excellent titles that deserve a revival. However, it's happening. Catherine Storr's Marianne Dreams (Faber Children's Classics, £4.99 - Buy it at BOL), Diana Wynne Jones's Dalemark Quartet (OUP Modern Classics, £6.99 - Buy it at BOL), are available again, and there are new ventures devoted to rescuing out-of-print favourites such as T H White's delicious Mistress Masham's Repose (Jane Nissen Books £5.99 - Buy it at BOL). The past is full of promise.

 Philip Pullman is an award-winning author.

webTitle: Every year I vow not to eat the food; every year I forget

fields.headline: Every year I vow not to eat the food; every year I forget
fields.standfirst: Ben Bradshaw, Labour MP for Exeter, is struck down by food poisoning on the fourth day of the Brighton conference
fields.trailText: Ben Bradshaw, Labour MP for Exeter, is struck down by food poisoning on the fourth day of the Brighton conference
fields.body:
The old grumps from the trade unions risk undoing all the good done by Brown and Blair by forcing and winning a vote on restoring pension increases to wage inflation.

The vote came despite promises of an increase in the state pension above wage inflation for the next three years when the pensioner credit comes in and an increase in the minimum pensioner income guarantee from £78 to £90.

Someone said to me earlier in the week when we were arguing about the role of the unions in the party that the good thing about them was that they knew when to stop. I wish I could remember who that was.

With thousands of canapes at the hundreds of receptions you're lucky to get away without eating something dodgy during conference week. Sure enough, I was struck down last night. After each conference I promise to myself not to eat the food, but I always forget.

That meant I missed one of the social highlights of the conference, the Mirror party. Shame, I wanted to congratulate their seasoned commentator and tormentor of New Labour, Paul Routledge, for bringing himself to say some nice things about Tony Blair in yesterday's paper.

It was either BSkyB or a reception for our sister parties from the rest of the world that made me ill. The New Labour brand clearly hasn't worn off abroad. The international lunch was packed with foreign party leaders and their countries' foreign ministers.

fields.headline: Paul Morrissey: Trash
fields.trailText: If the film is primitively made, with Morrissey's static camera augmented only by documentary inserts of street life, it isn't just an exploitative piece of sexual and social exotica. It actually has a twisted heart and mind behind it
fields.body:
A former British censor once said to me of Paul Morrissey's Trash: "It's all very well you middle-class people trotting along to see such films at the ICA or somewhere arty like that. But what do you suppose might happen if Trash were presented to a working-class audience in Manchester?"

Which is rather like asking - as did Sir Reginald Manningham-Buller, nicknamed Bullingham Manner, during the Lady Chatterley's Lover trial - whether you'd like your servants to read the book.

The answer, of course, is that the middle-classes did indeed lap up this story of a down-and-out junkie and his girl living on New York's Lower East Side, while the Manchester audience was never given the chance, though it might well have thrown its popcorn at the screen and left after 40 minutes or so. But the fact that films like Trash, its companion film, Flesh (1968), and Heat (1971) were once seen as dangerous now seems beyond all understanding.

There are two views of this seminal film from the early 70s. One is that Morrissey, who came out of Andy Warhol's Factory, is to be praised for imposing vaguely coherent story and fleshed-out character onto this Warholian epic. And that it's liberating frankness,which so worried the censor, actually masked an almost puritan and certainly rightwing morality. The other is that Morrissey should be censured, if not censored, for ruining the formal integrity of something like Chelsea Girls with conventionally authored and plotted films that were a mixture of prurience and condescension.

In fact, Morrissey certainly took a strict attitude towards drug-taking. He considered his characters worse than the Bowery winos and the film a counter attack against the romanticising of drug use in Easy Rider. "The basic idea is that drug people are trash. There's no difference between a person using drugs and a piece of refuse."

The film itself, however, was more compassionate, suggesting that its two lead characters were capable of salvaging something of their ruined lives through tenderness and loyalty.

Joe (Dallesandro) and Holly (Woodlawn, a transvestite who told Morrissey she was a Warhol Superstar despite never having met him) live in a basement apartment they furnish with trash from the street. His heroin addiction has rendered him impotent and the plot concerns Holly's abortive efforts to save him from himself and the oddities they meet on the way. The uptown people who pass through their orbit include a rich girl who wants LSD, a topless dancer, and a newly-wed couple fascinated by all things lurid.

Although it is clear that most of the women, and some of the men, including probably the director, want Joe's body - and the film is in a sense a kind of paean to this - it is Woodlawn who dominates Trash, with Morrissey accepting totally that he/she is a woman. She has said that she wanted to seem ridiculous and make people laugh. But also that the watcher should feel something for a woman who craves some sort of normalcy in her life.It is a performance that manages both, even in the notorious sequence where she masturbates with a beer bottle, gripping the impotent Joe's hand as she does so.

If the film is primitively made, with Morrissey's static camera augmented only by documentary inserts of street life, it isn't just an exploitative piece of sexual and social exotica. It actually has a twisted heart and mind behind it.

Whether you think Morrissey betrayed Warhol or not, Morrissey's view of his mentor was probably right. As he said: "Andy wasn't capable of any complicated thoughts or ideas. Ideas need a verb and a noun, a subject. Andy spoke in a kind of stumbling staccato. You had to finish sentences for him. So Andy operated through people who could do things for him. He wished things into happening, things he himself couldn't do. In that respect he was like Louis B Mayer at MGM."

He considered his characters worse than the Bowery winos and the film a counter attack against the romanticising of drug use in Easy Rider. "The basic idea is that drug people are trash. There's no difference between a person using drugs and a piece of refuse." The film itself, however, was more compassionate, suggesting that its two lead characters were capable of salvaging something of their ruined lives through tenderness and loyalty. Joe (Dallesandro) and Holly (Woodlawn, a transvestite who told Morrissey she was a Warhol Superstar despite never having met him) live in a basement apartment they furnish with trash from the street. His heroin addiction has rendered him impotent and the plot concerns Holly's abortive efforts to save him from himself and the oddities they meet on the way. The uptown people who pass through their orbit include a rich girl who wants LSD, a topless dancer, and a newly-wed couple fascinated by all things lurid. Although it is clear that most of the women, and some of the men, including probably the director, want Joe's body - and the film is in a sense a kind of paean to this - it is Woodlawn who dominates Trash, with Morrissey accepting totally that he/she is a woman. She has said that she wanted to seem ridiculous and make people laugh. But also that the watcher should feel something for a woman who craves some sort of normalcy in her life.It is a performance that manages both, even in the notorious sequence where she masturbates with a beer bottle, gripping the impotent Joe's hand as she does so. If the film is primitively made, with Morrissey's static camera augmented only by documentary inserts of street life, it isn't just an exploitative piece of sexual and social exotica. It actually has a twisted heart and mind behind it. Whether you think Morrissey betrayed Warhol or not, Morrissey's view of his mentor was probably right. As he said: "Andy wasn't capable of any complicated thoughts or ideas. Ideas need a verb and a noun, a subject. Andy spoke in a kind of stumbling staccato. You had to finish sentences for him. So Andy operated through people who could do things for him. He wished things into happening, things he himself couldn't do. In that respect he was like Louis B Mayer at MGM."

webTitle: Hillary senate race: funding clash leaves public cold

fields.headline: Hillary senate race: funding clash leaves public cold
fields.standfirst: Hillary Clinton's Republican opponent in the race for the senate scored a direct hit with an attack on soft money. But what is it and does the public care?
fields.trailText: Hillary and Rick: funding issues are firing the two candiates in the race for the senate, but not the public
fields.body:
It is one of those issues that captivates the political junkies and leaves the ordinary voter cold. Or, as one Democratic consultant puts it: "Nobody gives a shit about this stuff." The "stuff" in question is soft money and it has dominated Hillary Clinton's campaign for a seat in the US senate since her first televised debate with the Republican candidate, Rick Lazio who, it has been said, bears an uncanny resemblance to the presenter of BBC's Match Of The Day.

"I believe, personally, it is an important issue, but there are not many New York voters who think it is an important issue," says Mrs Clinton. "No voters ever talk to me about soft money." That's because none of them really knows what it is. And because the matter is complicated, popular newspapers do not have the room to explain it and make it interesting at the same time.

As with any episode in an election campaign, it is possible - just about - to perceive winners and losers, and in this instance Mr Lazio has won, even if the prize is a nebulous mutation of justification and credibility.

So what is soft money? Candidates are limited by law to accept contributions from individuals of up to $2,000 (£1,300) - that is hard money. But this cap is sidestepped by big-money donors and wealthy special interest groups who give unlimited amounts for "issue advertisements" that can barely be told apart from those for the candidates, except that they do not call explicitly for the election or defeat of either - and that is soft money. Just in case it might help, there are also TV and radio advertisements paid for by independent groups, say the National Rifle Association, which buy ads backing one candidate or excoriating the other.

Mr Lazio, an outwardly amiable but previously obscure Congressman from Long Island thought it was time to up the tempo of the contest and go beyond appealing to voters simply on the basis that he is not Mrs Clinton. So at one point during the debate he strode over to her and waved in her face a piece of paper called The New York Freedom from Soft Money Agreement and demanded she sign it on the spot, which she declined to do.

Most of the commentators judged that Mr Lazio had scored a few points with this and other ploys. Which was fine until the two polls after the debate showed that while this might be fine with the professionals, the voters - especially women - had divined little about the issue but a lot about him. They thought he was a bully.

The Republican had to try, somehow, to demonstrate that there was a purpose to all this, that he was on a crusade to drive out the influence of those who try to buy favour from the candidates. Never mind that Mr Lazio, on the face of it, has more to gain than Mrs Clinton from the absence of soft money in the race for the senate. He had not raised any of the stuff for ads while she had spent it freely.

On the other hand, she would still be able to spend soft money on mail-shots, phone banks and measures to get the vote out. As for the hard stuff, he has $10.2m to her $7.1m. Also, her campaign was the first to suggest banning soft money, even if she did not press the matter.

Finally, after a feeble stunted confrontation and some proper meetings, the two sides struck a deal. They agreed that only those TV and radio ads paid for by accumulations of those measly $2,000 donations would be allowed. Soft money from corporations, unions and influence-hungry individuals could not be used for this purpose. On top of that, those independent groups operating on behalf of one candidate or the other were implored to stay their hands.

Normal people may be more interested in the impending baseball World Series, but this is considered a historic agreement that could set a precedent for other elections and help the cause of campaign-finance reform in Congress. You can't argue with that. Well, you might not think so but others are less impressed by this exercise in openness, decency and restraint.

Take the AFL-CIO federation of labour unions, a supporter of Mrs Clinton. "We are not going to pledge not to do things," says Laurence Gold, its associate general counsel. "The campaigns can never secure promises from every conceivable group."

Then there is the Emergency Committee to Stop Hillary Clinton. "We raised lots of money from people," says Morton Blackwell, its chairman. "We are completely independent. No campaign or party can direct us."

If this qualifies as historic, perhaps it's just as well that the public is looking the other way.

fields.headline: Suharto corruption case dismissed
fields.trailText: An Indonesian court has thrown out corruption charges against ex-dictator Suharto, ruling he was medically and mentally unfit to face charges.
fields.body:
An Indonesian court has thrown out corruption charges against ex-dictator Suharto, ruling he was medically and mentally unfit to face charges.

The decision was greeted with stunned silence by the several hundred spectators in the makeshift courtroom. While a few Suharto supporters rejoiced, angry prosecutors said they would appeal.

Suharto was accused of stealing almost $600m in public funds during his 32 years in power.

The end of the unprecedented trial is a dramatic setback to efforts by President Wahid's year-old reformist government to end corruption and roll back a legacy of authoritarianism.

Judge Lalu Mariyan's ruling outraged anti-Suharto demonstrators outside the court, with some throwing stones and gasoline bombs at police. Officers responded with tear gas and warning shots. Six protesters were arrested.

"The doctors are all lying," said Zul Sikri, a demonstrator. "Suharto must go to jail and we will keep protesting until that happens."

A 23-member team of court-appointed doctors who said Suharto suffered from a range of ailments and after three strokes was mentally incapable of withstanding the rigours of a long trial.

"Based on neurological and psychiatric tests, Suharto has trouble expressing himself," said Dr Zakaria, the head of the team that examined Suharto last week. "When he speaks, he stops often and uses sign language to express himself. He cannot understand complex ideas."

The court also ruled that Suharto should be freed from house arrest and that other travel restrictions on him should be lifted immediately.

webTitle: Fox Kids UK poaches Capital Interactive boss

fields.headline: Fox Kids UK lures Capital Interactive chief
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Fox Kids UK has poached Capital Interactive head of business development Phil Guest to be its general manager for online and interactive services, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Fox Kids UK has poached Capital Interactive head of business development Phil Guest to be its general manager for online and interactive services.

Head of retail Beverley Blain is to replace him, taking on a wider remit encompassing both retail and sales.

The company has formed a single commercial department, combining both the retail and ad sales teams, that will cover all of Guest's responsibilities.

Capital is gearing up to launch three web radio stations in the next few months, as well as a personalised jukebox service called Kikido.

Guest joined Capital in mid-1998 from Emap, after five years in the Royal Marine Commandos.
fields.bodyText: Fox Kids UK has poached Capital Interactive head of business development Phil Guest to be its general manager for online and interactive services. Head of retail Beverley Blain is to replace him, taking on a wider remit encompassing both retail and sales. The company has formed a single commercial department, combining both the retail and ad sales teams, that will cover all of Guest's responsibilities. Capital is gearing up to launch three web radio stations in the next few months, as well as a personalised jukebox service called Kikido. Guest joined Capital in mid-1998 from Emap, after five years in the Royal Marine Commandos.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Window pains

Double glazing salesmen are an unloved and largely unlovable species. It's a reputation that some of them do their best to earn: they secure your life savings by means of a hyperbolic leaflet and smooth talking, and that's the last you hear of them. Krishna Ganase of south London, for instance, paid a £273 deposit to Essex-based firm Bryco Glaze in August 1999. A survey was conducted and he was promised that his new windows would be installed within a fortnight.

Thirteen weeks then passed in which Ganase (who had to do all the chasing) was variously told that the wooden corner sleeves he had requested were not yet available; that the company which made them had gone bust and that Bryco was trying to source them elsewhere; that no corner sleeves existed and would he accept the installation without them for a discount? He agreed, provided the job could be completed by Christmas, but was told this was impossible. A year on he's still waiting and two further letters have gone unacknowledged.

Romford Trading Standards explains that Bryco itself went into liquidation last March. BB Marketing now operates the business under the same name and, being new to the scene, shows touching signs of bashfulness. Ten weeks after Consumer first got in touch there was still no word from them. "The person you need to speak to" has a phone "but not a phone number" and therefore we can't be transferred. "What are we to do then?" we ask. "I don't know," says our spokeswoman. By the fourth week she announces that she's "sick and tired" of chasing her colleagues, but still no one calls.

Then, out of the blue, Ganase receives a refund but no letter of explanation or apology. That's because it's all his fault, retorts the numberless sales and marketing director who is finally coaxed to the phone.

"We told him the corner sleeves would be hard to come by but he's been very unreasonable and wouldn't negotiate. We've lost a lot of money over this and have always endeavoured to fulfil our contract." Ganase has since had his windows replaced without hitch by another firm.

Building trust is hard

Finding a builder who can be let loose on your home for days on end and merit an outlay of thousands can be just as nerve-racking, which is why Indar Picton-Howell of London chose one from improveline.com, a website that promises a list of meticulously vetted builders for a fee of £25. The result, for which he was asked to pay £750 in cash, was a disaster. He was left with an unusable kitchen, damaged furniture, an uneven ceiling and exposed wiring, and the builder demanded an additional £500 to continue. improveline.com promised to send an independent inspector round five weeks ago and Picton-Howell took the day off work, but no one turned up for the appointment. Since then, silence.

Soon after Picton-Howell's lament comes a remorseful email from improveline.com. "There is a strong case for compensation," says a spokesman. "Part of our service is to weed out unscrupulous and poorly performing tradesmen and if there is a problem - which is rare - we act quickly to sort it out. In this case a third-party administrator was involved who slowed the process down considerably. We no longer deal with them." improveline.com is paying for remedial work.

Online firm's apology

Tim Longdon bought an MP3 player from online electrical retailer dabs.com because the website and catalogue said it would work with Windows. What it didn't say was that it will work only with Windows 98 and not with Longdon's 95 version. Not that Longdon could know this until he had started installing the software, but Dabs still said he could not have a refund because he had opened the box. "Technical support's response was that it's well known in the industry that Windows 95 doesn't support a USB connection very well and that I should have contacted the manufacturer before buying it," says Longdon. "Why should I when the catalogue specifically states that it works with Windows?"

"We do not sell goods on a trial basis," begins Dabs sniffily, pointing out that its website is only a guide. Customers, it says, should find out more information by checking the links to manufacturers' websites. But, oh dear, Dabs did just that after Consumer rang, only to find that the manufacturer doesn't specify which Windows is compatible either. It is now offering Longdon an apology and a refund, and promises to amend its site.

Disc delivery delays

More on the many of you who are still awaiting free internet access from our new favourite, ntl. Earlier this month Karena Hackney of Stone, Staffordshire, was intrigued to read a spokeswoman promise on this page that "everyone who registered in April or May should be connected by the end of August". "I registered on March 18 and have received nothing, despite being given 10 different deadlines," she says. "The longer I'm kept waiting the more money ntl rakes in from my use of the internet. Does this disc really exist?" Chris Arundel of Tamworth registered two days before Hackney did and is also empty-handed. "They persuaded me to have an extra line installed to take advantage of their toll-free offer and have been charging me £5 a month since, although the service has never materialised," he says.

"At one point they told me that if they let me have the disc before upgrading their system I'd cause the 999 emergency network to crash. Another time they told me I had never registered."

ntl, which has blamed its own success for the delays, says "network issues" in Hackney's and Arundel's districts have compounded the problem. It promises that discs have now been dispatched to both and that Arundel's line rental has been refunded.

Doing Oftel's job

Surprisingly, given the above, David Richardson longs to join ntl's sidekick, Comtel. In fact, he wants to do what the telecoms regulator, Oftel, keeps urging customers to do - "regulate" poorly performing companies on its behalf by voting with his feet.

After his BT phone was out of order for 10 days he approached Comtel, only to find that he wouldn't be allowed to keep his existing phone number. "On pressing the matter with ntl I was told number portability is possible for a charge of £50 plus VAT, but it seems they are not advertising this as they don't have the capacity to take on many new subscribers."

"There does exist a very apparent price difference between Cable & Wireless (£4.99) and ntl (£58) regarding number portability," says a spokeswoman, after eight weeks' reflection. "This is due to C&W having an automated system for transferring numbers whereas ntl's system is manual and requires technician support. We are currently investigating how the automated system may be integrated across the entire company."

Since January, telecoms companies have been obliged to allow customers to take their numbers with them, but they can charge more or less what they like. "There is no set limit, but we say it must be reasonable - say up to £50 for a mobile," says an Oftel spokesman. Given that Oftel justifies its hands-off approach to poor service by insisting that unhappy customers should switch companies, it seems we are all to pay for the privilege of doing its job.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are set alight, so they burn long into the Sydney night
fields.trailText: Is Monaco midfielder John Arne Riise finally about to complete his on-off-on-off-on move to England? "We have had contact with Leeds in the last few weeks," his mother Berit claimed this morning, "but there are other Premiership clubs involved as well." However, David O'Leary remains the firm favourite to sign the 20-year-old Norwegian. "It is, of course, a lot of money we are talking about, but the distance between the club's valuation is not that big any more," said Berit.
fields.body:
Is Monaco midfielder John Arne Riise finally about to complete his on-off-on-off-on move to England? "We have had contact with Leeds in the last few weeks," his mother Berit claimed this morning, "but there are other Premiership clubs involved as well." However, David O'Leary remains the firm favourite to sign the 20-year-old Norwegian. "It is, of course, a lot of money we are talking about, but the distance between the club's valuation is not that big any more," said Berit.

Newcastle are set to offer 6ft 7in Trinidad and Tobago defender Dennis Lawrence a contract at St James' Park as soon as his work permit is granted, reports Planet Football. "We know the sort of player we want," said Bobby Robson. "We are lacking leadership at the back. There is nobody talking everybody is playing with their mouths shut, that's the trouble."

Wimbledon are set to sign Sunderland defender Darren Holloway in a £1.3m deal. "Darren's versatility is a big factor," admitted Wimbledon deputy chairman Charles Koppell on Teamtalk. "We already have players like Jason Euell, Neal Ardley and Kenny Cunningham who can play in more than one position. That is what we need."

Former Middlesbrough striker Jamie Moreno has flown in for talks with Huddersfield.

Blackburn defender Steve Harkness has agreed a £200,000 move to Sheffield Wednesday.

Former Middlesbrough striker Jamie Moreno has flown in for talks with Huddersfield. Blackburn defender Steve Harkness has agreed a £200,000 move to Sheffield Wednesday.

fields.headline: Videonet launches HomeChoice with huge ad campaign
fields.trailText: Videonet has announced a huge marketing and advertising campaign for its video-on-demand service, HomeChoice, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Videonet, the video-on-demand company, has announced a £15m marketing spend between September and December 2000 in support of the London-wide launch of its HomeChoice service.

Next year that spend will increase to £50m for marketing nationwide, with £35m earmarked for advertising.

Over two-thirds of the current budget will be spent on advertising and in addition to the poster, print, radio and cinema advertisements already in place, the company's first ever TV campaign breaks next week through Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters.

Two executions relay that for the first time people have the choice to watch what they want, when they want.

The first commercial features 'Comrade Steve' and his revolutionary team driving a tank and demonstrating in a suburban high street, while the second sees the revolutionaries taking over a TV studio and destroying restrictive TV schedules. A third execution will be filmed later this autumn.

Mark Springett, marketing director at Videonet said: "We will be absolutely everywhere across London over the next few months, making sure the HomeChoice name is recognised and our product benefits understood, prior to beginning our national roll-out."

At launch, HomeChoice will offer over 800 films, ranging from recent blockbusters to classics, more than 1,000 music videos, sports programming, plus over 1,000 hours of TV including comedy, drama, documentary and children's programmes - and access to TV home shopping and an interactive health and fitness service.

fields.headline: Einstein goes to war
fields.standfirst: David Bodanis  explains how E=mc2 changed the world in a fraction of a second over Hiroshima
fields.trailText: David Bodanis explains how E=mc2 changed the world in a fraction of a second over Hiroshima
fields.body:
The bomb had taken 43 seconds to fall from the B-29. There were small holes around its midpoint where wires had been tugged out of it as it dropped away: that had started the clock switches of its first arming system.

More small holes had been drilled further back on its dark steel casing and those took in samples of air as the free fall continued. At 7,000 feet above the ground, a barometric switch primed the second arming system.

From the ground the B-29 was just visible, but the bomb - a bare 10ft long, 2.5ft wide - was too small to see. Weak radio signals were pumped down from the bomb to the Shina Hospital directly below. Some signals were absorbed in the hospital's walls, but most bounced back skywards. Sticking out of the bomb's back, near the spinning fins, were a number of whip-like radio antennae. Those collected the returning radio signals, and used the time lag as a way of measuring the height remaining to the ground.

At 1,900 feet the last rebounded radio signal arrived. A bomb exploding much higher would dissipate heat in the open air; exploding much lower, it would dig a huge crater in the ground. At just under 2,000 feet the height would be ideal. An electric impulse lit cordite sacs, producing a conventional artillery blast. A small part of the total purified uranium was pushed forward down a gun barrel inside the bomb and slammed into the remaining bulk of the uranium.

Nowhere on earth had a ball of several dozen pounds of such purified uranium ever been accumulated. There were a number of stray neutrons loose inside it. Although the uranium atoms were densely protected by their outer flurries of electrons, the escaped neutrons - having no electrical charge - weren't affected by the electrons. They flew through the outer electron barrier like a probe skimming past the planets down towards our sun. While many flew straight on out the other side, a few were on a collision course for the speck of a nucleus.

They overbalanced the nucleus, making it jostle and wobble. The uranium atoms mined on Earth were each more than 4.5bn years old. Only a very powerful force, before the Earth was formed, had been able to squeeze their electrically crackling protons together. Once that uranium had been formed, the strong nuclear force had held the protons in place over all that long span: while the Earth cooled, and continents formed; as America separated from Europe, and the North Atlantic Ocean slowly filled; as volcanic bursts widened on the other side of the globe, forming what would become Japan.

A single extra neutron unbalanced that stability.

A single nucleus doesn't weigh much. Its speeding impact into the other parts of the uranium didn't heat it up much. But the density of uranium was enough that a chain reaction started, and soon there weren't just two speed ing fragments of uranium nuclei, there were four, then eight, then 16, and so on.

Mass was "disappearing" within the atoms, and coming out as the energy of speeding nuclei fragments. E=mc2 was under way. The bomb fell just a fraction of an inch in the time of most of the reaction. Only the first odd bucklings of its steel surface suggested what was going on inside. The chain reaction went through 80 generations of doubling before it ended. By the last few of those, the segments of broken uranium nuclei were so abundant - and moving so fast - that they started to heat the metal around them.

All the action of the E=mc2 reaction was over. No more mass was disappearing; no more fresh energy appeared. The energy in the movement of those nuclei was simply being transformed to heat - just as rubbing your hands together will make your palms warm up. But the uranium fragments rubbed against resting metal at immense speed, due to the multiplication by the immense value of c2 (the square of the speed of light).

They soon were travelling at several million miles per hour. The metals inside the bomb begin to warm. They had started at near body temperature - 98.6 F or 37C - reached water's boiling point - 100 C - then that of lead - 560 C. But the generations of chain reaction doubling had gone on, as yet more uranium atoms had been splitting. It reached several million degrees - the temperature of the centre of the sun - and kept rising.

The heat went through the steel tamping around the uranium, and through what had been the several-thousand-pound casing of the bomb. Then it paused. It started pushing X-rays out of itself. The explosion hovered; the fragments trying to cool down. Then, after perhaps 1/10,000th of a second, when the X-ray spraying was over, the heat ball resumed its outward spread.

An object resembling a giant sun fills several hundred times more of the sky than earth's sun. It burns at full power for about half a second, then begins to fade, taking two or three seconds to empty itself, spraying heat energy outward. Fires begin, seemingly instantaneously; skin explodes off, hanging in great sheets from the bodies of everyone below. The first of the tens of thousands of deaths in Hiroshima begin.

The heat accelerates the air to speeds several times faster than any hurricane - so fast it outruns any sound its immense force might make. There is a second air pulse, a little slower; after that the atmosphere sloshes back, to fill up the gap. This briefly lowers the air density to virtually zero. Far enough from the blast, life forms that have survived will begin to explode outward, having been exposed to the vacuum of outer space.

A small amount of the heat remains, hovering quite close to where the fuses and antennae and cordite had been. In a few seconds it begins to rise. It swells as it goes, and at sufficient height it spreads out. As that great mushroom cloud appears, E=mc2's first work on planet earth is done.

 E=mc2: A Biography of the World's Most Famous Equation, by David Bodanis, is published by Macmillan (£14.99).

fields.headline: Obituary: Robin Skynner
fields.standfirst: A pioneer of family therapy whose books - including one written with John Cleese - helped to make psychology more accessible to lay readers
fields.trailText: A pioneer of family therapy whose books - including one written with John Cleese - helped to make psychology more accessible to lay readers.
fields.body:
As a doctor, psychiatrist, psychotherapist and author, Robin Skynner, who has died aged 78, was a 20th century mental health pioneer. He contributed to major changes in clinical practice and professional training, and leaves a legacy in the practice of family, marital and group therapy, and through books like Families And How To Survive Them, which made psychology accessible to lay readers, and put analytic insights on to high street bookshop shelves.

Skynner's mother, he recalled, worried whether he would end up a genius or a lunatic. With hindsight he realised that, lacking the resources for the first option, he spent much of his life trying to avoid the second. He ultimately compromised by entering a mental hospital through the staff entrance.

The oldest of five sons born in Charlestown in Cornwall, Skynner's father had a family business mining and shipping china clay and his mother was a local fisherman's daughter. Educated at St Austell County School and Blundells School in Tiverton, in 1939, he volunteered for the Royal Air Force. He was commissioned and qualified as a pilot and a navigator. He spent 30 months training pilots in Britain and Canada and then flew Mosquito fighter-bombers on low-level raids.

Post-war, he qualified in medicine at University College Hospital, London, and in psychiatry at the Maudsley Hospital. There he specialised in child psychiatry. He became a consultant at Woodberry Down Child Guidance Unit and the Queen Elizabeth Hospital for Children, serving north-east London and the East End, and had a major influence introducing family therapy to Britain. He was made a member of the Royal College of Psychiatrists on its formation and was later elected a fellow.

He left child guidance in 1970 to become senior tutor in psychotherapy at the Institute of Psychiatry and the Bethlem Royal and Maudsley hospitals. There he remained until he retired from university and National Health Service teaching in 1982.

While at the Maudsley he met SH Foulkes, a psychoanalyst who had come from Germany in the 1930s and who had developed "group analysis", a group approach to the treatment of war neuroses. Skynner was an early member of the Group Analytic Society and, with Foulkes and others went on to establish the Group Analytic Practice which provided him with a professional home for the next 30 years. Here they developed individual, group, family and marital therapies. The practice continues to flourish.

In the 1960s they were in demand as trainers and the introductory course Skynner established led to the formation of the Institute of Group Analysis, which offers clinical training and a qualification in psychotherapy and is the main training centre for group therapy in Britain. The approach has had a major influence on psychotherapy in Europe and beyond.

In the 1970s Skynner brought together at the practice another network to staff a training programme which grew into the Institute of Family Therapy. The approach, based on systemic and structural principles, informs most psychiatric services for children and adolescents in Britain, and many adult services. Skynner was its first chairman, contributed to the later development of the Association for Family Therapy and became a regular contributor to its Journal Of Family Therapy.

Until her death in 1987 he had a highly constructive working relationship with his late wife Prudence in a partnership that linked group analysis and family therapy. They provided the early leadership of the courses for the Institute of Family Therapy; helped establish credibility for co-therapy with couples and families; and pioneered the development of therapy groups for couples that included groups for bishops of the Church of England and their wives. In 1978 the American Association of Marriage and Family Therapy awarded them distinguished affiliate membership and 12 years later St George's Hospital's family therapy unit was named in honour of Prudence.

His first two books, One Flesh, Separate Persons: Principles Of Family and Marital Psychotherapy (1976) and Families And How To Survive Them (1983) have been continuously in print. The latter, co-written with John Cleese, has sold some 353,000 copies in English editions and has been translated into 10 other languages. The clinical work on which it is based is available in two edited collections, Explorations With Families: Group Analysis And Family Therapy (1986) and Institutes And How To Survive Them: Mental Health Training And Consultation (Methuen 1989).

In the group analytic approach, as he describes it, the therapist exposes himself to the dynamics of those he is treating, remains closely attentive to his own responses and emotions and passes this back as information about himself in a careful and considered way. Skynner had a rare capacity to compose himself in the presence of others' emotions and to master the terms of their predicament in ways that were often very practical. He belonged in the tradition of the Cornish miners who designed and built London's underground, but this capacity for dealing with things below the ground was applied to human dilemmas.

His inquiry was focused by his struggle to deal with the confusion and distress of his own upbringing and he remained profoundly interested in the life of the family. "It has enormous creative potential including that of life itself," he observed, "and it is not surprising that, when it becomes disordered, it possesses an equal potential for terrible destruction."

These destructive forces, he believed, led to and derived from a fragmentation of consciousness complicated by the need to deny the underlying divisions. Denied problems were then transmitted across generations. He believed that his creativity as a clinician arose out of these fundamental concepts, but also derived from his native sense of curiosity; his commitment to work under pressure with needy people; and his consistent interest in health as well as illness.

He was a spiritual man, enriched by a long association with the Gurdjieff Society, and his experience of meditation lent a special quality to his attentiveness with people. He had bearing of authority and a strong, containing physical presence. During his early training he had been influenced by a group of philosophers, including Bertrand Russell, whose ideas influenced his own conceptual clarity and his publications introduce many original concepts to the field.

His co-author John Cleese wrote after Skynner's death that he had never met a man who knew so much about people. "He had a wonderfully unorthodox yet systematic mind: what was so special about him was that he never allowed himself to get stuck in theory as he was continually questioning it in the light of his own experience."

Some of the things Skynner said about Foulkes when he celebrated his colleague's life could well be said of Skynner himself. Foulkes, he had said, had an open, curious questioning attitude, always stepping back to examine the ground that he himself had just been standing on, and by that example aroused others to do the same. Foulkes and Skynner took everything seriously, yet took nothing too seriously.

For his last 12 years Skynner enjoyed a relationship with Welsh landscape painter Josh Partridge, who provided inspired care after he suffered a serious stroke in 1993 following the publication of his last book, Life And How To Survive It (1993), also written with John Cleese.

He struggled courageously against residual paralysis and his first speaking engagement after the stroke was the Jonathan Swift Founder's Day Lecture at St Patrick's Hospital Dublin in 1994. Skynner was a big man with an imposing presence. With his gait impaired by the stroke, and his long walking stick, he cut a remarkable figure. He travelled by himself and returned, elated, to report that his host, Anthony Clare, thanked him not only for the content of his lecture but for demonstrating to the audience by his spirit and bearing that there was no reason to fear old age.

This was only the beginning. He went on to travel and lecture in many parts of the world over the next few years. With advancing infirmity he required increasing levels of care, but despite the indignities of his condition he never lost this spirit and he continued to inspire extraordinary devotion among all who looked after him - carers, friends and family. "Simply by his presence, he taught us something about enjoyment of life, of learning," he had said of Foulkes, "of learning with each other." It was just as true of Robin Skynner.

He is survived by his son David, daughter Rosie, and four grandchildren.

fields.headline: Hack in the box
fields.standfirst: John Mullan on the life of Sir Richard Steele, father of journalism
fields.trailText: John Mullan on the life of Sir Richard Steele, father of journalism.
fields.body:
Alas, poor Dick! Work on levelling the floor of St Peter's Church, Carmarthen, has just turned up the skull of the Irish-born 18th-century author, Sir Richard Steele. It was found in a Victorian lead casket, inscribed with his name. It was first uncovered during excavations in the 1870s, and after it was reburied in the crypt no record of the site was kept. Its rediscovery tells us not so much of the indignity of being disinterred, as of having been forgotten in the first place.

For if any single person invented modern journalism, it was Steele. He wrote almost all of the Tatler, published thrice weekly from 1709 to 1711. Started as a newspaper to feed the arguments of "coffee-house politicians", it soon became a compendium of gossip, reviews, fashionable satire and energetic moralism.

He followed it up with the even more successful daily, the Spectator, which he wrote with his former schoolfriend Joseph Addison. Addison provided the erudition and gravitas; Steele, a true Grub Street man, contributed the swift stylistic verve.

A "Weekly Historian", he plotted the ways of fashion ("the arbiter, and rule of right") and was the first author to make an art of writing to deadlines. He should be the secular patron saint of hacks, for he not only discovered the commercial possibilities of periodicals, he also imbued them with cultural respectability. He sold copy, and he managed to make himself a public moralist. Yet this witty, gregarious writer has slipped into something close to oblivion. He can be found in academic libraries, but not in bookshops. While every significant figure of English literature seems to have a biography written about him or her every few years, the last biography of Steele was published in 1889.

Maybe his misfortune was to stand for values for which his contemporaries were grateful, but posterity found insufficiently colourful. As a young man he had been a soldier, fighting the French and living a dissipated life. He had even mortally wounded a fellow officer in a duel (campaigning against the fashion for duelling became one of his obsessions as a journalist). His life should be rich material for a biographer. As well as his struggles to make a living as a writer he was an MP, and often at the heart of the political controversies of his age. His knighthood (following a pattern that is still honoured) was given for his services as a political pamphleteer rather than his achievements as an anatomist of his age.

He was also a playwright and manager of the Drury Lane theatre, though his plays, admired by contemporaries, were soon to seem too moral to be interesting. Contemporaries sometimes laughed at the gap between his enthusiasm for good behaviour and his private conviviality - what Dr Johnson called his liking for "the lighter vices". But his early "irregularities", as he called them, are what made him a promoter of urbane virtue, a man who used journalism to shape his society.

His journalistic essays, however, have the vividness of satire rather than the weight of piety. What he condemned, he mocked, and many of his targets (the views of Tories, the behaviour of opera singers) are as satisfying now as they must have seemed when his comic portraits were first being perused, and probably read out loud, in White's Chocolate House. Steele is usually half-attracted to and half-appalled by the modern London he anatomises. This restless "Town" is a place where "Gamesters, Banterers, Biters, Swearers, and Twenty new-born Insects more, are, in their several Species, the modern Men of Wit". And modern is what Steele accepted he must be.

Many a contemporary columnist could learn something from him of combining opinions with irony. Even while he made fun of the vanities of luxury-loving Londoners, he mocked himself for assuming a "fantastical Dignity" as "Censor of Great Britain". He was out to turn his cul ture against the alluring rakishness of the Restoration. He even celebrated domestic affections. His unguarded, funny letters to his second wife, Mary Scurlock ("Prue"), also unpublished since the 19th century, make a picture of a marriage that undoes preconceptions about the formality or sexism of marriages in that distant past.

Indeed, even Steele the moralist was not such an archaic or unlikeable character. Some of the bourgeois values that he spread are (dare one say it?) dear to the hearts of many a Guardian reader. Probably his greatest influence was on sexual mores. A good deal of his wry commentaries on modern life were designed to illustrate that "the great source of our wrong pursuits is the impertinent manner in which we treat women". Theatre-goers and readers of fiction might like rakes, but they were the enemies of civilised life. It is odd that his satirical vignettes of sexual double standards have not been rediscovered by modern readers (or publishers).

The discovery of the skull has an extra piquancy. Because Steele's professional life was given up to those two low but fascinating employments, journalism and politics, he breathed London air. His best writing is completely urban, as well as urbane. The index to the standard edition of the Tatler has seven pages of references to places in London: the taverns and coffee-houses where he met the "characters" that fill his essays; the alleys and unexpected byways that took him to the heart of a commercial metropolis.

Yet his skull has been found in a small church in west Wales because, encumbered by debt, he had had to flee the expensive life of the metropolis. He went to live on the small estate that he had inherited from his adored wife, who had died during her fifth pregnancy. In the 18th century, Wales was where you could go to spend no money and avoid your creditors. Like his Grub Street contemporary, Richard Savage, who travelled to Wales when all his efforts at living from the pen failed, Steele's was a defeated retreat. Even before his death, he was fading from the attention of readers. His fate could stand as a lesson to authors hungry for fame: journalism might not be a good long-term prospect.

webTitle: Freeserve has laid out plans to move into internet television

fields.headline: Freeserve signs up with Bush Internet and ONnet
fields.standfirst: Freeserve's profits continue to slide
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Freeserve has laid out plans to move into internet television by signing up with Bush Internet and ONdigital's ONnet. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Freeserve has laid out plans to move into internet television by signing up with Bush Internet and ONdigital's ONnet.

The Freeserve portal has been reformatted for clearer TV viewing and will begin to be rolled out from mid-October.

Freeserve content and services will be pre-set on Bush TVs (£169.99) and set-top boxes (£79.99) sold through Dixon Group stores and supermarkets, and on the ONnet home page.

Analysts have welcomed the move as a positive strategy, but see it as just the start of what Freeserve has to do to make inroads into the interactive TV market.

It is still early days for Bush Internet, which has managed to sell about 200,000 boxes, but is about to discover aggressive competitors in its nascent market.

The ONnet partnership brings access to a potential audience of only 770,000 subscribers, with limited modem speeds and possible problems with handling Freeserve content.

Analysts are slightly disappointed by subscriber numbers - about 100,000 short of forecasts - but are encouraged by portal usage, with 186.2m page impressions in August. The total number of subscribers now stands at 2.1m.

The unmetered access offer has gained a strong following, with more than 250,000 subscribers now using the service. However, the results indicate that take-up of unmetered access has come from existing users rather than completely new Freeserve users.

fields.headline: The Amber Spyglass
fields.standfirst: An exclusive extract from the final book of Philip Pullman's His Dark Materials trilogy
fields.trailText: An exclusive extract from the final book of Philip Pullman's His Dark Materials trilogy
fields.body:
The polar bear king, Iorek Byrnison, has entered another world to seek out his friend Lee Scoresby...

And some time later, Iorek Byrnison stepped through the blackened undergrowth and the heat-split rocks at the edge of a burnt forest. The sun was glaring through the smoky haze, but he ignored the heat as he ignored the charcoal dust that blackened his white fur and the midges that searched in vain for skin to bite.

He had come a long way, and at one point in his journey, he had found himself swimming into that other world. He noticed the change in the taste of the water and the temperature of the air, but the air was still good to breathe, and the water still held his body up, so he swam on, and now he had left the sea behind, and he was nearly at the place Serafina Pekkala had described. He cast around, his black eyes gazing up at the sun-shimmering rocks of a wall of limestone crags above him.

Between the edge of the burnt forest and the mountains, a rocky slope of heavy boulders and scree was littered with scorched and twisted metal: girders and struts that had belonged to some complex machine. Iorek Byrnison looked at them as a smith as well as a warrior, but there was nothing in these fragments he could use. He scored a line with a mighty claw along a strut less damaged than most, and feeling a flimsiness in the quality of the metal, turned away at once and scanned the mountain wall again.

Then he saw what he was looking for: a narrow gully leading back between jagged walls, and at the entrance, a large low boulder.

He clambered steadily towards it. Beneath his huge feet, dry bones snapped loudly in the stillness, because many men had died here, to be picked clean by coyotes and vultures and lesser creatures; but the great bear ignored them and stepped up carefully towards the rock. The going was loose and he was heavy, and more than once the scree shifted under his feet and carried him down again in a scramble of dust and gravel. But as soon as he slid down he began to move up once more, relentlessly, patiently, until he reached the rock itself, where the footing was firmer.

The boulder was pitted and chipped with bullet-marks. Everything the witch had told him was true. And in confirmation, a little Arctic flower, a purple saxifrage, blossomed improbably where the witch had planted it as a signal in a cranny of the rock.

Iorek Byrnison moved around to the upper side. It was a good shelter from an enemy below, but not good enough; for among the hail of bullets that had chipped fragments off the rock had been a few that had found their target, and that lay where they had come to rest, in the body of the man lying stiff in the shadow.

He was a body, still, and not a skeleton, because the witch had laid a spell to preserve him from corruption. Iorek could see the face of his old comrade drawn and tight with the pain of his wounds, and see the jagged holes in his garments where the bullets had entered. The witch's spell did not cover the blood that must have spilled, and insects and the sun and the wind had dispersed it completely. Lee Scoresby looked not asleep, nor at peace; he looked as if he had died in battle; but he looked as if he knew that his fight had been successful.

And because the Texan aeronaut was one of the very few humans Iorek had ever esteemed, he accepted the man's last gift to him. With deft movements of his claws, he ripped aside the dead man's clothes, opened the body with one slash, and began to feast on the flesh and blood of his old friend. It was his first meal for days, and he was hungry.

But a complex web of thoughts was weaving itself in the bear king's mind, with more strands in it than hunger and satisfaction. There was the memory of the little girl Lyra, whom he had named Silvertongue, and whom he had last seen crossing the fragile snow-bridge across a crevasse in his own island of Svalbard. Then there was the agitation among the witches, the rumours of pacts and alliances and war; and then there was the surpassingly strange fact of this new world itself, and the witch's insistence that there were many more such worlds, and that the fate of them all hung somehow on the fate of the child.

And then there was the melting of the ice. He and his people lived on the ice; ice was their home; ice was their citadel. Since the vast disturbances in the Arctic, the ice had begun to disappear, and Iorek knew that he had to find an ice-bound fastness for his kin, or they would perish. Lee had told him that there were mountains in the south so high that even his balloon could not fly over them, and they were crowned with snow and ice all year round. Exploring those mountains was his next task.

But for now, something simpler possessed his heart, something bright and hard and unshakeable: vengeance. Lee Scoresby, who had rescued Iorek from danger in his balloon and fought beside him in the Arctic of his own world, had died. Iorek would avenge him. The good man's flesh and bone would both nourish him and keep him restless until blood was spilled enough to still his heart. The sun was setting as Iorek finished his meal, and the air was cooling down. After gathering the remaining fragments into a single heap, the bear lifted the flower in his mouth and dropped it in the centre of them, as humans liked to do. The witch's spell was broken now; the rest of Lee's body was free to all who came. Soon it would be nourishing a dozen different kinds of life.

Then Iorek set off down the slope towards the sea again, towards the south.

fields.headline: Academy introduces new cartoon Oscar
fields.trailText: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science has announced the creation of a new Oscar to be presented to what is judged the year's best animated feature film
fields.body:
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science has announced the creation of a new Oscar to be presented to what is judged the year's best animated feature film. The statuette will make its debut at the 2001 Oscar ceremony and will be the first new Academy category in 20 years (Make-up, in 1981, was the last).

The news is an important step in the cartoon form's long march towards legitimacy. Animated features have long been eligible for the Best Picture Oscar, but so far none have won. While Walt Disney was presented with a jokey honorary award for his 1937 feature Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (one regular Oscar and seven smaller ones), the Academy has traditionally been sniffy when it comes to honouring cartoons. Beauty and the Beast was the last animation to be nominated for the Best Picture award back in 1992.

Even the new category has a tentative, testing-the-waters quality to it. Academy president Robert Rehme explained that the award would only be given when eight or more eligible animated features are released. He admitted that there might be some years when the Oscar would lie dormant. Variety quotes an Academy spokesperson as admitting that: "... animators have been lobbying for inclusion in the Oscar race for years. The past three years in particular have consisted of weighing the pros against the cons. It has been a long, drawn-out process and finally the board has managed to iron out a feasible solution."

Inevitably the new award is being interpreted as an important acknowledgment of the growing importance of animation, recently revolutionalised by the silicon sorcery of films such as Toy Story and A Bug's Life. The Oscar is open to the full spectrum of the animator's art - from cell animation, to computer graphics to the stop-motion style most recently seen in Chicken Run.
