webTitle: Channel 4 rules out digital children's channel

fields.headline: Channel 4 rules out digital children's channel
fields.trailText: 10am: Channel 4's deputy director of programmes, Karen Brown, has ruled out the creation of a dedicated digital children's channel, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Channel 4's deputy director of programmes, Karen Brown, has ruled out the creation of a dedicated digital children's channel.

Ms Brown is giving up many of her commissioning responsibilities to concentrate on 4Learning, which will concentrate the channel's schools programming units, Channel 4 schools, Channel 4 Learning and the programme support unit, in an initiative costing the broadcaster £250m over five years.

Channel 4 is launching a range of interactive education initiatives, including the Black and Asian History Map, a web-based project examining the way black and asian culture has shaped British history. It launches on October 1.

But Ms Brown told MediaGuardian that Channel 4 would not be launching a separate digital channel. "There will be new channels in every sense but one - there will be no schedules. In a converged world there will be converged services," she said.

Her comments contradict recent speculation that Channel 4 was planning to spin off T4, its programming strand aimed at a teen audience, into a digital channel.

BBC director general Greg Dyke has confirmed that the BBC is planning new children's digital services, but Ms Brown said that the corporation had "retreated" from plans to create a discrete children's channel.

She said the bulk of 4Learning's investment would continue to be in commissioning traditional programming, but addedthat the development of interactive services would have an impact on the way Channel 4 commissioned programmes.

"In the longer term, content will be commissioned directly from interactive services, and we are moving towards developing broadcast programmes from interactive content," she added.

fields.headline: Campaign round-up
fields.trailText: Latest news from trade title Campaign.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is putting its £40m centralised media account out to pitch as part of a wide-ranging rethink that will also see the Schweppes and Dr Pepper creative accounts put up for review.

fields.headline: Press Gazette round-up
fields.trailText: The latest news from Press Gazette.
fields.body:
Press Gazette leads on an eleventh-hour concession by the BBC not to lift stories from the Evening Star, Ipswich. The paper's lawyers threatened the BBC with a breach of copyright lawsuit after a splash on the settlement of a WPC's claims of sex discrimination was put out on Ceefax without the paper being credited. The BBC backed down with a commitment not to infringe copyright minutes before the deadline expired.

The paper also reports on what it calls the "Battle to save Nine O'clock News" in the fallout from last week's News at Ten settlement. Press Gazette quotes shadow media secretary Peter Ainsworth, who says the BBC's plans to press ahead with moving its news to ten o'clock are "unsustainable".

In the wake of a report last week on sales figure deception at the Birmingham Post, the paper's former editor calls for the ABC system to be scrapped in favour of a system which would include scrutiny of sales figures by inspectors.

And Sunday People editor Neil Wallis has promised to continue to fight an injunction by the Ministry of Defence, banning the paper from reporting on the alleged murder of a civilian in Northern Ireland by a secret British Army unit.

fields.headline: Broadcast round-up
fields.trailText: The latest news from trade title Broadcast.
fields.body:
BBC director general Greg Dyke is set to give controller of specialist factual Glenwyn Benson and controller of children's Nigel Pickard responsibility for commissioning, as well as production, in their programming areas. Benson and Pickard will order shows from both in-house programme-makers - whom they also line-manage - and independent producers. But as with the four genre controllers already appointed to BBC director of television Mark Thompson's commissioning team, they will have to get a 'double tick' from channel controllers for commissions.

Media secretary Chris Smith has told a Labour Party Conference fringe meeting that broadcasters will not be governed solely by competition law under the proposed single regulator, but will remain subject to sector-specific regulations.

Carlton Television has signed a factual programming co-production deal with Washington Post-owned Newsweek Productions. The US-based outfit will be headed by former BBC head of TV news Richard Clemmow and develop factual shows for the US and international markets.

Canadian broadcaster/producer Alliance Atlantis Communications is trying to put together a deal to save cash-strapped UK factual specialist Cafe Productions. The two companies have two weeks to come up with a plan that satisfies Cafe's creditors and prevents the indie's closure.

fields.headline: GEO Interactive cheered by first-half results
fields.trailText: 10.15am: GEO Interactive, the Israeli internet technology company, has moved into the black after posting encouraging first-half results. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
GEO Interactive, the Israeli internet technology company, has taken its management by surprise with first-half results that took the company into the black.

GEO said that its focus on wireless technology had paid dividends, turning a loss of $7.4m (£5.06m) last year into a net income of $3.9m (£2.6m) this time round. Company revenue soared from $0.3 (£0.2m) to $12.7m (£8.7m), boosted by agreements that included placing GEO's Emblaze chips into the next generation of Samsung mobile phones, allowing wireless video conferences.

GEO's chairman, Naftali Shani, said: "We continue to make excellent progress and are greatly encouraged by the results for the first six months of the year. We remain confident that GEO still holds a 12 to 18-month lead over any potential competition in streaming solutions for the wireless and telecom markets."

GEO is bullish about the potential of the internet video market, as shown by the £60m it invested in technology companies this year. Analysts say the company should capitalise on the growth of video content broadcasts over wireless networks. GEO's shares rose 3.6% to 1282p in early trading.

webTitle: A little pick-me-up for the consumer boom's outcasts

fields.headline: A little pick-me-up for the consumer boom's outcasts
fields.trailText: Sit outside one of the hypermarkets that ring Budapest, and you can watch a stream of shoppers rattling their carts through the automatic doors, or stopping for an ice cream as they emerge laden with goodies. It is possible to get almost anything you want in Hungary these days - exotic fruits that were unknown a few years back, cheeses from all over Europe, and a dazzling choice of foreign dishwashers, refrigerators and cookers. If you have enough money, that is. But a lot of people do not. A surgeon friend showed us his pay slip the other day. His high-stress job in a casualty department is worth just over $170 a month, so he works on Saturday nights as a disc jockey to support his wife and two-year-old son. Others are even less fortunate.
fields.body:
Sit outside one of the hypermarkets that ring Budapest, and you can watch a stream of shoppers rattling their carts through the automatic doors, or stopping for an ice cream as they emerge laden with goodies. It is possible to get almost anything you want in Hungary these days - exotic fruits that were unknown a few years back, cheeses from all over Europe, and a dazzling choice of foreign dishwashers, refrigerators and cookers. If you have enough money, that is. But a lot of people do not. A surgeon friend showed us his pay slip the other day. His high-stress job in a casualty department is worth just over $170 a month, so he works on Saturday nights as a disc jockey to support his wife and two-year-old son. Others are even less fortunate.

Budapest is enjoying a construction boom, and the government reported a sharp fall in unemployment last month. But there has been no obvious decline in the number of homeless people roaming the streets, and unemployment is sure to soar again this winter. So the annual lomtalanitás (collection of unwanted items), when people turn out their basements and dump the contents at the side of the street for the council to take away, is still a keenly awaited event. The day before the pick-up for their district people get up early to put their stuff on the pavement before going to work. Then there's almost a party atmosphere as neighbours sort through discarded beds, mattresses, wash-basins, toilet bowls and tyres in case there's something they need.

The Gypsies and scrap metal dealers are up early too. "Got the other one, dearie?" a Romany woman asks a man who is dumping a bedside table outside a block of flats. Another resident grabs a bed almost before its previous owner has put it down, carries it upstairs and re-emerges with a smaller one. The basement of our house in the southwestern district of Kelenföld hasn't been emptied for a decade, and the family descends on us at 7am to weed out the treasures of yesteryear, when you threw nothing remotely serviceable away in case there was a sudden shortage, or someone got married and needed to fix a bathroom or a kitchen in their new home.

One by one these dusty trophies emerge: a bent tandem bicycle frame, a chipped sink, a divan with faded green upholstery, a collection of old tyres from the family Trabant, which is still in service, powered by a Volkswagen engine. Under the eagle eye of my mother-in-law, Edit, who uses her veto several times because she can't bear to part with something, we lug the stuff up the stairs and across the grass of the little park to a growing pile of similar objects. The tandem doesn't stay there long. Three scrap dealers lurking at the edge of the pile pounce on it, and one of them takes it to a van. A second attacks the sink with a blunt object, to free the taps and metal piping attached to it. The third inspects a loo contributed by a neighbour.

On the whole it is all very polite and good-humoured. One of the scrap men actually asks if it's OK to remove a child's two-wheeler. But across the way an elderly resident bawls out a ponytailed hippie who tries to put a small wooden something or other on a second heap. "That's my pile," shouts the older man, arguing that the object contravenes regulations (the lomtalanitás does not include ordinary household refuse or debris from building sites). Ponytail slinks off, to return later with a larger wooden object that he deposits on our pile alongside some sticks contributed by an old woman from a house opposite.

Our basement cleaned out, we set off in the car, past 20 or 30 battered fridges neatly stacked on some waste ground. As we drive by, a tiny pick-up truck approaches with two more. People are always looking for a fridge that works: these will be cannibalised, and the better-looking ones sold. When we get home late in the afternoon the heap on our side of the park stretches for 25m along the street and 15m on to the grass. At its highest it rises a good 3m. A few latecomers are nosing gloomily around in case the professionals have left anything worth having. Their task seems pretty hopeless. But these outcasts of the consumer boom have learned to make even a forlorn hope go a long way.

fields.headline: The champion county of old
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: How many times have Yorkshire have won the County Championship? asks Johan Robertsson from Norway
fields.body:
How many times have Yorkshire have won the County Championship? asks Johan Robertsson from Norway

Since the Championship was properly constituted in 1890 Yorkshire have won it 29 times, more than any other county. That includes seven titles in the 1930s, and six in the '60s. They also shared the title once (in 1949). But, as any avid White Rose fan will tell you, they haven't won it since 1968, when Brian Close was captain. That was the last year of a hat-trick of titles, something which no county has achieved since - although Surrey will have a shot at it next year.

I've been told that William Rodger Playle of New Zealand holds a record for slow scoring. Can you tell me some more about him? asks Valerie

Bill Playle was a right-hand batsman from Auckland who toured England in 1958 with a New Zealand side that was largely outplayed in the Tests. He was only 20 at the time. NZ were bowled out five times for less than 100, left-arm spinner Tony Lock took 34 wickets at the startling average of 7.47, and England won the series 4-0: only rain in the final Test at The Oval prevented a probable clean sweep. Playle's long innings came in the third Test at Headingley, when he survived 194 minutes for 18 runs, including a spell of 63 minutes without adding to his score - it's one of Test cricket's slowest innings, although not quite a slow-scoring record. Apart from those five Tests, Playle only played in three more, against England at home in 1962-63, when he made his highest Test score of 65 at Wellington. He finished with 151 runs at an average of 10.06. He then moved to Perth, and played for Western Australia for three seasons. Don Cameron, Wisden Cricket Monthly's New Zealand correspondent, says: "At last sighting, 12 months ago, Bill Playle was alive and well in Sydney. He's been there for some years after leaving Perth."

Did all four Mohammad brothers ever score centuries in the same Test? asks Sheharyar Pervez

No, they didn't - actually they never all played in the same Test team. But all four of them scored Test hundreds: Wazir, the oldest, made two in 20 Tests (1952-60), Hanif 12 from 55 (1952-69), Mushtaq 10 from 57 (1958-79), and Sadiq five from 41 (1969-80). Later Shoaib Mohammad, Hanif's son, played 45 Tests and made seven hundreds. Three of the Mohammad brothers did play together in one Test, against New Zealand at Karachi in 1969-70 - it was Sadiq's first Test and Hanif's last (Mushtaq was the other one). The only other occasions when three brothers played in the same Test were both in the 19th century. At The Oval in 1880 WG, EM and GF Grace all played for England v Australia, and at Cape Town in 1891-92 Alec and George Hearne played for England while their brother Fred turned out for South Africa.

I was surprised that Michael Atherton played in a Championship match at the end of the season, when I thought all England's contracted players were being given time off. Is he no longer going on tour? asks Eddie Hewitt

The only players forcibly rested from the last few Championship games were those who were selected for both the one-day and Test legs of England's pre-Christmas tours. The team departed for Kenya today (Sept 28), and the management wanted the players to be given a chance of some time off. Atherton isn't in the one-day squad, so he was allowed to play for Lancashire. Michael Vaughan also played for Yorkshire.

When are England next touring Australia? I'd like to attend one of the Tests, preferably in Sydney, asks Richard Bailey

The next Ashes tour Down Under is scheduled for the winter of 2002-03. Exact dates won't be available until early in 2002, but recent Australian seasons have all featured a Test at Melbourne starting on Boxing Day, followed by the New Year Test at Sydney, usually beginning on Jan 2. For this winter's dates, click here.

I enjoyed Matthew Engel's recent article in Wisden Cricket Monthly comparing the "Cardusian" and "Swantonian" styles of cricket writing. Unfortunately, I have lost the relevant copy of WCM. Can I obtain another copy, or is the article available on the internet? asks Paul Coupar

That article was in the April 2000 edition of WCM, which is still available from our Back Issues Dept (send a cheque for £2.90 to Wisden Cricket Magazines Ltd, 25 Down Road, Merrow, Guildford, Surrey GU1 2PY). To find the article on the net, click here.

Was Glamorgan's total of 718 for 3 against Sussex at Colwyn Bay a record for the County Championship? And what's the first-class record? asks Chris

Although it was a Glamorgan record, it didn't break the Championship best, which was set in 1896 by Yorkshire - 887 against Warwickshire at Edgbaston. Bobby Peel, who was better known as a left-arm spinner, hit 210 not out and there were three other hundreds, including 166 for Lord Hawke at No. 9. The Test record is Sri Lanka's 952 for 6 dec v India at the Saravanamuttu Stadium in Colombo in 1997-98. And the overall first-class record is 1107, by Victoria against New South Wales in a Sheffield Shield match at Melbourne in 1926-27.

I have recently heard about a national cricket writers' club. I have recently had some of my cricket writing published, and am keen to continue as a freelancer. Do you know if I might be eligible to apply for membership? asks Matthew Ryder-Whish

Full members of the Cricket Writers Club are supposed to earn their living primarily by writing or broadcasting about cricket, so I'm not sure that you would qualify for that. But the club does have associate membership. For full details, write to Derek Hodgson, the club secretary, at derekhodgson@compuserve.com.

Who were nicknamed "Tugga" and "Lager"? says Maurice Dengate

"Tugga" is an easy one: it's Steve Waugh, the Australian captain (tug of war, geddit?). "Lager" was the nickname of Brian Hardie, the right-hand batsman who had a long and successful career - usually as Graham Gooch's opening partner - with Essex (1973-90) after a few matches for his native Scotland. Hardie, who's now 50 and the master in charge of cricket at Brentwood School in Essex, scored 18,103 runs in first-class matches at an average of 34.22, with 27 centuries. And why "Lager"? Apparently his stock answer, when asked if he wanted a drink, was "Mine's a lager," which was more distinctive then than it is now.

fields.bodyText: How many times have Yorkshire have won the County Championship? asks Johan Robertsson from Norway Since the Championship was properly constituted in 1890 Yorkshire have won it 29 times, more than any other county. That includes seven titles in the 1930s, and six in the '60s. They also shared the title once (in 1949). But, as any avid White Rose fan will tell you, they haven't won it since 1968, when Brian Close was captain. That was the last year of a hat-trick of titles, something which no county has achieved since - although Surrey will have a shot at it next year. I've been told that William Rodger Playle of New Zealand holds a record for slow scoring. Can you tell me some more about him? asks Valerie Bill Playle was a right-hand batsman from Auckland who toured England in 1958 with a New Zealand side that was largely outplayed in the Tests. He was only 20 at the time. NZ were bowled out five times for less than 100, left-arm spinner Tony Lock took 34 wickets at the startling average of 7.47, and England won the series 4-0: only rain in the final Test at The Oval prevented a probable clean sweep. Playle's long innings came in the third Test at Headingley, when he survived 194 minutes for 18 runs, including a spell of 63 minutes without adding to his score - it's one of Test cricket's slowest innings, although not quite a slow-scoring record. Apart from those five Tests, Playle only played in three more, against England at home in 1962-63, when he made his highest Test score of 65 at Wellington. He finished with 151 runs at an average of 10.06. He then moved to Perth, and played for Western Australia for three seasons. Don Cameron, Wisden Cricket Monthly's New Zealand correspondent, says: "At last sighting, 12 months ago, Bill Playle was alive and well in Sydney. He's been there for some years after leaving Perth." Did all four Mohammad brothers ever score centuries in the same Test? asks Sheharyar Pervez No, they didn't - actually they never all played in the same Test team. But all four of them scored Test hundreds: Wazir, the oldest, made two in 20 Tests (1952-60), Hanif 12 from 55 (1952-69), Mushtaq 10 from 57 (1958-79), and Sadiq five from 41 (1969-80). Later Shoaib Mohammad, Hanif's son, played 45 Tests and made seven hundreds. Three of the Mohammad brothers did play together in one Test, against New Zealand at Karachi in 1969-70 - it was Sadiq's first Test and Hanif's last (Mushtaq was the other one). The only other occasions when three brothers played in the same Test were both in the 19th century. At The Oval in 1880 WG, EM and GF Grace all played for England v Australia, and at Cape Town in 1891-92 Alec and George Hearne played for England while their brother Fred turned out for South Africa. Is he no longer going on tour? asks Eddie Hewitt The only players forcibly rested from the last few Championship games were those who were selected for both the one-day and Test legs of England's pre-Christmas tours. webTitle: Media Maiden continues strong profit trend

fields.headline: Media Maiden continues strong profit trend
fields.trailText: Outdoor advertiser Media Maiden continues to post record sales and profits for 2000, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
UK outdoor advertising company Media Maiden has continued its strong trading performance into the third quarter of 2000.

Maiden, which had record sales and profits for the first half of the year, said today it estimated 26% growth in revenues for the nine months to September.

This strong performance is expected to continue unitl the end of 2000, with final quarter bookings already equal to 90% of total revenue achieved in the same period last year.

The group reported pre-tax profits of £5.2m in the six months to June 30, from a loss of £0.9m in the comparative period last year, on sales up 30% to £38m.

Maiden said it invested £14m in the first half of 2000, of which £2.3m was on capital expenditure and £11.7m on acquisitions.

fields.headline: CharlotteStreet to relaunch targeting Femail readers
fields.trailText: 8.30amCharlotteStreet, Associated New Media's ailing women's portal, is to be dismantled and relaunched as femail.co.uk later this year, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
CharlotteStreet, Associated New Media's ailing women's portal, is to be dismantled and relaunched as femail.co.uk later this year.

The announcement puts an end to speculation that the site would be rechristened you.co.uk, based on the Mail on Sunday's You magazine.

The new site site will target the 'Femail woman', readers of the Daily Mail's well-established women's supplement aged 30 to 50.

Editorial director Ted Verity said: "After a lot of external research, the focus groups reported overwhelmingly in favour of the Femail brand, because they felt comfortable with it - they immediately made the connection with the Mail and it gave them an assurance of quality."

Femail.co.uk will not be a straight replication of the printed product. There will be original content as well as highlights and columnists from Associated's other print titles, You, the Mail on Sunday, Evening Standard and Metro. "An independent editorial entity but part of the family so to speak", added Mr Verity.

Charlotte Street's core staff, including editor Maria Trkulja, will stay on.

The revamped site promises more interactive tools and the idea of "community" will remain one of the site's key propositions. "The main lesson that we've learned is that community works," Mr Verity added.

The chatroom and message boards will retain the CharlotteStreet brand. Cross-platform development, however, is on hold: "The main thing," Mr Verity added, "is to get a website up and running that we're proud of."

CharlotteStreet was launched in October 1999 backed by £10m. At the time, it was aiming at 25 to 50-year-old women 'in a hurrry' but insiders later admitted it was all "guesswork". Its monthly user figures are thought to be well below its rivals, Handbag, Beme and iCircle who all claim around 200,000.

webTitle: McCann Erickson launches Norwich Union campaign

fields.headline: McCann Erickson unveils Norwich Union TV and poster campaign
fields.trailText: 9.15am: McCann Erickson is launching a multimillion pound TV and poster campaign for Norwich Union - its first branding advertising since its merger with CGU earlier this year.By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
McCann Erickson is launching a multimillion pound TV and poster campaign for Norwich Union - its first branding advertising since its merger with CGU earlier this year.

The campaign incorporates the line "Together we're stronger" and aims to reinforce the importance of choosing the right financial services provider.

A series of three 40-second TV ads break next week, each covering a different product area. "Doctor" is for investments, "Couples" for pensions and "Love what you have" for general insurance.

Four black and white poster executions carry through the theme of feeling good today knowing that your future is secure.

The CGU brand will no longer be advertised. From next week, all unit trusts, pensions and life policies will be rebranded Norwich Union.

Ben Langdon, chairman and CEO of McCann London, said: "These ads highlight a universal truth, that although people are diverse, we all share the desire to make plans for loved ones."

The ads were written by Jerry Green and art directed by Roger Ackerman.

fields.headline: United execs braced for Granada to move in
fields.trailText: 8.30am: United News & Media insiders are preparing for Granada to take over management of the company's ITV businesses, after the merger deal was given the go-ahead by shareholders yesterday. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
United News & Media insiders are preparing for Granada Media to officially take over management of the company's ITV businesses next Wednesday (October 4), after the merger deal was given the go-ahead by the two companies' shareholders yesterday.

The fate of several senior United broadcasting and production executives may be announced shortly after that, according to United sources. As part of the £1.75bn agreed takeover, Granada has acquired the Anglia, Meridian and HTV ITV franchises, along with airtime sales house TSMS, United Productions and programme distribution arm Itel.

Malcolm Wall, chief executive of United Broadcasting & Entertainment (UBE), the United division that housed its ITV interests, is going with the businesses and has said he will work to integrate them into Granada.

Mr Wall has already ruled himself out as a candidate for the vacant ITV chief executive's post, saying he wanted to continue working in a business that involved some mergers and acquisitions activity.

There has also been speculation about the future of United Productions chief executive John Willis. Granada Media chairman Charles Allen, speaking at the Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival last month, said he wanted to keep United Productions together as a single programme-making entity and was keen to talk to Mr Willis.

One United executive who has been tipped for a role within Granada Media is Jim Raven, managing director of United Sport and UBE director of news. Raven is credited with building up United's sports rights and production business - an area where Granada does not have a significant presence - up from scratch in the past couple of years.

fields.headline: Granada shares collapse
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Shares in Granada Media suffered another drubbing yesterday after the ITV company warned that advertising revenues in the first half of next year would fall below this year's levels. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Shares in Granada Media suffered another drubbing yesterday after the ITV company warned that advertising revenues in the first half of next year would fall below this year's levels.

The shares slipped by 65p to 438p, which means almost 21% has been wiped from the value of the group in two days. The group's market capitalisation has fallen from £10bn at its peak last month to £6.5bn.

The collapse was badly timed for Granada: it now seems likely it may have to pay cash for the £1.75bn takeover of the ITV assets of United News & Media. Investors in United yesterday gave their overwhelming backing to the sale, which can be taken in cash instead of shares if the Granada Media share price is below 585p in mid-December.

A Granada trading statement said it had experienced "unprecedented" growth in advertising revenues of 11% during the first half of this year due to the Euro 2000 football championships and Rugby World Cup, which it would not match in 2001.

But a spokesman tried to play down the significance of the statement. "This is largely a timing issue. The nature of TV advertising means there will always be exceptional set-piece events which occur frequently but will never fit into a regular pattern."

Advertising growth in the second half of this year had settled back to what Granada Media described as "more normal levels" of 6%.

The note of caution from Granada Media compounded negative comments this week from investment bank Merrill Lynch, which downgraded its 2001 profit forecast for the company by 21% to £256m - largely owing to a weaker advertising market.

ITV, it noted, is under pressure from a declining share in an increasingly competitive market. The network has all but raised the white flag over its published targets for peak-time share this year of 38.5%. Another bank, ABN AMRO, was also downbeat on Granada Media's prospects.

In its defence, the company said the recent deal on News at Ten has left it with more advertising minutes at a time when it can charge premium rates and said ITV would also benefit from the impact of the Premier League in August.

Granada Media pulled down others in its wake. Carlton, its chief rival in the ITV market, was 32p lower at 548p while SMG, which owns the Scottish and Grampian franchises, was down 11.5p to 295p.

Shorn of its ITV assets, United's share price resisted the downward pressure, closing 32.5p higher at 744p.

United chief executive Lord Hollick, who had been cast as a loser in the battle over ITV, was clearly enjoying his day. "We sold very much in the knowledge that the good times were unlikely to last," he said. "It was already clear that the advertising market was beginning to turn down so we wanted to expedite the process as quickly as possible. Our shareholders are in the happy position of receiving value based on the highest price for ITV assets and struck at one of the high points of the marketplace."

The deal struck with Granada had been one-third cash and two-thirds in shares with the fall-back position of taking the entire proceeds in cash if it fell below 585p. The group intends to return £1.25bn to shareholders and invest the rest in information businesses. Granada Media raised £1.7bn in cash from its flotation in July, and insiders said it would have little problem paying United cash.

fields.headline: 'For three hours we held on for dear life'
fields.trailText: A British survivor, Michael Beaton, said: "There was no instruction to abandon ship at any point so people went up on deck and pulled lifebelts on, but weren't really sure what to do.
fields.body:
A British survivor, Michael Beaton, said: "There was no instruction to abandon ship at any point so people went up on deck and pulled lifebelts on, but weren't really sure what to do.

"The ship was slowly tipping over and people were thinking perhaps it had run aground on a sandbank but I don't think we were ever told. I think we were holed by a rock and floated on. There were a lot of people on the 'uphill' side of the ship as it were, wondering should we try to launch the lifeboats or wait for instructions from the crew.

"At a certain point we thought we needed to launch the lifeboats but at that point it was too late because the ship was tipping so far over that when they were released they didn't slide into the water. But we did actually unhook the lifeboats and I ended up on the upturned bottom of one.

"As the ship was finally going down, we were on the top side of the ship, I was trying to help push people upwards so they weren't [trapped] behind the railings.

"As it finally went down, I got hit on the head by some piece of the ship and I think perhaps trapped under one of the liferafts for about 15 seconds.

"I then climbed on the upturned bottom of one of the liferafts with 20 other people clinging on to the side.

"There were lots of small Greek boats trying to help people and pull people out of the water.

"A Greek guy had a lifejacket on, but let two other people swim over to him and cling on, so there were three people holding on to that lifejacket in that water for two hours and they survived."

Two young British women were among survivors rescued by helicopters from aircraft carrier HMS Invincible.

Speaking from Invincible, college friends Katrina Wallace and Nicola Gibson-Hosking spoke of their fight for survival as they clung to rocks for over three hours.

Ms Wallace, 25, from Hertfordshire, said: "I was on the ship and heard the crack when it hit the rock at about 10.30 at night.

"Luckily I found a lifeboat to get on in all this chaos of screaming people - as you would have seen on the Titanic, I guess.

"The lifeboat we were in had about 12 of us on at the time and there were people jumping into the sea.

"I was thinking we were safe in the lifeboat but we hit a rock in the middle of the sea, so we had to clamber on to this rock.

"The wind was hitting up and the waves were crashing on us, then the helicopter from HMS Invincible came and saved us.

"For three hours we held on for dear life, all terrified and cold and waiting for help. We could see boats and the island in the distance but there was nothing we could do."

Ms Gibson-Hosking, from Derby, said: "We were lucky to stay together because it was pretty mad and chaotic with everyone pushing.

"When the helicopter arrived we were starting to get really cold and tired and just worried in case another big wave came over and washed us off because they were coming over all the time.

"We just felt so, so lucky, seeing the news about the people who died.

"Some people jumped out of the boat in panic and I don't know what happened to them. Someone tried to pass a baby down from the ship and I don't know if they got away."

fields.headline: Channel 4 makes sound investment in music sourcing system
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Channel 4 has signed up to a new music sourcing system to save it time finding the right music for programmes, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has signed up to a new music sourcing system to save it time finding the right music for programmes.

The system, called Startle, gives producers, librarians and broadcasters direct access to over 70,000 tracks of production music that they can research, audition, download and license via the internet.

Instead of manually trawling through CD archives, Startle claims broadcasters could speed up the process by anything up to 20 times and make savings of up to £5,000 per producer per year. The system is aimed at companies making TV programmes, films, adverts or those adding sounds to websites or games.

While attention is focused on the global market for digital downloads of music, Startle claims the biggest difference will happen in the business to business market, which is currently worth £20m in the UK alone.

A Channel 4 spokesman said: "It cuts search time down to a minimum, which is so vital in the time-pressured environment in which we work. The service gives us increased choice and a better quality of music."

The Startle system is already used by a number of media firms including the BBC, Turner, TWI and IPC.

fields.headline: New editor at Harpers & Queen as Macpherson steps up
fields.trailText: 8am: Harpers & Queen editor Fiona Macpherson has been made editor-in-chief of the title, and will be replaced by Tatler deputy editor Lucy Yeomans, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Harpers & Queen editor Fiona Macpherson has been made editor-in-chief, and will move across to work on a new launch within the National Magazine Company's Affluent magazines group in the new year.

Harpers has also recruited Lucy Yeomans, deputy editor of Tatler, who will step into Macpherson's shoes. Currently on gardening leave for Conde Nast, she will join Harpers & Queen on October 25.

Duncan Edwards, deputy managing director of NatMags, said Ms Yeomans was "the best person for the job". He denied poaching her was a part of the company's strategy of taking its magazines upmarket to compete with Conde Nast. "We edit Harpers for Harpers," said Mr Edwards. "We've never particularly seen our titles as going head to head with theirs."

Harpers celebrates its 30th birthday on October 12 with a bumper issue.

webTitle: Murdoch's Music Choice in £50m brand building fundraiser

fields.headline: Murdoch's Music Choice in £50m brand building fundraiser
fields.standfirst:
Net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's Music Choice Europe yesterday announced it had raised £50m through a share placing which will value the business at almost £200m.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's Music Choice Europe yesterday announced it had raised £50m through a share placing which will value the business at almost £200m.

The company broadcasts audio services over digital television platforms, including Sky Digital in Britain and Stream in Italy, and is aiming to further develop online and mobile phone services.

The placing reduces the stake of BSkyB, Mr Murdoch's pay-TV business, from 48.9% to 38.4% of Music Choice.

The other large shareholders include music publishers Time Warner and Sony and mobile phone maker Motorola. Some £20m of the proceeds has been earmarked for marketing over the next four years to build the Music Choice brand. A similar amount will be used to develop technologies for interactive TV and webcasting. Simon Bazalgette, Music Choice's chief executive, said the cash would help the business into "potentially lucrative new markets such as broadband and mobile technology".

Music Choice has an existing 47 channels based on genres including dance, jazz, classical and country which are uninterrupted by advertising or DJs.

Around 5m people have access to the radio services in 17 countries.

The firm was founded in 1993; BSkyB bought into it two years ago. The shares were placed at 162p, and trading is scheduled to begin next Wednesday.

webTitle: Poor showing rubs off on catering and hotels group

fields.headline: Poor showing rubs off on catering and hotels group
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Granada Compass felt the pain of its offshoot, Granada Media, yesterday despite telling the City that its own plans were on track.
fields.body:
Granada Compass felt the pain of its offshoot, Granada Media, yesterday despite telling the City that its own plans were on track.

Shares in the catering and hotels group, which owns 80% of Granada Media, slumped to a new low of 595.5p before ending the session at 607p - more than 4% lower.

The fall its share price heaped further pressure on the company which has had a torrid time on the stock market since its formation in July to allow Granada to spin off its media interests.

Earlier this month the company's shares were only a little shy of 900p.

To address the decline in its share price, Granada Compass has admitted that it is considering selling off its hotels business, which includes the Le Meridien, Posthouse and Heritage chains. An announcement on the sale is expected later in the year, with Accor of France seen as the most likely bidder.

In a statement yesterday, Granada Compass said the hotels had achieved "strong summer trading".

The group said it was pleased to have merged the two management teams of Sutcliffe, Granada's former catering arm, and Compass, with out any disruption to client relationships. Investors want the company to focus on this business, which it regards as having potential for faster growth than hotels.

Granada Compass also revealed it had taken a 49% stake in Levy Restaurants, a US company which provides catering to sports arenas and convention centres.

webTitle: Cable trailblazer cements News Corp link

fields.headline: Cable trailblazer cements News Corp link
fields.standfirst:
Entwined shareholdings may be springboard for acquisition of satellite business

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: News Corp, the sprawling media empire run by Rupert Murdoch, yesterday cemented its link with John Malone, a trailblazer of the US cable industry often characterised as one of the world's most powerful media figures.
fields.body:
News Corp, the sprawling media empire run by Rupert Murdoch, yesterday cemented its link with John Malone, a trailblazer of the US cable industry often characterised as one of the world's most powerful media figures.

The company announced a series of transactions which will lift Mr Malone's stake in News Corp from 7% to 18%, underlining his status as the second largest shareholder in the business. The Murdoch family has a 30% stake in the media concern, which owns assets from filmmaker 20th Century Fox to the Times newspaper and pay-television business BSkyB.

Mr Malone has also agreed to acquire $500m worth of shares in Sky Global Networks, the combination of News Corp's international satellite operations which has been earmarked for flotation. He will not be on the board of either company and his stakeholding in News Corp is non-voting.

Under the broad outline of the deal, News Corp is acquiring the 21% stake held by Mr Malone's Liberty Media in Gemstar-TV Guide International, the provider of interactive programming guides and publisher of TV Guide magazine in the US. News Corp will add the stake to its existing 22% share in the business.

"We have enjoyed a long, productive and mutually beneficial relationship with Liberty Media and John Malone, one of the giants of the media industry," Mr Murdoch said.

"That John has chosen to be come our single largest non-voting equity owner is as strong an endorsement as we could get of our strategic direction and operational performance."

Mr Malone was also in backslapping mode.

"Over the years we have developed an outstanding relationship with Rupert and his management team, and we continue to believe that News Corp is one of the best managed and best positioned global entertainment companies in the world," he said.

Liberty is transferring 80% of its holding in Gemstar to News Corp in return for American depository receipts representing 486m News Corp non-voting shares. The other 20% will be injected into Sky Global Networks.

Liberty is also swapping its interests in a number of companies operating under the umbrella of Sky Latin America to Sky Global Networks in return for an additional 4.8% of the new company.

The relationship between Mr Murdoch and Mr Malone strengthens a labyrinthine network of interests uniting some of the world's largest media and telecoms groups.

Mr Malone built the Denver cable company Tele-Communications before selling it to US telecoms group AT&T last year for £37bn.

Liberty is still owned by AT&T and has a wide set of interests including stakes in European cable companies UPC and Telewest.

There has been speculation that the alliance would strengthen Mr Murdoch's hand in his ambition to acquire Hughes Electronics, which owns satellite business DirecTV, from General Motors.

The business has been valued at $40bn but would add significant weight to Sky Global Networks. DirecTV has 8m subscribers in the US and Latin America.

webTitle: Currency conundrum that won't go away

fields.headline: Currency conundrum that won't go away
fields.standfirst:
Notebook Intervention is a short-term fix

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Recent economic history tells us we should feel some trepidation about the outcome of today's referendum in Denmark on joining the euro. The last time the Danes went to the polls on a European matter, in April 1992, their rejection of the Maastricht treaty set off a chain of events which culminated in a full-blown European currency crisis.
fields.body:
Recent economic history tells us we should feel some trepidation about the outcome of today's referendum in Denmark on joining the euro. The last time the Danes went to the polls on a European matter, in April 1992, their rejection of the Maastricht treaty set off a chain of events which culminated in a full-blown European currency crisis.

Eight years on, however, there are clear grounds for optimism. Whichever way it goes, the markets are likely to receive today's result calmly.

A rejection would clearly be a huge symbolic blow to the euro's credibility, strengthening the hand of eurosceptics in this country, but it is unlikely to significantly effect the euro's value in the short term.

After last Friday's surprise defence of the euro by the G7, the big speculating battalions of the currency markets remain wary of picking a fight with the central banks.

In the less likely event of a clear Danish "yes" vote, the euro may well enjoy a rally - in relief - but there are doubts about how sustained this could be.

Some European governments may favour using the opportunity of improving sentiment towards the euro to intervene again and cement its gains, although it is not clear the US would agree to play ball this time.

While the recent glut of profit warnings from US corporations, whose foreign earnings are being squeezed by the euro's weakness, means the US treasury is ready to help stop the currency going into free fall, actively funding the euro's appreciation from here is another matter entirely.

While accepting that the euro's weakness may be overdone, the US Treasury believes much of the depreciation reflects real economic disparities between the US and Europe. It reckons that unless they are addressed by European governments with real vigour the euro will only enjoy temporary benefit from intervention. It is a sensible view.

Grabiner veritas

If you were to bump into Mike Grabiner at a social gathering you might chat for a moment about the energetic way he runs Energis. You might then move on to BT for an hour or two before posing the irresistible question: are you about to buy Thus? The buttonholing would not ruffle Mr Grabiner - a well-trained, modern executive. There would just be a little shrug of the shoulders, a few dismissive words about Demon Internet, Thus's internet services provider, being a busted flush, and then a short critique of the company's mainly Scottish network. And that would be it.

The Square Mile, of course, is buzzing with the story, convinced that Energis has approached Thus's 50.1% shareholder, Scottish Power, with a firm offer. Mr Grabiner, they are sure, is more than capable of mounting a chunky acquisition at home while rolling out the Energis network across Europe through its various alliances with local utilities and then simultaneously beating up BT in the UK over the dishevelled introduction of broadband communications.

In fact, they may even have been encouraged by an Energis-sponsored study on the changing nature of Britain produced by Professor Chris Edwards of the Cranfield School of Management this week which came to the oh so new-economy conclusion that we are now a "superchange" nation, whatever that is.

But those doing the chattering are probably overestimating the attractions of Thus for Energis. For a start, it is difficult to assess what portion of the company's £1bn market capitalisation is represented by the Demon business - which Energis is unlikely to want, having developed its own services through Planet Online and Energis Squared. The telecoms business, meanwhile, has been slow to expand out of Scotland.

That said the companies have clearly spoken, and it is an open secret that Scottish Power considered a trade sale to Energis before going ahead with the flotation of its telecoms division two years ago. But this is one deal which does not look as though it will be clinched in the short term.

Swedish cool

Per Larsson, the Viking raider who wants to run our stock market, put his blunt weapons to one side yesterday and started using cogent argument in schmoozing the private client stockbrokers who now effectively control the London Stock Exchange's destiny.

The wine was crisp, the gravlax came in bite-sized pieces and, yes, the blond Swede struck a sharp contrast with his staid, old-fashioned prey. There was no use of a podium to guard against difficult questions - instead, out came the handheld microphone, and Mr Larsson and his colleagues almost looked comfortable perched on bar stools, fielding questions from the floor.

Even more of a contrast was his use of language. Mr Larsson told the brokers that he was there to listen. Corny as it may seem, he sounded convincing.

Eight years on, however, there are clear grounds for optimism. Whichever way it goes, the markets are likely to receive today's result calmly. A rejection would clearly be a huge symbolic blow to the euro's credibility, strengthening the hand of eurosceptics in this country, but it is unlikely to significantly effect the euro's value in the short term. After last Friday's surprise defence of the euro by the G7, the big speculating battalions of the currency markets remain wary of picking a fight with the central banks. In the less likely event of a clear Danish "yes" vote, the euro may well enjoy a rally - in relief - but there are doubts about how sustained this could be. Some European governments may favour using the opportunity of improving sentiment towards the euro to intervene again and cement its gains, although it is not clear the US would agree to play ball this time. While the recent glut of profit warnings from US corporations, whose foreign earnings are being squeezed by the euro's weakness, means the US treasury is ready to help stop the currency going into free fall, actively funding the euro's appreciation from here is another matter entirely. While accepting that the euro's weakness may be overdone, the US Treasury believes much of the depreciation reflects real economic disparities between the US and Europe. It reckons that unless they are addressed by European governments with real vigour the euro will only enjoy temporary benefit from intervention. It is a sensible view. Grabiner veritas If you were to bump into Mike Grabiner at a social gathering you might chat for a moment about the energetic way he runs Energis. You might then move on to BT for an hour or two before posing the irresistible question: are you about to buy Thus? The buttonholing would not ruffle Mr Grabiner - a well-trained, modern executive. There would just be a little shrug of the shoulders, a few dismissive words about Demon Internet, Thus's internet services provider, being a busted flush, and then a short critique of the company's mainly Scottish network. And that would be it. The Square Mile, of course, is buzzing with the story, convinced that Energis has approached Thus's 50.1% shareholder, Scottish Power, with a firm offer. Mr Grabiner, they are sure, is more than capable of mounting a chunky acquisition at home while rolling out the Energis network across Europe through its various alliances with local utilities and then simultaneously beating up BT in the UK over the dishevelled introduction of broadband communications. In fact, they may even have been encouraged by an Energis-sponsored study on the changing nature of Britain produced by Professor Chris Edwards of the Cranfield School of Management this week which came to the oh so new-economy conclusion that we are now a "superchange" nation, whatever that is. But those doing the chattering are probably overestimating the attractions of Thus for Energis. For a start, it is difficult to assess what portion of the company's £1bn market capitalisation is represented by the Demon business - which Energis is unlikely to want, having developed its own services through Planet Online and Energis Squared. The telecoms business, meanwhile, has been slow to expand out of Scotland. That said the companies have clearly spoken, and it is an open secret that Scottish Power considered a trade sale to Energis before going ahead with the flotation of its telecoms division two years ago. But this is one deal which does not look as though it will be clinched in the short term. Swedish cool Per Larsson, the Viking raider who wants to run our stock market, put his blunt weapons to one side yesterday and started using cogent argument in schmoozing the private client stockbrokers who now effectively control the London Stock Exchange's destiny. The wine was crisp, the gravlax came in bite-sized pieces and, yes, the blond Swede struck a sharp contrast with his staid, old-fashioned prey. There was no use of a podium to guard against difficult questions - instead, out came the handheld microphone, and Mr Larsson and his colleagues almost looked comfortable perched on bar stools, fielding questions from the floor. Even more of a contrast was his use of language. Mr Larsson told the brokers that he was there to listen. Corny as it may seem, he sounded convincing.

webTitle: No votes inch ahead in Denmark's euro poll

fields.headline: No votes inch ahead in Denmark's euro poll
fields.trailText: Danes voting in today's referendum on the single currency appear to be voting narrowly against joining the euro, though the final result is too close to call. Latest exit polls indicate a vote of 51.5-48.5 against membership in what was reported to be a day of brisk attendance at voting stations. An earlier exit poll broadcast by the TV2 station said 52.2% of voters were against the euro, with 47.1% in favour.
fields.body:
Danes voting in today's referendum on the single currency appear to be voting narrowly against joining the euro, though the final result is too close to call. Latest exit polls indicate a vote of 51.5-48.5 against membership in what was reported to be a day of brisk attendance at voting stations. An earlier exit poll broadcast by the TV2 station said 52.2% of voters were against the euro, with 47.1% in favour.

However, a three percentage point margin of error indicated a statistical dead heat, and Danish MPs were cautious about predicting the outcome of the Scandinavian country's fifth referendum on EU-related issues since it joined what became the European Union in 1973.

"I am not feeling very certain," prime minister Poul Nyrup Rasmussen said after casting his ballot. His Social Democratic-led government is in favour of joining the single currency.

The euro became an official currency in 11 of 15 EU countries in January 1999 for corporate and investment transactions, with coins and bills to be introduced in January 2002. Denmark, Britain and Sweden opted out, while Greece, which was barred from membership because of high inflation and a budget deficit, will join on January 1. EU officials, who said a Yes vote in Denmark would help the euro but a rejection would have no effect, plan to meet tomorrow morning in Brussels to take the pulse of the currency after the Danish vote.

Today's vote also was being closely watched by Sweden and Britain, whose governments also support joining the single currency but plan to let the public decide in referendums.

Prime Minister Tony Blair played down the potential impact, saying: "Denmark's got its own decision, we've got our own decision. It's important also to realise that Denmark has a slightly different type of decision, since their currency is actually linked to the euro in any event. But that's a matter for the Danes, and I'm not going to interfere." Denmark already ties its fiscal and monetary decisions to those made by the 11-member euro zone, which forms the bulk of its export market. Supporters say membership of the Economic and Monetary Union will give it more influence, while opponents say the euro threatens Denmark's extensive welfare state and will lead to an erosion of sovereignty.

The most senior financial official in Germany, Europe's largest economy, urged Danish voters to choose the euro.

"Europe will go forward. European integration is a historic process that isn't reversible." finance minister Hans Eichel said. "But the earlier one is there, the better."

Christina Dallmann, a 31-year-old student, agreed as she ticked "Ja" for yes. "I think it's better to be sitting at the table. It will lead us to a stronger economy, a better society," she said.

Voting booths will close at 8pm (1900 BST), with final results expected a few hours later.

Danes stunned fellow EU nations in 1992 by rejecting the Maastricht treaty for a common currency and a common defence policy. A year later, voters approved a revised treaty with clauses allowing it to initially stay out of the currency and the defence cooperation. A 59-year-old social worker said he saw EMU membership as a threat to Denmark's sovereignty. "If you say yes, you change to a central bank where you haven't got any more democratic influence," Fritz Olsen said.

A series of polls published almost daily for the past few weeks had given the opposition a comfortable lead, but that began to narrow late last week as the government turned up its pro-euro rhetoric. Five final surveys published earlier today also forecast a statistical dead heat.

European Union's Euro site

webTitle: Up to 12% of Danes undecided as euro referendum day dawns

fields.headline: Up to 12% of Danes undecided as euro referendum day dawns
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: More than one in 10 Danes voting in today's euro referendum will make up their minds at the last minute - or even in the polling booth.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Copenhagen and  Mark Atkinson
fields.body:
More than one in 10 Danes voting in today's euro referendum will make up their minds at the last minute - or even in the polling booth.

According to opinion polls on the last day of the six-month campaign, the Yes and No camps are neck and neck, making the result too close to call.

But four of yesterday's polls found the numbers of undecided voters ranged from 4% to 12% of the 4m-strong electorate. Analysts said many of those would make their choice at the last possible moment.

Underlining anxieties about the closeness of the race, advocates of the single currency quickly dismissed a report that the president of the European Central Bank (ECB), Wim Duisenberg, had warned Danish pensions would have to be reformed if the country opted into euroland.

In Frankfurt, the ECB insisted that Mr Duisenberg had been misquoted in the Swiss weekly HandelsZeitung, although that mattered little to euro opponents sensing a late opportunity to gain ground.

Fears that Denmark's famously generous welfare pro visions might have to be dismantled have been a central theme of the debate.

Financial markets will keep a close eye on the outcome of today's vote, mindful that in April 1992 the Danish referendum on Maastricht launched a chain of events which culminated in Black Wednesday, when sterling was ejected from the exchange-rate mechanism.

A No vote would be a temporary blow to the euro's credibility, although probably not its performance.

The effect of such a result on the value of the euro is expected to be limited by a fresh wave of intervention by the Group of Seven industrialised nations, which last week launched a coordinated buying spree on the markets to prop up the ailing currency.

But the longer-term effect could increase the likelihood of a two-speed Europe, where more integrationist-minded countries forge ahead, leaving the laggards behind.

However close the result, it is clear that Denmark's No voters include less well-educated and unskilled workers, with a larger proportion of women, especially public sector employees such as nurses, teachers and welfare managers.

Denmark's elite in business, politics, trade unions and the vast majority of the media want to scrap the krone and join euroland, because they say it will bring jobs, stability, growth and influence.

The issue has split families and soured friendships.

"I am a Yes man but my daughter says No and the other two children are Yes and the mother is No," said one elderly man. "We argue about it all the time."

In a live television debate on Tuesday night, the leaders of the main parties urged supporters to stick with them as they pressed home their views. However, no one was risking a prediction.

"I am not a prophet," said the foreign minister, Neils Helveg Petersen. "But it will be very close."

webTitle: Car makers race ahead of next crisis

fields.headline: Car makers race ahead of next crisis
fields.standfirst:
BMW counts on alternative energy sources moving a little closer to reality

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The petrol crisis has prompted a serious rethink among some of Europe's motorists as they rush to escape the ever-present threat of higher prices by buying the latest models powered by fuel efficient, high performance, low emission diesel engines produced by manufacturers such as VW, Peugeot and even BMW.
fields.body:
The petrol crisis has prompted a serious rethink among some of Europe's motorists as they rush to escape the ever-present threat of higher prices by buying the latest models powered by fuel efficient, high performance, low emission diesel engines produced by manufacturers such as VW, Peugeot and even BMW.

Yesterday, on the eve of the Paris motor show, analysts reported that around a third of new cars bought in Europe this year will be diesel compared with just 15% a decade ago.

But the ramping up of crude oil prices and its impact on forecourts allied with regulations to reduce greenhouse gases has prompted both oil companies and car makers to bring forward the unthinkable: vehicles no longer fuelled by petrol or diesel but by alternative energy sources such as hydrogen - an apparently limitless and non-pollutant fuel previously thought of in connection with only nuclear or rocket technology.

At an extraordinarily eerie filling station behind the cargo area at the Bavarian capital's airport, you can already fill up a top of the range BMW 7 series with the fuel of the future: liquid hydrogen. A robotic arm, triggered by a series of electronic messages from the dashboard and a smart payment card, glides out and fills the 750HL with up to 140 litres of liquid hydrogen - enough to travel 400km.

The fuel is stored, at -253 C, in a tank fitted behind the rear seats that, according to Martin Geier, a BMW research executive, can withstand a full scale, rear end crash. The 5.4 litre engine, producing 204HP, does 0-100km in 9.6 seconds (compared with 6.8 for a conventional 750iL) and has a top speed of 226km an hour (compared with 250). It uses 40 litres per 100km compared with 13.8 for its conventional sister and the three or four litres of petrol now targeted by manufacturers. And in case the hydrogen runs out and the driver is not near the DM34m (£10m) filling station at the airport, it has a 95-litre reserve petrol tank.

The only problem is that you cannot yet buy the vehicle. There are only 15 such cars running in Germany. But Burkhard Goeschel, BMW's development director, says the engine has reached the stage where it is virtually ready to go into series production, and forecasts that at least several thousand will have been sold within the next few years.

"Series production, technically, can be started within a couple of months," says Mr Geier.

Future rivals

BMW has opted for liquid hydrogen, now extracted from natural gas by its project partner Linde, rather than the hydrogen fuel cells being developed by rival groups which have forged strategic partnerships: Ford and DaimlerChrysler with Canadian cell producer Ballard and General Motors and Toyota, for instance.

"Everyone is buying a ticket to the lottery because we all know that whoever wins will win big time," says Paul Everitt, chief economist at the Society of Motor manufacturers and Traders. "Nobody really knows what the market will be nor what is the right technology - they know they just have to be in the game."

BMW says it favours liquid hydrogen because that guarantees higher performance than fuel cells which, so far, can enable a car to run for around 230km rather than the 400km of the 750HL and because it promises nil emissions

However, says Mr Everitt, the extraction of hydrogen from water or gas is now achieved at considerable environmental impact - and manufacturers are betting on several tickets, including hybrid vehicles, in advance of a market that is still in the making.

"Nobody says they're going to win, and there's a considerable degree of doubt. They all have their own strategy and if you get it right and hit it first, you'll be the first one into the market and have a very clear competitive advantage," he says.

So the oil companies such as BP Amoco are backing the car groups' alliances but equally hedging their bets as to the outcome, torn between their awareness that in the medium term oil may no longer fuel the modern economies and short-term issues of cost and competitiveness.

Fritz Vahrenholt, a German Shell executive involved in the BMW project, says: "The first hydrogen filling stations are here now. In 20 years every other new car worldwide should be capable of running on hydrogen. That's our objective."

Crude rethink

The recent fuel crisis underlined the degree to which modern economies depend on oil but also that to which oil is a finite resource. Opec countries already realise that the time for achieving maximum revenues may be relatively short-lived, and Saudi Arabian ministers have said that the emergence of alternative fuels such as hydrogen should stabilise oil prices.

BMW's Mr Geier points to an immediate snag: the absence of a national infrastructure to support alternative fuels.

"We could start production when we know our politicians are willing to support this and we have had no clear statements, even from the red-green coalition in Berlin, that hydrogen will be the fuel of the future."

The more fundamental snag remains the issue at the heart of the stand-off between farmers and hauliers and their governments: tax. BMW executives acknowledge that without fiscal incentives the development of hydrogen-fuelled cars will be delayed or even prevented.

So groups such as BMW may be ready to produce hydrogen-fuelled cars in volume but the political process has yet to encourage this.

The recent crisis on the roads of Europe may yet prove to be the spur for a radical rethink which, within the next decade or so, will see us queuing up for fuel at filling stations such as the now deserted facility at Munich's airport.
