fields.headline: Ministers agree voucher review
fields.standfirst:
Asylum

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The government last night agreed to an immediate and wide-ranging review of its controversial voucher scheme for asylum seekers and the scrapping of the "no-change" rule on voucher use to head off a conference defeat today.
fields.body:
The government last night agreed to an immediate and wide-ranging review of its controversial voucher scheme for asylum seekers and the scrapping of the "no-change" rule on voucher use to head off a conference defeat today.

Transport and General Workers' Union leader Bill Morris, who has made the campaign against vouchers a personal crusade, is now expected to support a Labour national executive statement and avoid pressing the union's motion opposing vouchers to a vote.

The union has been given an understanding that the review will lead to the end of the voucher system, the TGWU said.

Under the scheme, introduced in April to cut the numbers coming to Britain, asylum seekers are given vouchers to buy groceries and other essentials from selected stores, but are not allowed change if the cost of the goods is less than the value of a voucher.

Tony Blair has been personally involved in negotiations all week in Brighton aimed at securing a compromise formula and avoiding a head-to-head confrontation on asylum policy with the country's most prominent black public figure.

Mr Morris plans to tell delegates today his union is determined to end a "degrading and inhuman system which creates new targets for racist attacks" and the "grotesque situation where taxpayers and asylum seekers are subsidising Sainsbury's and Tesco" because of the "no change" rule.

The TGWU yesterday released a dossier the union has used to lobby ministers for an end to the voucher scheme, including evidence of its link to racist harassment.

Sodexho, the private company running the scheme on behalf of the government, has advertised vouchers to retailers as a "revenue-making opportunity", while both Safeway and Sainsbury's have expressed embarrassment at "profiting from asylum-seekers".

Although ministers conceded a review of the voucher scheme at Labour's national policy forum in July, the TGWU said yesterday the new committment to an immediate review according to agreed criteria was a breakthrough.

Both sides accept that if the TGWU's motion opposing vouchers is put to the conference, it will win a strong majority among union and constituency delegates alike.

fields.headline: Pledges failed to sway unions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown and his chief adviser Ed Balls returned from the IMF meeting in Prague shortly after 9pm on Tuesday. He was given a copy of the proposed conference composite and immediately recognised that it was not acceptable.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown and his chief adviser Ed Balls returned from the IMF meeting in Prague shortly after 9pm on Tuesday. He was given a copy of the proposed conference composite and immediately recognised that it was not acceptable.

A meeting including Blair, Brown, Balls, John Presscott and Unisons' Rodney Bickerstaffe was held later that night in the PM's third floor suite at the Metropole. Mr Bickerstaffe argued his union had already moved substantially by giving the government the option of raising the basic pension either in line with earnings or inflation.

The union leaders privately claim Mr Brown was the man insisting the government would not back down. They claimed by being so rigid, Brown was turning a molehill into a mountain, though the Treasury and No 10 claim they were at one.

At 7.30am yesterday the NEC met and the party general secretary Margaret McDonagh claimed Unison was prepared to withdraw its motion. Unison had in fact not given such a commitment. The day was set for a classic seventies style confrontation between a Labour government and the party conference.

Blair and Brown again called in Bickerstaffe, giving him more details of plans to increase the basic state pension. In a further concession, they promised to reconvene the national policy forum in November by which time Brown would have spelt out his plans to improve pensions both in a white paper and his pre-budget report. Brown then met Alistair Darling and the two men called in John Edmonds, the GMB leader and the other key figure in the jigsaw. It was still only 9am.

An emergency meeting of the Labour party and trade union liaison committee was convened to inform other unions of the discussions. The leaderships then met their union delegations, but both Unison and the GMB decided to withstand the pressure.

Just before midday Brown and Blair jointly and separately met Edmonds and Bickerstaffe in the prime minister's suite. Bickerstaffe was by now being pulled in all directions. When Brown and Bickerstaffe did finally meet, Brown told the Unison leader he was reconvening the composite group in a further effort to put pressure on him. By eight votes to five, the composite group voted for the motion to be remitted. However, the vote did not shift Bickerstaffe and as movers of the motion, it was for Unison alone to decide whether or not to remit.

The Millbank fixers then hauled in Dennis Skinner, one of Bickerstaffe's oldest friends. Skinner is thought to have voiced faith in government promises to lift pensions.

After the unions finally inflicted the defeat, voting 85% to 15% against the government, the GMB claimed: "The leadership defeated themselves. We opened the door to allow them to move and for some reason which we will never understand they chose not to walk through it."

However others were more rueful. A senior union figure who had resisted the 24 hours of arm twisting asked: "Should we have done it though?"

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText:
Good day
Tony Blair is being sent 100 free cans of body spray after one of his most embarrassing leaks yet. His unavoidably noticeable perspiration during Tuesday's speech has spurred one fragrance firm to despatch boxes of its product to 10 Downing Street. A spokesman for Sure said:"He was quite obviously wearing deodorant rather than anti-perspirant. The problem is with deodorant, although it smells good for a while it doesn't actually stop you sweating. Many people do not realise that."

Good day
Tony Blair is being sent 100 free cans of body spray after one of his most embarrassing leaks yet. His unavoidably noticeable perspiration during Tuesday's speech has spurred one fragrance firm to despatch boxes of its product to 10 Downing Street. A spokesman for Sure said:"He was quite obviously wearing deodorant rather than anti-perspirant. The problem is with deodorant, although it smells good for a while it doesn't actually stop you sweating. Many people do not realise that."

Bad day
After a storming day yesterday life was a little bit glum for Andrew Rawnsley yesterday. Hoping to capitalise on the runaway success of his Labour bashing book, the Observer's chief political commmentator slipped down to Politicos for an eagerly awaited book signing. But there were no books to scribble in. A Securicor van due to deliver 100 copies was refused entry by conference security and had to turn back.

Quote of the day

fields.headline: Bank checks on benefit cheats
fields.standfirst:
Fraud

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The government is to introduce the toughest powers ever contemplated by Labour to tackle benefit cheats.
fields.body:
The government is to introduce the toughest powers ever contemplated by Labour to tackle benefit cheats.

A new benefit fraud law will be included in the Queen's speech which will give investigators powers to trawl through claimants' bank accounts, insurance policies and check phones to see if they are running businesses while on benefit. Claimants using bogus addresses to claim benefit - such as empty or unused flats - will find fraud investigators checking on their electricity and water use.

The bill will form part of the government's law and order agenda alongside measures to tackle yob culture and tougher criminal laws being introduced by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, and Jeff Rooker, the social security minister, believe that bogus addresses are widely used by fraudsters to obtain benefit - and that too much time and resources are spent in survellience of these properties to prove fraud. Obtaining readouts from electricity and water meters will be much quicker.

But the ministers are also concerned that investigators do not exceed their powers. They will introduce a code of practice and insist that investigators must have genuine suspicion of cheating before they apply to see details of claimants' bank accounts or cross check tax returns.

The proposed changes have already generated a row inside the benefits agency and the ministry, with some civil servants pressing ministers to go even further. Some investigators wanted to launch "fishing expeditions" on all claimants in one office or town. But ministers believe such measures would contravene the new human rights laws and the right to privacy of innocent people.

Officially the government is consulting on these proposals until October 21. In fact ministers have decided to proceed with the bill as part of what Downing Street sees as a vote winning package. Civil servants are already drafting the short bill with the aim of getting it on the statute book by May, in time for the earliest date for an election.

Ministers claim that there has been little resistance to the plans from civil liberties organisations. Benefit fraud is estimated to cost the taxpayer between £2-£4bn a year out of a budget of £100bn.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: A venomous reminder of times past

fields.headline: A venomous reminder of times past
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The Labour party had its acrimonious debate on pensions yesterday. Social security secretary Alistair Darling was matched against one of its greatest heroines, Barbara Castle. Which would the conference take to its heart - the white-haired old woman, or Baroness Castle?
fields.body:
The Labour party had its acrimonious debate on pensions yesterday. Social security secretary Alistair Darling was matched against one of its greatest heroines, Barbara Castle. Which would the conference take to its heart - the white-haired old woman, or Baroness Castle?

Of course they went for Babs. Dozens of photographers clustered around her on the front row. "Back, get back!" yelled a Labour official, thinking he was protecting her, but missing the whole point. The day young men with 1,000mm lenses don't force their attentions upon her is the day that she'll decide to pack it in.

The party management was desperate to stop a rebellion. As we came into the hall we were handed a "supplementary NEC statement" pleading for the right result. It said, "in addition to the nationwide consultation on our new pension proposals there will also be a party wide consultation which will lead to a national policy forum to examine all the issues by the end of the year". What a battle cry! So the Labour party hasn't lost its power to stir the blood. William Blake would have been proud. "Nor shall my sword sleep in my hand/ Till we have built a party-wide consultation leading to a national policy forum to examine all the issues."

You had to feel sorry for Mr Darling. With his snowy white hair and jet black eyebrows he looks like one of those children's books with sliced pages which allow you to make comic faces. And with Gordon Brown sitting near him scowling at everyone, he must have felt like Silas Marner's official spokesman. His technique was to pretend that there wasn't a problem. "We must be the first government to abolish pensioner poverty once and for all. And all pensioners must share in our rising prosperity!" he declared, while defending a policy which will, of course, do neither. If he were Tony Blair he'd just knock the verbs out. "Poverty. Abolished. Once and for all. Sharing prosperity. Meaningless. But resonant."

The chancellor sat frowning and nodding at this as if abolishing pensioner poverty was a great idea, so long as it didn't mean giving pensioners more money.

They made poor Mr Darling sit on a chair to be grilled by the audience. The chairman was the former soap star and Labour MEP Michael Cashman. It was like Room 101 with Paul Merton. "Well, Michael, I'd like to put the entire Labour party conference into Room 101." They gave him a terrible time. Nobody offered any support at all. He fell back on the old John Major defence, which is, don't judge us by what we do, but by what we wish we could do if we felt like it. "Unlike the Tories, we want to spend more on pensioner incomes," he said. We just don't intend to, that's all.

Finally it was Barbara Castle's turn. She may be old and fragile and almost blind, but by golly she can shoot out sarcasm like a spitball. "Tony Blair told us in ringing tones 'I am listening, I am here, I will act'," and every word she uttered dripped with disbelief. The financial facts of life had been described by Alistair Darling "so movingly..." Ooof! It was a bracing reminder of Labour conferences past, when a speech without venom was thought as empty as a day without sunshine.

"This country can afford it. The earnings link only rises if earnings are rising too. Can't a rich country afford this dignity for pensioners?" She hobbled slowly back to her seat, two dozen photographers snapping every step, her ears ringing with the wondrous sound of a Labour conference cheering at a Labour government shafted.

fields.headline: Pressure grows on Milosevic
fields.standfirst:
Yugoslav leader 'broken like a baby's rattle' claim rally organisers

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Thousands of opposition supporters brandishing leaflets that proclaimed the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, was "broken like a baby's rattle" poured into Belgrade city centre last night in a trial of strength over Sunday's disputed election.
fields.body:
Thousands of opposition supporters brandishing leaflets that proclaimed the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, was "broken like a baby's rattle" poured into Belgrade city centre last night in a trial of strength over Sunday's disputed election.

On the fourth consecutive night of burgeoning demonstrations, protesters were ordered by police to dismantle a stage outside the headquarters of the Federal Election Commission, but immediately regrouped nearby.

Final results in the presidential race are expected to be announced tonight. But since Mr Milosevic controls the Federal Electoral Commission, they are widely expected to be fixed.

Mr Milosevic's camp has claimed that the main opposition candidate, Vojislav Kostunica, won the first round of the election but failed to gain 50% needed for outright victory.

As people began coming on to the streets shortly after 5pm yesterday in preparation for a rally at 8pm, no one appeared to be contemplating the option of participating in a second round. The proposal put forward by Mr Milosevic was rejected by Mr Kostunica, a 56-year-old lawyer.

For three days, domestic and international pleas for Mr Milosevic to step down have been ignored.

President Bill Clinton yesterday accused him of trying to steal the election from the opposition and said the United States would support the people of Serbia.

"It certainly appears from a distance that they had a free election and somebody is trying to take it away from them," he said.

Mr Milosevic was indicted by the International War Crimes Tribunal in the Hague and has few options if he is forced to step down. There is also a $5m (£3m) bounty on offer from the US government for his capture leading to prosecution by the Hague.

There were concerns that Mr Milosevic would try to use the paramilitary police to break up the rally last night. Before the rally began, a few dozen policemen were wandering around the city centre with their hands in their pockets.

The opposition leaders are concerned to avoid any violence and fear provocations by the regime. "Our stand is to avoid any conflict; we are the winners and we do not need conflicts," said Zoran Djindjic, an opposition leader.

Student activists warned that government provocateurs dressed in protesters' T-shirts might stir up trouble at the rally. They said police had confiscated 4,000 T-shirts - marked with a clenched fist, the symbol of the Otpor movement. Otpor means resistance in Serbian.

"We wish to warn that we are not responsible for that because our methods are non-violent," Otpor activist Vukasin Petrovic said.

"We're just ignoring him now. It's a new psychological phenomenon that I have never seen before," said Mr Petrovic, a 32-year-old architect.

"He can do whatever he wants. He can say he's king of the earth - but nobody cares."

Meanwhile, former allies of Mr Milosevic are preparing to jump ship, and threatening to abandon their coalition with him in the Serbian parliament. Vojislav Seselj, leader of the extremist Radical Party, is considering the move that would mean the fall of the Milosevic government.

Scenting blood, Mr Seselj's nationalist extremists, whose men provided some of shock troops for Mr Milosevic's "ethnic cleansing" campaigns in Bosnia and Kosovo, are abandoning him.

Another former ally, Vuk Draskovic, is also paying the price for refusing the join the united front against Milosevic. After a devastating defeat for his party, the Serbian Renewal Movement - he went public two days ago and said that he was wrong not to back opposition leader Vojislav Kostunica's bid to become president.

Mr Milosevic's government is still in denial. The media he controls does not know how to react.

On the front page of Politika, the only picture at this momentous crossroads in Serbia's history was one of the designer, Karl Lagerfeld, who is involved in a tax scandal in France.

The front page, is still insisting that Mr Milosevic's party, the Socialist Party of Serbia, and his wife's party, Yugoslav Left, are going to form the next federal government.

But two government television stations, BK television and Studio B yesterday surprised viewers with extensive reports from the opposition press conference, where it was announced that Mr Milosevic had lost the election. For the first time, it appears that Mr Milosevic is even beginning to lose control of one of his most powerful weapons.

webTitle: Air France sues over Concorde crash

fields.headline: Air France sues over Concorde crash
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Air France and its insurers said yesterday they had launched legal action against Continental Airlines over the American carrier's possible responsibility for the Concorde crash in July that killed 113 people.
fields.body:
Air France and its insurers said yesterday they had launched legal action against Continental Airlines over the American carrier's possible responsibility for the Concorde crash in July that killed 113 people.

French accident investigators have said a strip of metal found on the runway at Roissy-Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris resembles a piece missing from a Continental DC-10 aircraft that used the runway minutes before the doomed Concorde took off on July 25.

The twisted piece of metal, apparently a wear strip from an engine thrust reverser assembly, is thought to have punctured one of the Concorde's tyres, sending chunks of rubber hurtling up into its under-wing fuel tanks.

These then leaked fuel into the port engine, sparking the catastrophic blaze that sent the jetliner plunging some two minutes later into a hotel in the small town of Gonesse, killing all 109 people on board and four on the ground.

"A piece from a Continental Airlines plane could have caused the Concorde accident," an Air France spokeswoman said, adding that airlines were legally responsible for any damage caused if parts dropped off their aircraft.

Continental Airlines said in a statement that it was aware legal action was being prepared against it, but insisted that "at this stage of the investigation, there is no conclusive evidence that Continental Airlines is involved in the crash".

Air France's action is likely to be long and costly. It will have to prove that the strip came from Continental's flight COA 55 and that it was instrumental in causing the accident.

The French accident investigators have been cautious about confirming the details of the complex chain of causes and effects that led to the catastrophe.

The accident investigation bureau, BEA, has taken care to hedge its findings and stressed that its full report on the causes of the crash - which will not apportion blame but merely attempt to explain the accident - will take more than a year to prepare.

The US airline may also argue that postponement of a routine runway inspection scheduled for an hour before the Air France Concorde took off could be partly responsible.

The BEA's interim report last month revealed that the inspection was delayed to allow time for a 35-minute fire drill, meaning that the runway used by the doomed plane had not been checked for potentially dangerous debris for more than 12 hours.

The lawsuit was lodged by Air France and its insurer, Réunion Aérienne. The insurance consortium is believed to be claiming all the costs in curred in the disaster, a bill which could run into hundreds of millions of pounds. The French company has already said it will compensate the families of those killed in the accident, mainly German tourists, as well as the owner of the destroyed hotel.

In Germany yesterday, Christof Wellens, a lawyer for the families of 20 crash vic tims, said he was also planning to sue Continental. He said his lawsuit would probably be filed in a Texas court. US courts are generally more generous with compensation awards than European judges.

webTitle: Falconer admits failures on dome but refuses to quit

fields.headline: Falconer admits failures on dome but refuses to quit
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The embattled dome supremo Lord Falconer yesterday admitted the project had not been a success but rejected calls for him to resign, in the first statement to parliament since the latest round of troubles hit the failing millennium attraction.
fields.body:
The embattled dome supremo Lord Falconer yesterday admitted the project had not been a success but rejected calls for him to resign, in the first statement to parliament since the latest round of troubles hit the failing millennium attraction.

He told the House of Lords that the government acknowledged the scheme had been "too ambitious" and that it was not appropriate for the public sector to manage a large visitor attraction, but said he was "determined to see this project through to the end".

"I can assure the house that we are aware of the lessons to be learned. However, we cannot put the clock back, and we are where we are. The project is three months from its conclusion and there are still vital tasks to be accomplished."

He said the dome's failures should not distract from what had been achieved in turning it into the second most popular visitor attraction in Europe, employing more than 13,000 people during its construction and operation. It had also been the catalyst for the regeneration of the Greenwich peninsula.

The government was still firmly committed to securing a long term future for the dome, he said, and confirmed that it was in talks with Legacy plc, the sole remaining shortlisted bidder to take over the project after the Japanese merchant bank Nomura pulled out, citing "contractual chaos".

Lord Falconer, a close friend of Tony Blair, was also forced to correct statements he made to parliament earlier in the summer that the dome was trading solvently.

He said the assurances he had given in July to the Commons culture, media and sport committee and in a written House of Lords answer had been based on information from the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome. However, a report the next month by PricewaterhouseCoopers warned that the dome needed an immediate £47m injection of national lottery cash if it was to keep going.

"The answers I gave on July 17 and 27 obviously didn't contain the material subsequently revealed in the PWC report because I didn't know it," he said. "I have taken this first opportunity to put the record straight in this house."

He said the report had considered in detail whether it would be cheaper to close the dome early, but that "the expenditure saved would not be as high as the revenue lost and the likely claims that would be made in the event of earlier closure".

The beleaguered minister came in for fierce criticism from the opposition benches. Lady Anelay of St Johns, for the Tory peers, called on Lord Falconer to resign. "It has been a fiasco, but the sole shareholder sails blithely on," she said.

"When do we get to the point when you accept your own responsibility and go?

"Many suspect you are acting as something of an air raid shelter for the prime minister and other members of the government who have made the decisions and driven this project from day one.

"It may be an honourable position to stand by your friends. But it would be far more honourable and add to the respect in which you are held if you would now accept ministerial responsibility for what Clare Short has called 'the disaster of the dome' and lay down the office you now hold."

She condemned as "negligent" the financial monitoring of the project, with no data on the company's assets, and urged Lord Falconer to publish the Pricewaterhouse report in full, including the "missing section" on implications for directors.

Lord Harris of Greenwich, for the Liberal Democrats, described the dome as a "fine old mess" and a "very substantial failure", but he stressed that it had been a cross-party project from the outset.

"Serious and indeed grave errors have been made by a significant number of people over the dome. But to try to pin the responsibility on a single individual is absurd," he said.

The government was still firmly committed to securing a long term future for the dome, he said, and confirmed that it was in talks with Legacy plc, the sole remaining shortlisted bidder to take over the project after the Japanese merchant bank Nomura pulled out, citing "contractual chaos". Lord Falconer, a close friend of Tony Blair, was also forced to correct statements he made to parliament earlier in the summer that the dome was trading solvently. He said the assurances he had given in July to the Commons culture, media and sport committee and in a written House of Lords answer had been based on information from the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome. However, a report the next month by PricewaterhouseCoopers warned that the dome needed an immediate £47m injection of national lottery cash if it was to keep going. "The answers I gave on July 17 and 27 obviously didn't contain the material subsequently revealed in the PWC report because I didn't know it," he said. "I have taken this first opportunity to put the record straight in this house." He said the report had considered in detail whether it would be cheaper to close the dome early, but that "the expenditure saved would not be as high as the revenue lost and the likely claims that would be made in the event of earlier closure". The beleaguered minister came in for fierce criticism from the opposition benches. Lady Anelay of St Johns, for the Tory peers, called on Lord Falconer to resign. "It has been a fiasco, but the sole shareholder sails blithely on," she said. "When do we get to the point when you accept your own responsibility and go? "Many suspect you are acting as something of an air raid shelter for the prime minister and other members of the government who have made the decisions and driven this project from day one. "It may be an honourable position to stand by your friends. But it would be far more honourable and add to the respect in which you are held if you would now accept ministerial responsibility for what Clare Short has called 'the disaster of the dome' and lay down the office you now hold." She condemned as "negligent" the financial monitoring of the project, with no data on the company's assets, and urged Lord Falconer to publish the Pricewaterhouse report in full, including the "missing section" on implications for directors. Lord Harris of Greenwich, for the Liberal Democrats, described the dome as a "fine old mess" and a "very substantial failure", but he stressed that it had been a cross-party project from the outset. "Serious and indeed grave errors have been made by a significant number of people over the dome. But to try to pin the responsibility on a single individual is absurd," he said.

webTitle: Serbs hope election commission will crack

fields.headline: Serbs hope election commission will crack
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Serbian opposition representatives were rebuffed yesterday when they tried to see the ballot records on which federal election commission officials based their claim that Vojislav Kostunica failed to win enough votes for a first-round victory over President Slobodan Milosevic in Sunday's poll.
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele  and  Gillian Sandford  in Belgrade
fields.body:
Serbian opposition representatives were rebuffed yesterday when they tried to see the ballot records on which federal election commission officials based their claim that Vojislav Kostunica failed to win enough votes for a first-round victory over President Slobodan Milosevic in Sunday's poll.

"As I had expected, they did not ... allow us, and nor will they, to look into the election material," Nebojsa Bakarec said after speaking to officials inside the parliament building where the commission works.

"There is great fear among the commission," he added. He was the only member of the 40-strong team allowed in. He later appealed to commission members to "publish the real results and act according to their conscience, without creating tensions".

The commission's rebuff only served to add conviction to the opposition's belief that it won the election outright. Cedomir Jovanovic, the spokesman for the 18-party Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS) said that, with 97% of the votes counted, Mr Kostunica had won 52%.

The credibility of its figures was reinforced by the ultra-right Radical party, which had its own presidential candidate and is still nominally part of Mr Milosevic's government. Its figures tally.

The opposition's confidence in rejecting a runoff is based on several factors, analysts in Belgrade said. They range from a determination to retain the initiative in the battle of wills with an increasingly desperate Mr Milosevic, to a sense that the federal election commission will soon "crack" and be forced to give new figures showing that the opposition did indeed win.

There are also signs that the police will not dare to beat peaceful protesters; that the army is uncertain of its conscripts' loyalty; that Mr Milosevic has lost the support of his best ally, Russia; and that his more pragmatic advisers are saying that he still could have a political future in Serbia as an ex-president.

"They may well be telling him that Vojislav Kostunica is a nationalist who has repeatedly said that he does not accept the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague. They could also remind him that he can stay on as leader of the Socialist party of Serbia," said Sasha Nenadovic, former editor of a leading Belgrade newspaper.

The most optimistic scenario canvassed by Belgrade observers was that the election commission would give different results when it releases the final count this evening. It is known to have held back about 500,000 votes which have allegedly not yet been counted. This could allow it to declare that Mr Kostunica did get more than 50% of the vote, thereby making him president without a runoff.

The very fact that the commission has already conceded an eight-point lead to Mr Kostunica was being seen as historic in Belgrade.

Mr Milosevic has frequently turned to force to try to handle problems. His record of bloodshed is strewn across the Balkans. But he has also retreated when the odds were overwhelming.

Nato's intervention last year ended after 78 days when Mr Milosevic finally found too many factors were building up against him.

Similar realism could prevail again, the DOS leadership hopes. Strengthening the argument that the commission may have to concede victory for Mr Kostunica are its own official figures for the elections to councils in Serbia as well as the federal parliament.

These show that the DOS had an almost clean sweep of the poll at the local level. It won a staggering 105 of the 110 seats on the Belgrade city council, virtually wiping out Mr Milosevic's Socialist party, which won only four seats, as well as the Radical party of Vojislav Seselj, which took one.

Vuk Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement, which once ran Belgrade's city government, failed to win a seat. Several ministers from Mr Milosevic's socialists lost their council seats.

The overwhelming switch to the opposition was repeated across Serbia. DOS won councils in almost every major town. Mr Seselj lost his seat in his home suburb.

The only good news for Mr Milosevic came as a result of the boycott of the election in Montenegro, organised by the government of Milo Djukanovic. This allowed the pro-Milosevic party to win almost all the seats from Montenegro, leaving the embattled Yugoslav president in control of both houses of the federal parliament.

DOS says it also defeated Mr Milosevic in many army bar racks where conscripts voted. The message will not be lost on officers who will have to think hard before ordering the army to break up street protests.

Mr Milosevic's continuing control over the federal parliament still leaves him with a few cards. He also controls the government and presidency of Serbia through committed loyalists.

These two factors might allow him to negotiate his future with Mr Kostunica, getting a guarantee of his personal security as head of the Socialist party in return for working with the new president.

webTitle: Microsoft accuses BT of spoiling tactics in high speed web roll-out

fields.headline: Microsoft accuses BT of spoiling tactics in high speed web roll-out
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Microsoft yesterday launched a stinging attack on BT, accusing the former state-owned monoply of spoiling the rapid roll out of high speed web connections.
fields.body:
Microsoft yesterday launched a stinging attack on BT, accusing the former state-owned monoply of spoiling the rapid roll out of high speed web connections.

Neil Holloway, Microsoft's UK managing director, claimed it was in BT's interest to delay rivals from launching super-fast ADSL net services.

"It does seem ironic that one minute the government is saying the local loop is going to be opened up in June or July next year and ... the next we hear there's not enough room [in BT's exchanges], it's the wrong type of carpet, the air conditioning was wrong on a Wednesday afternoon," he said.

"It's not in BT's interest to get everyone else to roll it out. The longer they can delay it, the better."

Earlier this month US telco WorldCom pulled out of the broadband market - after reports that it was "frustrated" with Oftel's handling of the process opening up BT's monopoly to competition.

Another player in the high speed web market, RSL Communications, pulled out of the first stage of bidding and accused the industry's regulator of failing to ensure fair play for rivals to BT.

The company was also under fire yesterday after it was revealed that that nearly 40% of the British population - around 23m people - will be excluded from the high speed internet revolution.

Leaked BT documents suggested that the company predicts there will be "dead zones" where the new services will be "commercially and technically unviable".

Those most likely to miss out were said to be businesses and consumers in Cornwall, Wales, the North East and North West, Scotland and Northern Ireland.

But a spokeswoman for BT dismissed the claims and emphasised there was nothing secret or underhand about the roll-out programme.

The company, she said, had always maintained the initial roll-out would only cover around 75% of the population as there were technical and geographical barriers.

"We have always said that beyond next spring it will depend on what demand there is for these new services," she said. "If there was huge provider demand we could invest more in our local network to take it further out.

"If there is demand, we're not going to sit there and not go for it."

The spokeswoman also refuted claims that BT was dragging its feet with the roll-out.

"We are working to a timetable laid down by the entire telecoms industry in the UK," she said.

"That is designed to open up BT's exchange to allow even more competition for broadband internet."

Mr Holloway also noted that a link-up between Telewest and NTL - in which Microsoft own stakes of 23.7% and 3% respectively - would "speed up competition between cable, ADSL, satellite and wireless".

Neither NTL nor Telewest were prepared to comment last night.

However, industry sources said the pair were already working closely with each other and suggestions of a merger were being made.

A deal would have to attract the support of France Telecom, which owns 23% of NTL and UPC NV, the Dutch cable operator, which has a 25% stakeholding in Telewest.

This week's debate over broadband services will be another blow for Tony Blair's plan to get Britain online.

It follows in the wake of the farce earlier this year over unmetered internet access after payment of a flat fee.

AltaVista, the American internet portal and software producer, was encouraged to take a leading role but had to withdraw its service as it proved to economically unviable.

Last week America Online stoked up the war between internet service providers by offering unlimited use of the web and free customer support for £15 a month.

webTitle: US election: Battleground states call the shots

fields.headline: Battleground states call the shots
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: In American elections, just as in the US constitution, all voters are created equal - but those who vote in the handful of battleground states are more equal than the others.
fields.body:
In American elections, just as in the US constitution, all voters are created equal - but those who vote in the handful of battleground states are more equal than the others.

The contest between George W Bush and Al Gore on November 7 will be decided by a handful of votes in a body called the electoral college. The presidency is settled not by a national tally of Bush voters against Gore voters - the "popular vote" - but in a state-by-state contest in which the winner in each state collects all of that state's votes in the electoral college.

The number of votes each state casts in the electoral college is equal to its members in the US House of Representatives and the Senate combined. Since a state's representation in the house is based on its population, while each state has two senators, California has the most electoral college votes, with 54, while seven small states and the District of Columbia each have just three.

There are 538 members of the electoral college, therefore 270 electoral college votes are required to win the presidency.

The effect of the electoral college is brutal, especially for voters in smaller states. The big states matter most because they have most electoral college votes, and the big swing states matter most of all, especially in an electoral race as close as this year's.

California and New York, with 87 votes between them, are both leaning towards Mr Gore. In all, the Associated Press's senior analyst Ron Fournier estimates, 15 states and the District of Columbia, worth 224 electoral college votes between them, are likely to go for Mr Gore, while Mr Bush looks to have 21 states worth 171 votes.

This leaves 14 swing states, in which the election is likely to be decided, with 143 electoral college votes in all.

The majority of the most important states in this group are, as so often in the past, in the midwest, led by Ohio (21 votes), Michigan (18), Missouri (11) and Wisconsin (11).

But the battleground is not confined to the midwest: States such as Washington (11 votes) and - the most intriguing of all - Florida (25) also remain very much up for grabs.

Expect these states to get the lion's share of the campaign time and money between now and November 7. Mr Gore, for instance, is said privately to have made his last visit to California, so confident is he of victory there. Mr Bush, on the other hand, still faces the difficult decision of whether to spend valuable time and money in California between now and November. Republican candidates running for other offices there want him to fly the party flag in the state, but every day Mr Bush spends in California is a day not spent in the battleground states.

Although the presidency grabs most of the media attention, the elections on November 7 are not just about the White House. The whole 435-member House of Representatives is up for election, as it is every two years, while 34 seats in the 100-member Senate and 11 state governorships are also being contested.

The most important battle is for control of the house, where Republicans hold an 11-vote majority. If Mr Gore wins the presidency and the Democrats retake the house under Dick Gephardt, the domestic legislative consequences would be enormous - as would the soul-searching among the Republicans.

webTitle: US election: Centerville sits on the fence

fields.headline: Centerville sits on the fence
fields.standfirst:
With just 40 days to the US presidential election, the race is on to woo undecided voters in the key swing states

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Ohio lies at the heart of a nation still wavering over who it wants to be president. In fact, if there was a meridian of indecision running through the country, it would bisect this swing state, through Montgomery, its most evenly balanced county, down the middle of Dayton and under the feet of Felix Garfunkel.
fields.body:
Ohio lies at the heart of a nation still wavering over who it wants to be president. In fact, if there was a meridian of indecision running through the country, it would bisect this swing state, through Montgomery, its most evenly balanced county, down the middle of Dayton and under the feet of Felix Garfunkel.

Mr Garfunkel's vote, like the state of Ohio, is up for grabs. And with 40 days until the US goes to the polls, his opinions - and those of his fellow floating Daytonians - could prove decisive. Historically, the candidate who wins Montgomery county usually wins Ohio, and the winner in Ohio almost always wins the presidency.

Mr Garfunkel, out shopping in the aptly named Dayton suburb of Centerville, is having a hard time deciding.

"I'm waiting for the debates to make up my mind," he says. "I will see what the positions of the two are. Gore has promised a lot, but those things have yet to be proved. But Bush hasn't given details of what he thinks either."

Mr Bush's lead in the state has narrowed to 4%, which is virtually insignificant, statistically speaking. In Dayton and the surrounding Montgomery county, the two candidates are running neck and neck with the support of 49% of likely voters apiece. Dayton's decision could be critical in determining the allocation of Ohio's precious 21 votes in the electoral college, which formally decides the presidency.

Mr Garfunkel is 69 years old and shares the concerns of his fellow pensioners about the ballooning cost of prescription medicines and the fate of the state-funded Medicare system. But he admits he does not have a clear idea of either candidate's plans.

Mark Taylor, 45, a respiratory therapist at a Dayton hospital is in the same boat. "To be honest, there's not an easy answer," he says. "I'm not real happy with either side. I'm not happy with the whole concept of politics. I think as far as the economy is concerned it's going a little bit easier on us. But I'm not sure if that has anything to do with Mr Gore."

Ralph Nader, the environmentalist contender, is a man of real integrity, the Centerville voter believes, but as he is not going to win, what is the point?

Other shoppers have more concrete views. Most of the white, middle-class residents are long-term Republicans who say they are still sickened by the Monica Lewinsky sex scandal, and angry with the vice-president for not resigning in disgust. Most of the black Daytonians are traditional Democrats whose party loyalty was set in stone 40 years ago, in the civil rights struggle.

There is no reason to believe that the range of views in Centerville is very different from anywhere else in the great undecided heartland. It certainly looks like a thousand other quietly prosperous suburbs around the country. Regional unemployment - at 4% - is at a post-war low. The shopping malls are full and most of the cars parked along the shaded streets seem to have been bought in the last five years.

In Dayton, a city of about 180,000, the scars of de-industrialisation are visible - empty sites where cars were once assembled for General Motors, whose jobs have gone to cheaper labour in Mexico and Asia. But those scars are being quickly smoothed over. The sleek offices of hi-tech companies have transformed the outskirts of town.

"There is a sense of contentment and a general lack of commitment," Jim Walker, a politics professor at Dayton's Wright State University, says. "You will normally get a third partisan Republicans, a third Democrats and a third who just don't pay any attention. Ohio perhaps has more of those. I've found about 42 or 43% who just don't identify. That mostly means they don't pay attention."

Prof Walker argues that the usual neat profile of a swing voter - someone carefully weighing their interests and options in the light of the party platforms - is a false one. Confusion, ignorance of the issues and disinterest are far more common.

Certainly, the opinions expressed in Centerville appeared to be based on gut feeling rather than careful calculation. "With many people", Prof Walker says, "the last good idea they hear will be the one they go for."

The candidates have visited Ohio about a dozen times since the August conventions, and will visit another dozen times before the election, in the hope of providing that decisive "good idea".

During a visit last week, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, Joe Lieberman, told a crowd of supporters: "If the Gore-Lieberman ticket carries Ohio, that's it folks - the other side doesn't have a chance.

"I'm not trying to put pressure on you but the future of America is on your shoulders."

"You will normally get a third partisan Republicans, a third Democrats and a third who just don't pay any attention. Ohio perhaps has more of those. I've found about 42 or 43% who just don't identify. That mostly means they don't pay attention." Prof Walker argues that the usual neat profile of a swing voter - someone carefully weighing their interests and options in the light of the party platforms - is a false one. Confusion, ignorance of the issues and disinterest are far more common. Certainly, the opinions expressed in Centerville appeared to be based on gut feeling rather than careful calculation. "With many people", Prof Walker says, "the last good idea they hear will be the one they go for." The candidates have visited Ohio about a dozen times since the August conventions, and will visit another dozen times before the election, in the hope of providing that decisive "good idea". During a visit last week, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, Joe Lieberman, told a crowd of supporters: "If the Gore-Lieberman ticket carries Ohio, that's it folks - the other side doesn't have a chance. "I'm not trying to put pressure on you but the future of America is on your shoulders."

webTitle: Mandela: the face of Unicef adverts

fields.headline: Mandela: the face of Unicef adverts
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela is to appear in a £200m advertising campaign for the United Nations' Children's Fund to be directed by Steven Spielberg.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela is to appear in a £200m advertising campaign for the United Nations' Children's Fund to be directed by Steven Spielberg.

The pair will collaborate on the project, which aims to push children's rights to the top of the agenda ahead of a UN report next year.

The campaign will be run by the London-based advertising agency, TBWA, which won the account over M&C Saatchi New York.

A spokeswoman for Unicef in New York said that a deal was expected to be finalised next week.

The campaign is intended to develop a coherent brand for Unicef, including an international campaign targeting corporations, governments and young people.

It will aim to change attitudes among industry and government leaders. The organisation hopes to galvanise support from academic bodies, charities and industry for the project, which is known internally as the Global Movement for Children.

At the time of TBWA's appointment in March, Corinne Wood, head of communications at Unicef, said: "TBWA has demonstrated an acute understanding of the brief as well as an ability to challenge perspectives on children's issues and proven experience of repositioning global brands."

webTitle: Taking the struggle out of family life

fields.headline: Taking the struggle out of family life
fields.standfirst:
Ministers may have accepted the need for improved parental rights, but the loudest call is for more paid leave

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Ministers may have accepted the need for improved parental rights, but the loudest call is for more paid leave
fields.body:
Women at a crowded fringe meeting at the Labour conference this week were reassured to hear Cherie Booth say that she frequently discusses the balance between work and home life at the Downing Street kitchen table with her husband and teenage children. What was less reassuring was how much of a "constant struggle" she found such a balance, and how she suspected it probably always would be.

"Struggle" may be a true description of the high profile Blair household, but it has been a central plank of the campaign for better maternity and paternity rights for more than two decades that there is no reason why it should be the case for millions of other families. Indeed, campaigners argue that it is perfectly possible to remove the element of "constant struggle" from family life - it is simply a matter of sensible policies. There is no reason why participation in the labour market should be at the cost of children or marriages.

There is now clear evidence that the government has broadly accepted their case on the need for reform of maternity and paternity rights. Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, who is leading the ministerial review on the issue, admits that maternity rights provision is inadequate, lagging up to 20 years behind provision in many European states. The battle is no longer over whether there should be reform, but what form it should take.

It is at the birth of a child that these "livability" issues, as they are known in political jargon, are most sharply defined and the battle is greatest. This is one of the most physically and emotionally demanding times of women's lives, yet they are entitled to only six weeks leave at 90% of their salary, followed by statutory maternity pay of £60.20 a week for 12 weeks.

Harriet Harman, Labour's most vocal champion of improved maternity rights, argues that SMP is too low for many of the poorest paid women. In a report, commissioned by the Knitwear, Footwear and Textiles Union, the former social security secretary said she found women factory workers returning to work six weeks after the birth, often having to give up breastfeeding as a consequence.

"Their stories are heart-rending," said Ms Harman, who is lobbying for one year's paid maternity leave to be a Labour manifesto pledge for the next election.

Christine Gowdridge, of the Maternity Alliance, pinpointed the most significant shift which policy-makers had to recognise. Women's participation in the labour market was no longer for a bit of extra pin money but was a crucial contribution to the family income. In the past 10 years this change has accelerated: in 1990 50% of women went back to work; seven years later it had leapt to 68%.

The significance for the policy-makers is twofold. First, unless income is properly protected, the leave is not taken. Britain is, theoretically, generous on maternity leave - most women can take up to 29 weeks - but unless there are savings or a partner's income that can support the family, few women take the full entitlement.

"People just can't afford to take time off if it is unpaid, said Richard Dunstan, of the National Association of Citizen's Advice Bureaux. Unpaid leave was a perk for the rich, said Ms Gowdridge. So the priority for reform is more leave at full pay, said the Maternity Alliance.

This argument is also used against unpaid parental leave. The experience across Europe has been that take-up rates, particularly among men, are poor unless it is paid properly. This year Ruth Kelly, Labour MP for Bolton West, produced a pamphlet calling for a flat-rated parental leave rate of £150 a week, which Mr Byers went out of his way to praise.

Second, the dramatic shift in women's work patterns has been crucial in persuading the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and the Treasury that reform on maternity provision is needed. What concerned the Treasury was that women at the lowest end of the pay scale had the most inadequate rights - higher earners benefit from contractual company schemes - yet they are crucial to the government's commitment to end child poverty.

Mary-Ann Stephenson, of the Fawcett Society, said: "Enhanced maternity rights encourage women to stay in paid work, and in the long run that saves the Treasury money because women dropping out of the labour market are more likely to go on to benefits. They are also not building up a pension. Plus, if women take a break, when they go back to work they take a job at a lower level and lower pay. Women workers end up being deskilled, and that is a loss of productivity for the economy."

These arguments are likely to carry weight with Mr Byers's review because its remit gives priority to how maternity provision affects economic competitiveness and productivity. What concerns child welfare campaigners is that the review does not include anyone with a child welfare brief, either from the Department of Health or the Home Office. They claim it makes nonsense of joined-up government.

Campaigners fear that the government will miss the opportunity for radical reform because it is frightened by the business lobby, which has declared its vehement opposition. The government insists it will not allow business a veto, but there are worrying signs that the review will come up with only some cheap symbolism. Two weeks of paid parental leave is one such option which campaigners say will do little to improve the lot of mothers.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Man Who Knew Everything/Europe: Belief And Belonging
fields.body:
In the Afternoon Play, Jack Klaff becomes The Man Who Knew Everything (2.15pm, Radio 4), the first of four stories about the real-life Victorian solicitor George Lewis. As a Jew involved in some of the most notorious criminal cases of the period, he was often regarded by his contemporaries as beyond the pale. But his clients focused on the more relevant fact that his team usually emerged the winners.

Europe: Belief And Belonging (8.0pm, Radio 4), presented by David Sells starts in Aachen, from which Charlemagne ruled the original European Union. The empire shared Latin, Christianity, and a single currency. Notably missing from Sells' account, however, is what was happening across the Channel at the same time. Offa would only accept a limited trade agreement with Charlemagne and then started building the dyke for which history remembers him.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Thing From Another World/The Cable Guy/From Dusk Till Dawn/I Forgot I Don't Remember
fields.body:
The Thing From Another World

(Christian Nyby, 1951)

3pm, Carlton Cinema

Stranded at a frozen polar research station, a group of scientists discover a spaceship, and are gradually whittled down by the malignant alien it carried. Where John Carpenter's remake, The Thing, gave us the beast in all its horror, this Howard Hawks production keeps it lurking round the corner, building suspense and dread: these people are brave and resourceful, but that just ain't enough. Classic sci-fi, with Margaret Sheridan and Kenneth Tobey among the threatened few.

The Cable Guy

(Ben Stiller, 1996)

10pm, FilmFour

Nightmare scenario: you get the cable guy to install a little extra on the TV, and next thing he's leeched onto you and it's impossible to get rid of him. Matthew Broderick, as the prim Steven, and the bordering-on-insanity Jim Carrey, pictured (no: he's way over the border), as the cable guy, a disturbed character formed from a neglected life in front of the TV, couldn't be better. A wild comedy, with high spots including the intercutting of Carrey's lewd karaoke number (Jefferson Airplane's Somebody To Love) with Broderick attempting a seduction.

From Dusk Till Dawn

(Robert Rodriguez, 1995)

10.10pm, UK Gold

A trashy, back-from-the-pub, Quentin Tarantino-scripted special. George Clooney and Tarantino are murderous, bank-robbing brothers who kidnap the Rev Harvey Keitel and family (including Juliette Lewis) and turn up at the Titty Twister, a gruesome Mexican brothel swarming with rancid biker-vampires out for their blood. The carnage that follows is like The Wild Bunch meets The Evil Dead, a gorefest of staggering proportions. Enjoy.

I Forgot I Don't Remember

(Carlos Rulfo, 1999)

10.30pm BBC Knowledge

Knowledge's Kino season of non-English language films continues with this idiosyncratic portrait of Mexican writer Juan Rulfo, by his son, Carlos, which won the International Film Category at the 1999 Montreal World Film Festival.

webTitle: TV guide: The price is right

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which pair of film-makers will co-direct a movie for release before 2002?
fields.trailText: Which pair of film-makers will co-direct a movie for release before 2002?
fields.body:
David Lynch and Mel Brooks evens

Milos Foreman and Oliver Stone 2-1

Francis Ford Coppola and Quentin Tarantino 5-1

Woody Allen and Robert Altman 5-1

It has recently been announced that directors Martin Scorsese and Steven Spielberg are going to work together. The two heavyweights have long been friendly, even swapping projects - Scorsese gave Spielberg Schindler's List in return for Cape Fear - and are together the ying and yang of filmmaking styles. That raises the question: who else would make a perfect match?

Mel Brooks admires David Lynch, and directed the documentary Pretty As A Picture: The Art Of David Lynch. Lynch's wholly distinctive, challenging and visually arresting cinema and Mel Brook's clever humour does seem to be well matched. "It's not nearly as unlikely as it sounds given the clear mutual admiration between these two", concurs Sean Boyce, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler. "Brooks may have enjoyed more mainstream success, but he shares Lynch's anti-establishment inclinations."

Francis Ford Coppola and Quentin Tarantino share a fascination with gangster culture. "Some would argue that Tarantino is Coppola's natural heir, but for this pairing to work huge amounts of pride would have to be swallowed. Any cinematic offspring of this coupling could be subtitled 'when two egos collide'", argues Sean.

Milos Forman has already worked with Oliver Stone on the well received The People vs Larry Flynt. "Another combination that might be slightly more likely than it appears", says Sean. "It's a pairing that looks capable of creating the right kind of creative sparks."

And finally we come to Woody Allen and Robert Altman, the most strangely kooky directors of the bunch. "Every film buff's dream combination no doubt, but these two strike me as out and out loners when it comes to their craft," declares Sean.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Teacher jailed for sex attacks
Piano teacher William Mogford, 57, who sexually abused teenage pupils during private music lessons, was jailed for seven years yesterday at Cardiff crown court. Mogford, from Ystrad Mynach, south Wales, was convicted of 22 sex offences against seven teenage girls and a woman.
fields.body:
Teacher jailed for sex attacks
Piano teacher William Mogford, 57, who sexually abused teenage pupils during private music lessons, was jailed for seven years yesterday at Cardiff crown court. Mogford, from Ystrad Mynach, south Wales, was convicted of 22 sex offences against seven teenage girls and a woman.

33-year ban lifted on Ulysses
A film of James Joyce's novel Ulysses has been passed fit for Irish audiences, 33 years after it was made. Censor Sheamus Smith gave the movie a 15 certificate following refusals in 1967 and 1974. It is expected to get its first viewing in the city that inspired it during the next few weeks.

Castle widow's plea to charity
The widow of entertainer Roy Castle yesterday demanded his name be removed from the charity for which he helped raise thousands of pounds before he died from lung cancer in 1994. Fiona Castle has told the troubled Merseyside-based Roy Castle Foundation that she no longer wishes to be involved in its work.

Police inquiry decision A two-year police inquiry into alleged council corruption in Wakefield, West Yorkshire, has ended without charges. Papers relating to claims of improper deals by senior Labour councillors with a security firm may now be passed to the district auditor's office.

Workmen dig up skeleton
A human skeleton between 60 and 100 years old has been discovered by workmen at a house in Plymouth, Devon. Police are treating the death as suspicious.

£50,000 pledge by DJ Evans
Virgin Radio DJ Chris Evans yesterday promised £50,000 to help send 18-year-old Joanne Harris for a heart and lung transplant in the US. The pledge means the £250,000 appeal target has been met - her friend Craig Phillips gave his £70,000 Big Brother prize money towards it.

Extra condoms for Sydney
Extra supplies of condoms are being sent to the Olympic athletes village in Sydney, following concerns that they may be needed as the games near an end.

webTitle: Three airports considered for second runway

fields.headline: Three airports considered for second runway
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Plans to double the size of Gatwick, Stansted and Southampton airports are being urgently studied by the government to cope with the expected rapid increase of passenger traffic over the next 20 years, BAA, the airports operator, confirmed last night.
fields.body:
Plans to double the size of Gatwick, Stansted and Southampton airports are being urgently studied by the government to cope with the expected rapid increase of passenger traffic over the next 20 years, BAA, the airports operator, confirmed last night.

BAA said it had been asked by John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, to draw up plans to build a second runway at each of the three airports.

BAA's views will be considered by ministers in a review of sites for new runways in the south east expected next year. Forecasts by the Department of Transport show total passenger numbers at UK airports rising from 160m in 1998 to 400m in 2020. This is equivalent to four new airports the size of Heathrow or eight new airports the size of Gatwick.

Mr Prescott has ignored a commitment by BAA to the local community that it would not consider a second runway until after 2019 at the earliest. But BAA made it clear that a second runway at Gatwick was only a number of options being examined,

The decision has been revealed to members of the airport consultative committee by Alastair McDirmid, BAA director of strategy at Gatwick. He told the committee that BAA had not been asked to produce specific details, only to say whether the plan was feasible.

Brendon Sewill, chairman of the Gatwick conservation campaign, said: "The news took us totally by surprise. The government would have to introduce primary legislation, amid considerable hostility. You can see the logic of its thinking because a housing scheme in the area was refused permission earlier this year."

The government has already made clear that BAA's commitment to the local community can be overruled by ministers in the national interest.

BAA said it had told Mr Prescott that a further expansion of Heathrow was out of the question. It could not be party to any plans to build a third runway there.

A spokeswoman said: "Heathrow is full enough. There is a danger that we will lose quality for passengers if it is allowed to expand beyond building of the fifth terminal. We are also reaching the position of saturation at Heathrow for landing and take-off."

The Department of Transport said that BAA's views would form part of a consultation plan, due to be published early next year. Ministers are fighting shy of a white paper on airport expansion until after the election. They know that whatever they say will be vigorously opposed by people living near the development.

They are also waiting for the inspector's report on the development of Heathrow's fifth terminal. It was the longest public inquiry and the inspector has been given two years to produce his report.

This will be published before the election, and is likely to approve the plan with restrictions on landing rights and the expansion of passengers. But because of its political sensitivity and the impact on marginal parliamentary seats around Heathrow, Mr Prescott will not reach a decision until after the election.

The Department of Transport said: "The government would like to act more swiftly on overcrowding at airports in the south-east, but must wait for the Terminal Five decision."

Stansted is the most likely of the three airports under scrutiny to get a third runway. It is situated in a largely rural area, away from heavily populated areas. It would therefore not be as controversial as Gatwick, where a second runway would cause an uproar.

Southampton has room for a second east-west runway and a railway station next to the airport. It has fast rail communications with central London and must be classed as a serious candidate.

Rapid expansion Airports gear up for growth

Passenger numbers will more than double to 400m at Britain's major airports over the next 20 years, increasing congestion in the skies by 5% a year

Heathrow
Plans to expand capacity from its current yearly 63m passengers to 80m by 2007 if terminal five is approved

Gatwick
Due to expand from 31m to 40m by 2008, without a second runway

Stansted
Planned £200m terminal expansion at Stansted will increase passengers from 11m to 15m by 2005, without a second runway

Manchester
Will increase from 18m passengers a year to 40.7m by 2015. Second runway opening early next year

Edinburgh
Running at 5m passengers a year with £54m extension. No projected growth

Brendon Sewill, chairman of the Gatwick conservation campaign, said: "The news took us totally by surprise. The government would have to introduce primary legislation, amid considerable hostility. You can see the logic of its thinking because a housing scheme in the area was refused permission earlier this year." The government has already made clear that BAA's commitment to the local community can be overruled by ministers in the national interest. BAA said it had told Mr Prescott that a further expansion of Heathrow was out of the question. It could not be party to any plans to build a third runway there. A spokeswoman said: "Heathrow is full enough. There is a danger that we will lose quality for passengers if it is allowed to expand beyond building of the fifth terminal. We are also reaching the position of saturation at Heathrow for landing and take-off." The Department of Transport said that BAA's views would form part of a consultation plan, due to be published early next year. Ministers are fighting shy of a white paper on airport expansion until after the election. They know that whatever they say will be vigorously opposed by people living near the development. They are also waiting for the inspector's report on the development of Heathrow's fifth terminal. It was the longest public inquiry and the inspector has been given two years to produce his report. This will be published before the election, and is likely to approve the plan with restrictions on landing rights and the expansion of passengers. But because of its political sensitivity and the impact on marginal parliamentary seats around Heathrow, Mr Prescott will not reach a decision until after the election. The Department of Transport said: "The government would like to act more swiftly on overcrowding at airports in the south-east, but must wait for the Terminal Five decision." It would therefore not be as controversial as Gatwick, where a second runway would cause an uproar. Southampton has room for a second east-west runway and a railway station next to the airport. It has fast rail communications with central London and must be classed as a serious candidate. fields.headline: The mourning after
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Modern Times: Suicidal/Dicing With Debt/Animal Hospital In Oz
fields.body:
Two young men commit suicide every day in the UK. Thousands more attempt to take their own lives. They do so in a variety of ways - overdoses, hanging, slashing their wrists. Modern Times: Suicidal (BBC2) went beyond the stark statistics and bloody methods of suicide and explored why a suicide epidemic has exploded among the young male population, as well as uncovering the suffering of the families left bereft when their son takes his own life. The result was contemplative, moving and rather worrying television.

Darren Humphrey hanged himself while on holiday with two friends in France. His parents, Lynda and Bob, are still devastated, still unable to make sense of his decision. While Lynda goes into Darren's room twice a day - once to say good morning and once to say good night - Bob speaks to other families and suicidal and depressed people on the internet.

Thanks to their honesty and that of the other contributors - Chris and Jamie, who have both attempted suicide as well as committing self harm, and the professionals who help such young men who feel worthless and left behind by the world - Modern Times went some way to making sense of suicide. Before watching this programme, suicide seemed such an illogical and inexplicable act, committed by nutters, loonies and those with a screw loose.

Afterwards, it seemed, if not rational, then certainly understandable as the only course of action open to desperate, lonely and miserable young men. The contradictory, illogical reasoning that drives someone to try and kill themselves was summed up by Chris, who communicated with fellow suicide survivors on the internet and persuaded others not to kill themselves: "A lot of us want to die, but we don't want other people to die." Once you stop trying to make sense of it in a conventional way, it falls into place a bit more. It's perhaps a bit naively optimistic to hope Modern Times stopped a couple of young men attempting suicide and got them to seek help, but you can't help but hope nonetheless.

It's amazing how quickly you go from being a student and resenting the world for the disdain it directs towards you and becoming someone who holds students in utter contempt. If you are no longer a student and dislike them with an intensity normally reserved for Serbian war criminals, then Dicing With Debt (Channel 4) probably isn't for you. Its premise was so simple even a land economy student could follow it: answer a question to roll a dice. Roll a dice to win points and then prizes. Gamble the prizes on a place in the final and the chance to win the cash to pay off the debt. In essence, it is quite a good idea and will perhaps appeal to students who aren't watching The Simpsons. Where the programme fails is that the rest of the show's audience scorn students so much, they are rooting for everyone to lose.

Consider a few of the contestants. Chris, who owed £3,000, could wake up his entire halls of residence by burping. Em, who was in the red to the tune of £1,600, confessed to owning 60 pairs of shoes and 100 bottles of nail polish, and arranging them by colour. Meanwhile Stuart's claim to fame was he had once got Shane McGowan arrested. He owed £1,800, most of which it looked like he had spent on earrings and doughnuts.

In short, none of them deserved to win anything. Their debt was well-earned. In fact, they should be fined more money for their distinct lack of general knowledge. Out of the lot of them, the only one you could remotely feel sorry for was one Adriana, and only because she had once met Robin Cook. Even the glaikit boyish charm of the unfortunately underused Paul Tonkinson couldn't rescue Dicing With Debt from being mildy irritating, mediocre tosh. Students, therefore, will love it.

I'd never thought of Rolf Harris's hair as comfy until an ever-so-cute possum climbed up his shoulder and began nesting in it in Animal Hospital In Oz (BBC1). Heretofore, it had always struck me as being of Brillo Pad softness, but the lil' possum knew better and snuggled down in a most pleasing TV moment. What with a lovely kangaroo, some dinky kittens and dopey dogs, Animal Hospital In Oz would have been quite pleasant from start to finish if we hadn't seen Matt the Vet with his hand inside Jacko the Dog. And not even in a natural orifice. Not a pretty sight.
