webTitle: Business: SFO looks at CSG accounts

fields.headline: SFO looks at CSG accounts
fields.trailText: The serious fraud office last night launched an investigation into accounting irregularities at recruitment firm Corporate Services Group, the recruitment firm which owns the Blue Arrow agency.
fields.body:
The serious fraud office last night launched an investigation into accounting irregularities at recruitment firm Corporate Services Group, the recruitment firm which owns the Blue Arrow agency.

The company said the investigation related to a period prior to a change of management last year, when institutional investors ousted four directors following a string of profit warnings and accounting errors.

The SFO's move follows a report by the Department of Trade and Industry which started an inquiry into the company last year.

It is understood the problems surround flaws discovered in the accounts during 1996 and 1997.

At the time the company belatedly reported a loss of £60.2m. CSG said it had found "material irregularities, principally in the head office records, which represent fundamental errors in the preparation of the 1997 financial statements". Restating the results reduced the 1997 pre-tax profit by £6.9m to £23.4m.

Since the holes in the accounts were revealed the boardroom was cleared.

"A report dealing with accounting irregularities at Corporate Services Group plc has been referred to the serious fraud office by the Department of Trade and Industry. The serious fraud office has decided to investigate these irregularities," the SFO said in a statement to the London Stock Exchange.

CSG said the inquiry related to "historic accounting practices, under the previous management, which preceded a radical reorganisation of the board in the spring of 1999 and the appointment of Michael Davies as chairman of the Corporate Services Group in May 1999".

CSG had grown rapidly since starting in the early 1990s and within four years was named as one of the world's 100 fastest growing companies in a survey by Deloitte & Touche, the accountancy firm. It was once a takeover target of the billionaire Michael Ashcroft.

Its accounting methods have, however, attracted criticism in the past. At the end of 1998 it sold its training division to a management buyout, then later admitted it would have to make provisions for the £20.9m of loan notes it had received from the sale.

Last week CSG, now being turned around under Mr Davies, reported a pre-tax loss of £3.8m after £9m of exceptionals against a £100,000 profit previously. The figures, say analysts, are a reflection of the wayward performance which resulted in the new management being installed.

Peter Owen was brought in as chief executive at the beginning of this year to help turn its fortunes around.

Its shares closed down 0.5p at a year-low of 8p last night before news of the fraud inquiry, after falling 6.7% following Friday's results.

fields.headline: No: 1729
fields.standfirst: Denmark
fields.trailText: Denmark
fields.body:
Population: 5.3m.

Size: 43,092 square kilometres.

Major exports: Lego. Carlsberg. 1996 Tour de France star Barne Riis.

Distinctly unimpressive claim to fame: It's the cheapest country in, erm, Scandinavia.

Wonderful, wonderful Copenhagen! Exactly. Though Sjælland, Fyn, Langeland, Falster, Lolland and Bornholm are pretty nice too.

AKA: The footnote country.

This is not, I hope, another instance of this column's tendency to mock our northern European neighbours for being rather less than scintillating? Hardly: these guys gave us the Little Mermaid (above), Hans Christian Andersen, nuclear physicist Niels Bohr and Karen Blixen, author of Out of Africa, to name a few. The nickname refers to the Danes' tendency to wangle exceptions to EU treaties.

And no jokes about pastries, right? Indeed not. I have a whole smørrebrød of alternative dodgy cultural references. Anyway, this is serious political stuff: something is rotten in the state of ...

Don't tell me. Bacon producers have gone on strike. Not quite that rotten. The Danes vote today on whether to join the euro - and there's every chance they'll vote nej, like they did on the first incarnation of the Maastricht treaty.

They're worried about the economics of EMU? The Save the Krone campaign is more of an emotional thing. Or as Søren Kierkegaard, Danish philosopher and author of such feelgood existentialist tomes as Fear and Trembling and Sickness Unto Death might have put it: "We're all døømed!"

Does anyone care if the Danes become economically isolated from the rest of Europe? Are you kidding? Can you imagine the worldwide consequences of a self-imposed export ban on the little two-by-four blocks you always end up needing to finish Lego houses?

Biggest loss in the event of Danish economic collapse: Aquavit.

Smallest loss: Aqua.

webTitle: Business: Buyers rush for Bamforth archive

fields.headline: Buyers rush for Bamforth archive
fields.trailText: The well-padded stars of a uniquely British art form, the saucy seaside postcard, have proved their commercial strength after the bankruptcy of their parent firm.
fields.body:
The well-padded stars of a uniquely British art form, the saucy seaside postcard, have proved their commercial strength after the bankruptcy of their parent firm.

Buyers are competing for the Bamforth section of the collapsed ETW Dennis printing company, which took over the range of groan-inducing but perennially popular cards 20 years ago.

A creditors' meeting in Dennis's home town of Scarborough, north Yorkshire, heard yesterday that there was no interest in the parent company, which has debts of more than £1m. But the Bamforth copyright, covering hundreds of paintings of pneumatic wives and pitifully equipped husbands, is expected to recoup much of the loss.

The news offers no comfort for the remaining 20 staff employed by Dennis, who are expected to follow 30 colleagues who took voluntary redundancy earlier this year. A spokesman for Dennis's receivers said: "The Bamforth's side of the business does not employ anyone directly. It is a shell company but whoever owns it, owns the copyright to the images."

Bamforth's started in the Pennine Methodist stronghold of Holmfirth in 1870, achieving the unusual shift from illustrated verses of hymns to cards.

The Bamforth archive also includes a range of early silent movies - the main interest of the family's second generation - who opened an office in New York and employed most of Holmfirth as extras in westerns, which saw the Pennines standing in somewhat unconvincingly for Arizona.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Merger may hit jobs at Avesta
fields.body:
Merger may hit jobs at Avesta

Jobs at Avesta Sheffield's UK plants could be at risk following yesterday's confirmation that the Stockholm-based company is on the brink of merging its stainless steel business with Finnish group Outokumpu.

Avesta, majority owned by Anglo-Dutch steel group Corus, has UK operations in Sheffield and Panteg, south Wales, as well as in Sweden and the US and employs more than 6,000 worldwide.

Analysts said that the proposed merger would enable the combined business to seek cost-savings by concentrating production in Sweden and Finland and possibly closing down some UK plants.

No pay for Daewoo staff

Around 750 outraged staff at the Worthing design centre of troubled South Korean car group Daewoo yesterday demanded government intervention after they were told that their employers had no money to pay their salaries - for the fourth time in recent months.

The staff were said to be "fuming" after receiving letters telling them Daewoo Motors' main creditor, the Korean Development Bank, had been late in sending funds to the west Sussex centre.

The car group, which has some $7bn (£4.8bn) in debts, plunged into a further crisis two weeks ago when Ford pulled out of a deal to buy it and creditors invited earlier bidders to reopen negotiations.

Christie's out of court deal

London-based auction house Christie's, which is being pursued by the US federal courts and accused of price-fixing, said it has agreed to pay $256m (£175.3m) to customers affected by the practice in order to avoid further legal action. The statement confirms press reports that the company was to follow the example of Sotheby's, which announced an identical settlement with clients at the weekend. Under the agreement, yet to be approved by the presiding judge - and which does not preclude federal prosecution - both companies are permitted to issue $50m in credit notes against future transactions.

British Energy allays worry

British Energy sought yesterday to soothe concerns after a sharp fall in its share price, saying the present, reduced pay-out was sustainable.

In May, British Energy halved its annual dividend and warned that it might go into loss this year as it became the latest British utility to fall victim to vigorous regulation and competition.

The company's stock fell 13.4% yesterday to 165p.

webTitle: Can the Yanks still pull it off?

fields.headline: Can the Yanks still pull it off?
fields.standfirst:
The US online predators seem to have lost their touch recently. Justin Hunt assesses their chances of conquering Britain
Special report: Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The US online predators seem to have lost their touch recently. Justin Hunt assesses their chances of conquering Britain
fields.body:
In the UK's cyberjungle, there is only one big lumbering beast which is really feared. It is the American predator. British e-commerce directors are constantly being warned by venture capitalists that if their defences are not strong enough they will be swallowed up by an aggressive US rival.

Today, all the legendary internet companies are American. Freeserve might have broken new ground but everyone knows it is an online midget when compared to giants such as Yahoo!, Amazon and eBay.

The US dominance of the internet marketplace can be explained by the fact that the Americans logged on quicker and are now streets head of everyone else in terms of technology know-how and usage. But in recent months, the image of US online supremacy has been slightly dented. There are clear signs that some American online companies are finding it difficult to crack the UK digital marketplace.

In June, e-tailer Fogdog Sports closed its London office and announced it was concentrating on its US operation. At the end of August, blaming heavy losses back home, US broadcaster NBC pulled the plug on the UK launch of its internet operation. And around the same time New York-based UrbanFetch, which delivers goods within an hour, announced it was laying off 18 staff from its London office.

UrbanFetch recently collected an award for being the most exciting newcomer from the European e-commerce association, but rumours still persist that the company is experiencing difficulties.

"We would be foolish to think London is going to be a walkover," says chief executive Andrew Tsai, who strongly denies that the business is in trouble. "We will be fighting tooth and nail to win market share in London and it's still early days."

Tsai argues that the staff cuts were necessary for the business to remain efficient. "We're making sure we get the model to profitability by the end of next year and we are on track to do that. But it is a difficult process."

E-commerce consultants point out that UrbanFetch has a tough fight on its hands. The company offers free delivery and needs to serve a dense population. New York is ideal because lots of people live in skyscrapers. But in London the population is more spread out and to make the economics work, large orders have to be delivered regularly to substantial numbers of people.

UrbanFetch has also not been helped by some pranksters who have been going on to the site just to order one small item such as a bag of nuts which then has to be delivered free by an express courier. To succeed, e-commerce consultants say UrbanFetch has to get its customers buying more expensive products with higher margins.

"We are going to expand our gift section enormously. We are gearing our consumer site up to be an enormous opportunity for Christmas," Tsai says, pointing out that over-crowded London shops should help UrbanFetch.

As part of the government's initiative to make the UK a leading digital marketplace, the Foreign Office has been launching a charm offensive in Silicon Valley trying to encourage US dot.coms to set up over here. But it has not all been going smoothly.

"Most US internet companies vastly overestimate the value of their brand," explains director of Ernst and Young's e-business accelerator service, Jo Enefer, who was seconded to the Foreign Office initiative for two years. "When they are sitting in the Valley, US companies have an idea that their brand is going to be recognised very quickly in the UK. When they get over here, they are often disappointed very quickly."

Enefer, who has advised eBay, says the business to consumer sector has now calmed in the UK and the latest US entrants tend to be in the business to business space or provide enabling technologies. She says the most successful ones seek out local partnerships.

"They are looking for partners who can given them 'traction' quickly. Traction is a new buzzword which means getting a footprint in the marketplace." She adds that any new US entrants are usually helped by the fact that they are less deterred by risk and are generally more flexible than their UK-based rivals.

"I have noticed since coming back to the UK that relative to the US, there is some nervousness about the extent to which UK internet companies will partner with other organisations to go to market. In the States, everyone is open and keen to get in bed with everyone else to achieve their objectives."

Inevitably there is a lot of money to be made from helping US internet companies into the UK. And specialist London-based incubator services such as eVentures work in partnership with US internet companies writing their business plans and offering them access to a select list of preferred local suppliers.

"Most US companies we dealt with in the past wanted speed before everything else and wanted to launch very quickly. But that emphasis has changed, and what US companies want now is a more cautious and well-thought out strategy," explains Valerio Massimo, director of eVentures.

Earlier this year, the heavily-discounted shopping site, Buy.com chose to launch into the UK in partnership with eVentures to help them localise their service.

"The UK consumer is crying out for value and our decision to expand from the US to the UK was based on that," explains Buy.com's chief executive, Murray Hennessy. "We saw that pricing on the UK high street was very high across the board. There was room for the internet in general to offer better value."

To make its presence felt and win market share quickly, Buy.com is aggressively pursuing partnerships. Hennessy says: "We are all over the web with people like AOL, MSN and LineOne and we have 500 affiliate partners."

It is clear that US entrants to the UK market have taken a few bruises over the past few months and are now behaving more cautiously. But it is worth remembering that running an internet-based business presents huge challenges to anyone. Irrespective of which country you start from, issues such as ensuring your technology is robust enough, finding and hiring the right people and raising the necessary capital are difficult to solve.

Furthermore, it would be unwise of anyone to attempt to write off US entrants to the UK market. Major players in the US, such as the giant online directory service About.com, have only just arrived, and they have been successfully doing business for about four years.

"In Silicon Valley, they eat, sleep and breathe what they do. I have been to places where they have got sleeping bags under their desks," says Jo Enefer, who has witnessed how aggressive and single-minded US internet companies can be. "When they come over here," she warns, "they do what it takes to get the job done."

fields.headline: Business says 'enough' but in UK little is on offer
fields.trailText: Business knows what it likes: open markets and the minimum of red tape from the government. And it knows what it does not like: any new-fangled idea that is going to add to its costs - for example, more rights for working parents.
fields.body:
Business knows what it likes: open markets and the minimum of red tape from the government. And it knows what it does not like: any new-fangled idea that is going to add to its costs - for example, more rights for working parents.

The official Confederation of British Industry line is that companies need a breather to adjust to the parental leave provisions introduced last year before they tackle any new rights.

But behind the scenes it is clear that the CBI and other business lobby groups are telling the Department of Trade and Industry's review on work and parents that they are extremely unhappy at the prospect of paid parental leave or further enhancements of maternity rights.

"Enough is enough," Digby Jones, the CBI's director general, told the Guardian recently, while British Chambers of Commerce said moves in this direction could decrease labour market flexibility and make companies less competitive.

Business organisations argue that although they do not pay for the direct costs of maternity leave - the government reimburses them for statutory maternity pay - the cost of finding a replacement for key staff is considerable.

So far, the new rights to 13 weeks of parental leave are less of a problem, but only because take up rates are low. Surveys suggest that, because it is unpaid, most parents would consider taking it only in an emergency, such as when a child is sick.

If parental leave were paid at a flat rate of £150 a week, surveys suggest that 50% of men would take time off - and, because the leave can be taken at any time, the burden for companies is even greater than extending maternity leave. Every time an employee makes use of his leave, a temp has to be found and trained to cover for him.

For all the complaints from business lobby groups, surveys show that UK employment rights are limited and the burden of red tape is light. The Economist Intelligence Unit's regular survey of business competitiveness ranks Britain as the most attractive place in Europe to do business, and number two in the world after Hong Kong.

Individual companies are often more sympathetic with the case for family-friendly working practices than the organisations that lobby on their behalf. They recognise that rather than being a burden they can be a way of attracting and holding on to staff in a tight labour market.

Most companies already give parents more than the statutory minimum time off, and a CBI survey showed that half offer emergency leave to care for dependants, while four out of 10 top up maternity pay.

Pay is the critical issue for many families. At present women are entitled to six weeks leave at 90% of earnings and 12 weeks at £60 a week. In most European countries, they are entitled to their normal pay for 14 to 16 weeks.

Could the government afford better pay for parents? Increasing maternity pay to 90% of earnings for 18 weeks would cost about £600m, according to estimates from KPMG, while paid parental leave at a flat rate of £150 a week for 13 weeks would cost £525m.

The combined bill sounds hefty, but in government spending terms it is small change, and funding it would cost less than 1p on the basic rate of tax.

The government is more likely, however, to give any extra assistance to low paid families.

fields.headline: Tribute to John Smith
fields.standfirst:
New outward bound centres to challenge drop-out pupils

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The culture secretary, Chris Smith, will today unveil a £50m scheme to create outward bound centres on hills and seashores to enable inner city teenagers to experience the thrills and challenges of outdoor adventure. Mr Smith will tell Labour's conference that the need to provide such opportunites to 16- and 17-year-olds has emerged from the government's research into social exclusion.
fields.body:
The culture secretary, Chris Smith, will today unveil a £50m scheme to create outward bound centres on hills and seashores to enable inner city teenagers to experience the thrills and challenges of outdoor adventure. Mr Smith will tell Labour's conference that the need to provide such opportunites to 16- and 17-year-olds has emerged from the government's research into social exclusion.

Youngsters likely to drop out of school early would be better off spending their last months in such schemes rather than "sitting around making mayhem in school", ministers have concluded.

But the plan's underlying inspiration dates from the walks Mr Smith used to take across Scotland's mountains with his namesake, the late Labour leader, John Smith, who set out to tackle all 284 peaks known as the Munros.

The picture shows the two Smiths on a Scottish mountain in 1991.

The dozens of outward bound centres, expected to be created from the national lottery's New Opportunity's Fund, may be called "John Smith centres" in honour of the Highlander who led Labour from 1992 to his sudden death in 1994 when Tony Blair succeeded him. "He would have longed to see us giving children the opportunity to reach out beyond the concrete confines of the towns and cities," Chris Smith will say.

webTitle: Key strategist tells Chirac: a little truth could cool scandal

fields.headline: Key strategist tells Chirac: a little truth could cool scandal
fields.trailText: President Jacques Chirac was under heavy pressure yesterday to call a truce in a potentially catastrophic feud with Lionel Jospin, his socialist prime minister, by coming clean about past covert funding operations.
fields.body:
President Jacques Chirac was under heavy pressure yesterday to call a truce in a potentially catastrophic feud with Lionel Jospin, his socialist prime minister, by coming clean about past covert funding operations.

Amid growing calls for snap presidential and general elections, Patrick Devedjian, a close adviser to the president and spokesman for Mr Chirac's conservative RPR party, said the president should admit publicly that all political parties used to have illegal slush funds. This ended after the early 1990s, he maintained.

Mr Devedjian hopes to shut the door on a cupboard positively stuffed with skeletons, and his words were echoed yesterday by those of another leading conservative, Philippe Séguin. "We have to stop the games we're playing," he said.

The president has consistently referred to all the accusations as "utterly without foundation", but even in his own party few now seem to believe he can maintain this approach.

Mr Devedjian's call for openness came after several days of mudslinging prompted by the videotaped confession of an RPR official, now dead, directly implicating Mr Chirac in a vast party financing scam while he was mayor of Paris from 1977-95.

MPs and commentators were already referring to the Chirac scandal as worthy of a banana republic when it expanded to embroil the socialists earlier this week. It emerged that their former finance minister, the disgraced Dominique Strauss-Kahn, had a copy of the video - but had not told Mr Jospin or magistrates investigating the RPR's financing.

The RPR immediately accused the socialists of political manipulation, or even fabrication. Mr Strauss-Kahn, it was alleged, got the tape from a lawyer for granting a massive tax break to the couturier Karl Lagerfeld. The former minister, now under investigation, strenuously denies this.

"If the president were to close the chapter on the past it would be a healthy step for everyone, for our democracy, for a country of our standing," Mr Devedjian said. He said Mr Chirac should "state publicly that everybody, including the RPR of course, raised funds illegally", so that French politics could finally move on.

"We are the fourth largest power in the world and we are reduced to holding debates that are totally humiliating and degrading for all politicians and for our democracy," Mr Devedjian declared.

The public Chirac-Jospin struggle comes at a time when France is in charge of complex talks on the future of the EU. After three years of polite if strained "cohabitation", the two leaders have every interest in abandoning a battle that would ruin them on the domestic and international stages

Mr Jospin has already sought to calm his more virulent supporters, including the head of the socialist group in the national assembly, Jean-Marc Ayrault, who accused Mr Chirac of being a "demagogic populist" who was dragging French politics down and would be facing prosecution were he not covered by presidential immunity.

"My conception of public life has led me not to make use of scandals in political debate," the prime minister said on Tuesday night, before adding: "But that does not mean we should allow ourselves to be intimidated, or to be accused collectively of crimes we have not committed."

Newspaper editorials have started to call for presidential and general elections to be called much earlier than when they fall due in 2002. And an opinion poll shows that 70% of respondents want Mr Chirac to volunteer for questioning by investigators.

"Only a presidential election and the resignation of the government would relieve our disgust," said the L'Express weekly, while Ouest France said that "everything, whether we like it or not, is happening as if we had started to plan for an early election once the French presidency of the European Union is over [at the end of December.]"

Allegations of underhand financial dealings at the Paris town hall when Mr Chirac was mayor are now so commonplace that most voters are readily prepared to believe the videotape.

The investigators have also found letters that seem to corroborate the tape, adding to suspicions that the president is not telling the truth.

Wages of power

Kickbacks
Under investigation are some 60 politicians and businessmen - the Paris mayor, Jean Tiberi, among them - suspected of involvement in kickbacks from building firms seeking council contracts in the capital, run for 18 years by Jacques Chirac of the centre-right RPR

Payroll scams
The former RPR prime minister, Alain Juppé, and three former RPR treasurers are being investigation on suspicion that as many as 300 party activists were given fictitious jobs at the town hall or with friendly construction firms

Influence peddling
Xavier Dugoin, a former RPR official, has been sentenced to 18 months in prison for paying £20,000 to Mr Tiberi's wife Xavière for a 36-page report largely copied from a textbook. Mrs Tiberi's case was annulled on technicalities but will be retried in November

Election fraud
The Tiberi clan under investigation is suspected of filling electoral rolls in Tiberi's Paris constituency with thousands of non-resident pro-RPR voters

Elf scandal
Twenty people are under judicial investigation on suspicion of bribery and embezzlement - dating back to François Mitterrand's socialist presidency in the early 90s - involving the oil company Elf. The suspects include ex-foreign minister Roland Dumas, his mistress Christine Deviers-Joncours, Elf's former president Loik Le Floch-Prigent and a number of senior executives

webTitle: Lawyers claim deception over lost embryos

fields.headline: Lawyers claim deception over lost embryos
fields.standfirst: Risk of errors occurring 'was heightened by fact that clinic's embryologist was working alone'
fields.trailText: The scientist at the centre of a missing embryo scandal may have lied about his work to cover up for mistakes, it was claimed last night.
fields.body:
The scientist at the centre of a missing embryo scandal may have lied about his work to cover up for mistakes, it was claimed last night.

Lawyers acting for four of the victims said it looked increasingly likely that women's embryos were never frozen despite patients being told by their IVF clinic this had been done.

This suggestion was backed up by sources at the privately run Hampshire Clinic, where the bulk of victims come from.

"If this is so, then there has been a huge deception on behalf of one individual, the embryologist," said Catherine Hopkins, a clinical negligence specialist with the Basingstoke-based Penningtons solicitors.

"Women have been told their embryos had been mislaid but now it looks as though they were never kept in the first place."

The harvesting of the eggs is carried out by a gynaecologist, who then hands them to an embryologist for storage, a trained scientist who has sole control of them until they are reintroduced after in vitro fertilisation.

The embryologist checks the eggs for IVF suitability, and if there are more eggs than is needed for immediate use, the excess eggs are frozen. The embryologist then writes to the patient telling her that the remainder have been stored for future use.

"That person could complete the paperwork as required by human fertility and embryology authority legislation but may not actually have been skilful enough to complete the embryo storage process properly," said Ms Hopkins.

"If, due to the lack of skill of an individual, the embryo was damaged and rendered unsuitable for reimplantation, he may have tried to cover this up. We still don't know what happened."

Lawyers believe the latest debacle suggested that there might be other areas where standards had fallen below those set by the HFEA.

The risks were heightened if, as in this case, a single embryologist worked alone and unsupervised, as was particularly common in smaller, privately run clinics.

The lawyers are now calling for a full government review of existing guidelines which allow a single embryologist to have sole control over the work, including the freezing and harvesting of embryos.

Penningtons said they had been acting for one victim until it emerged this week that there was a much bigger problem.

Tomorrow, they are meeting lawyers from the Hampshire Clinic and are hopeful of reaching a global settlement to compensate victims.

In some cases, the loss may be far greater for some women such as those who are now too old or medically unable to try another embryo cycle.

Last night a hospital source confirmed that the investigation was now focusing on whether Paul Fielding, an embryologist who both worked for North Hampshire hospitals NHS trust in Basingstoke and was contracted out to the Hampshire Clinic, had tried to cover up mistakes which led to embryos being destroyed.

"It may be that he was just not very good at the freezing process and destroyed the embryos.

"In a panic he may then have tried to cover his tracks with a false paperwork trail," the Hampshire Clinic source said.

Richard Kennedy, an obstetrician and gynaecologist and secretary of the British Fertility Society and Centre for Reproductive Medicine, said that the freezing and storage of spare embryos had been carried out under strict guidelines laid down by by the Association of Clinical Embryologists and the human fertilisation and embryology authority.

IVF therapy is now routine in the UK and approximately one third of all IVF treatments generate surplus embryos suitable for freezing, stortage and future replacement in one woman.

This provides the couple with an additional opportunity for a pregnancy without having to repeat the expense and risks of ovarian egg stimulation.

"There are clear recommendations in how to run an IVF lab. If embryos go missing they are either stolen, which I have not heard of in this country, or the procedures had not been followed properly.

"This case is an absolute tragedy and my heart goes out to these women who thought they had embryos in storage and may have concerns about what embryos they have had replaced."

Tim Hedgley, of the fertility charity Issue, which been counselling victims of the blunder, said that it understood the HFEA had audited the Hampshire Clinic for the past four years, since the time it started offering IVF treatment.

He said that the charity was baffled as to why HFEA inspectors had failed to detect that embryos had been missing for four years.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has asked the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, to prepare a report on the missing embryos.

webTitle: Unionists pile the pressure on Trimble

fields.headline: Unionists pile the pressure on Trimble
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Ulster Unionists opposed to the Good Friday agreement were yesterday again circling their leader, David Trimble, with the 30-month-old accord once more in crisis and his own position increasingly under threat.
fields.body:
Ulster Unionists opposed to the Good Friday agreement were yesterday again circling their leader, David Trimble, with the 30-month-old accord once more in crisis and his own position increasingly under threat.

The No camp was preparing to call for yet another meeting of the party's ruling body, the Ulster Unionist council, either to dump Mr Trimble or to force him to withdraw from the power-sharing executive. The moves follow a steering group's conclusions that IRA moves on arms decommissioning were so far insufficient.

Party figures, including the deputy parliamentary leader, John Taylor, were beginning to talk openly about a new, three-month time limit on the IRA destroying some of its weapons. With the battle over policing reform also raging, most politicians are now recognising that the agreement is in terrible trouble.

The outlook worsened considerably with the victory last week in the south Antrim byelection of the Democratic Unionist party's Willie McCrea, campaigning on an anti-agreement ticket. He overturned an Ulster Unionist majority of 16,611 to squeeze home by 822 votes over its flagbearer, David Burnside, the London-based PR guru.

Willie Ross, the resolutely anti-agreement Ulster Unionist MP for East Londonderry, seen by many within the party as a potential stopgap leader, yesterday refused to rule himself out of a leadership battle. He is seen as a more credible candidate than the south Belfast MP Martin Smyth, who won 43% of the council's votes in March despite campaigning for little more than 48 hours.

The anti-agreement wing of the party is understood to have secured the necessary 60 signatures to force a meeting of the council. Support for Mr Trimble there has steadily decreased since he won more than 70% backing for the agreement in April 1998.

Amid pleas from Ulster Unionists to the nationalist SDLP to help them out through compromise, the SDLP is opposing any delay in next May's council elections. The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, was prepared to delay them, pending another look at local government post-devolution, as long as there was cross-community consensus.

It is highly unlikely the agreement would survive Mr Trimble's fall. Any Ulster Unionist leader needs 50% of support from both communities in the assembly to become first minister.

Mr Ross said: "Mr Trimble is the person who created this policy. He cannot escape culpability for the position he now finds himself in."

But Sir Reg Empey, the minister for enterprise, a close Trimble ally, asked: "Do you want to go back to war? The paramilitaries could do it at any time, if we start messing with this without any alternatives in mind."

Sinn Fein, which finds itself in a win-win position whether the agreement goes down or survives, is unwilling to help Mr Trimble. Last night it accused him of trying to create another crisis.

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, said: "This is a bid to resurrect the arms decommissioning issue. I would remind those involved that what they are doing is creating a political boomerang out of this."

Ulster Unionists say the IRA's move to open its dumps in June to outside weapons inspectors was merely a confidence-building measure. They still want another step, involving weapons destruction.

webTitle: Damning verdict for council's care of children

fields.headline: Damning verdict for council's care of children
fields.trailText: A breakdown in services for vulnerable children in the Vale of Glamorgan was disclosed yesterday by the audit commission in the most damning report so far about shortcomings in a local authority social services department.
fields.body:
A breakdown in services for vulnerable children in the Vale of Glamorgan was disclosed yesterday by the audit commission in the most damning report so far about shortcomings in a local authority social services department.

It blamed mismanagement by politicians and senior officers who failed to provide strategic leadership for the authority, centred on Barry, south Wales, after it was set up in a local government reorganisation in 1996.

Andrew Foster, controller of the commission, said: "This review shows children's services are close to collapse in the Vale of Glamorgan. We have found evidence of children left without adequate support to ensure safety. Neither are adults served well by the service."

The findings follow a routine investigation by the commission and the social services inspectorate for Wales. They place the Vale of Glamorgan at the bottom of a list of more than 50 councils in England and Wales that have undergone such reviews so far.

Sue Read, assistant director of the joint review service, said: "We judged the council not to be serving people well, and we judged their prospects [for improvement] at the time of the review to be poor. There is no other council to date that has had that judgment."

The review, carried out between January and March, found inadequate provision of mental health services and help for children with disabilities. There were also long waits for occupational therapy and family support.

The report urged a root and branch overhaul by managers to ensure children did not slip through the net.

Jane Hutt, secretary for health and social services in the Welsh assembly and AM for the Vale of Glamorgan, said she had given the authority four weeks to come up with an action plan. The social services inspectorate for Wales would carry out a special inspection of children's services next spring to monitor progress.

The audit commission's report is the latest in a list of public embarrassments for the authority, which was severely criticised by the district auditor for its performance during its first four years. Labour lost control in the 1999 local elections and Vale of Glamorgan is now a hung council with the Conservatives chairing all the committees.

The director of community services, James Cawley, said the council had already started to deal with the problems highlighted by the commission after receiving an outline of its findings six months ago.

"The report, as it stands, is not a true reflection of the current situation," he said last night. "A lot of work has already been undertaken to bring about change."

fields.bylineHtml: John Carvel and Geoff Gibbs

fields.headline: Raise maternity benefits
fields.standfirst:
It is more than a women's issue

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The case for reform of maternity rights is overwhelming. In the last seven years, the number of mothers going back to work after childbirth has leapt a staggering 18%. No longer does government policy on maternity rights need to get snagged in an ideological feud about the proper place for a woman.
fields.body:
The case for reform of maternity rights is overwhelming. In the last seven years, the number of mothers going back to work after childbirth has leapt a staggering 18%. No longer does government policy on maternity rights need to get snagged in an ideological feud about the proper place for a woman.

This week, there have been many encouraging sounds from Brighton of a commitment to "livability" issues. With a strong economy, we can afford to highlight in the next election the question of how to make ourselves happier - with rounded, fulfilled lives as Cherie Booth described it on Monday's fringe meeting.

The most exacting test of this new commitment will be in November when Stephen Byers publishes his ministerial review on maternity provision. Mr Byers has to arbitrate between two New Labour constituencies: business and women. The fear is that business will win out and women will get some cheap tokenism: Mr Byers's promise, reported in our pages today, to extend maternity provision to those women who are paid too little to qualify currently is not sufficient. As long as proper consultation and preparation time is allowed for, the business lobby cannot be allowed to fight off maternity rights which are widely accepted across the rest of Europe.

What is needed is radical reform. First, paid maternity leave should be extended from six weeks to 18 on 90% of pay. Second, scrap the incomprehensible dual system of maternity pay and maternity allowance which causes confusion among women and employers alike, and scrap qualifying periods; all women are entitled to the same rights as a recognition of the stake we all have in their children. (Forget the irrelevant argument about means-testing; they number no more than a tiny 2% - a mere 9,000 women.)

Finally, Mr Byers needs an ambitious long-term plan which will be flexible enough to reflect that families are diversifying in different ways to share breadwinning and caring roles. Men need paid parental leave if they are to share childcare. As a first step, the manifesto should offer two weeks paid paternity leave. Mr Byers's review can do more to support the fraying fabric of family life than any number of speeches on marriage. It is no coincidence that Britain has the longest working hours and the highest divorce rate in Europe. This is not a women's issue: it affects every family and every child in the country.

webTitle: Business: At this price? National Grid

fields.headline: At this price?  National Grid
fields.trailText: Shares in National Grid sparked into life yesterday as regulator Ofgem surprised the market by producing a "best case" decision on a new price regime for the monopoly electricity carrier.
fields.body:
Shares in National Grid sparked into life yesterday as regulator Ofgem surprised the market by producing a "best case" decision on a new price regime for the monopoly electricity carrier.

National Grid shares have been held back by the uncertainty over its future pricing but rose 5.5% and ended the day up 30p at 585p. It may fancy itself as a mover and shaker in the deregulating US market, but British transmission charges still make up most of its earnings.

The company has until October 27 to decide whether it will accept the arrangements but seems likely to do so. Ofgem said in June it was looking at a range of 5.5% to 6.25% and has now opted for the top of that range. The higher the cost of capital presumed by the regulator, the easier it is for National Grid to increase its revenues.

Price rises will be limited to inflation minus 1.5% a year in 2002 to 2005, with no cut in the first year under the latest regulatory plan. In June Ofgem proposed a cut of between zero and 6% for each of the remaining four years.

CCF Charterhouse says the review lifts a cloud from National Grid, and estimates that a fair value for the shares is 650p. Rival CSFB has raised its valuation of National Grid to 746p, taking in its proposed acquisition of US utility supplier Niagara Mohawk Holdings.

National Grid has proposed a £2bn takeover to consolidate its position as well as the purchase of neighbouring New England Electric System and Boston-based Eastern Utilities Associates.

National Grid is already squeezing out 25% better returns on capital in its earlier North American acquisitions than expected.

National Grid might still be regarded as a dour pylons and sub-stations business, but it now has a British business that looks secure, bubbling teleco interests and growing power opportunities in the US. If you like steady performers and are in for the long haul, these shares are still worth buying.

fields.headline: Bid talk moves Invensys
fields.trailText: Troubled controls and automation group Invensys topped the FTSE 100 performance charts yesterday as traders reacted excitedly to news that US group General Electric has a 3.02% stake in the company.
fields.body:
Troubled controls and automation group Invensys topped the FTSE 100 performance charts yesterday as traders reacted excitedly to news that US group General Electric has a 3.02% stake in the company.

Invensys shares ended 9.5p, or 6.48%, higher at 156p, on the hope that GE might use the stake a base for a takeover offer.

Since its shock profits warning early this month Invensys has appeared vulnerable to a bid. In a consolidating industry Invensys cannot continue to trade at a massive discount to the market without one of its peers - in this case GE, Tyco or Siemens - making a move, say analysts.

Market professionals point out that it is GE Asset Management, which manages money for the likes of DaimlerChrysler and GE's own pension fund, which owns the stake and not the parent firm.

Those hoping for a bid, it seems, will have to wait a bit longer.

fields.headline: US buyer moves on ITE
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Emerging markets exhibition and conference organiser ITE Group was catching the eye of City traders yesterday on talk that a major re-rating of the company's shares could be on the cards.
fields.body:
Emerging markets exhibition and conference organiser ITE Group was catching the eye of City traders yesterday on talk that a major re-rating of the company's shares could be on the cards.

In July, ITE said it was in takeover discussions with a number of potential buyers. However, the nature of the discussions changed because, sources claim, ITE boss Lawrie Lewis felt the offers undervalued the company.

Since then ITE has been trying to negotiate the sale of a substantial equity stake to an American investor.

Market sources believe the talks are close to fruition and within the next week Veronis Suhler, a US merchant bank, will inject £30m into ITE via the purchase of shares at a premium to the last night's closing price of 62p.

The move would leave the Veronis with a stake in excess of 16% and give it the perfect platform from which to engineer further corporate activity.

Veronis Suhler recently launched an UK affiliate to direct the firm's investments in Europe. Veronis Suhler International will be headed by Nigel Stapleton, who until recently was co-chief executive officer of Anglo-Dutch publishing group Reed Elsevier.

In recent years Veronis has been an active investor in European media assets through its VS&A Communications Partners, which last year closed its third buyout fund. Capitalised at $1bn (£690m), it is said to be the largest private equity fund dedicated to investment in technology, media and telecom assets.

Leading shares, meanwhile, mounted an unexpected recovery. Against the backdrop of a dreadful showing from US indicies on Monday, the FTSE 100 index ended 56.1 points higher at 6,269.3, both delighting and baffling dealers. The FTSE 250 index fell 2.6 points to 6,699.6 and the Techmark index gained 22.53 points to 3,749.44.

The best explanation anyone could come up for the performance of the main index was bargain hunting in recently out of favour sectors - and there was certainly some evidence to support such a view.

Vodafone, which recently dipped below 240p for the first time in over a year, put on 5p to 250p, while Cable & Wireless advanced 15p to 965p and Marconi rose 25p to 990p.

Pharmaceutical stocks, which were hit hard on Tuesday, also recovered. AstraZeneca gained 83p to £35.48, while Glaxo Wellcome rose 21p to £19.85.

Anglo-Dutch software group CMG added 49p to £13.49 after Deutsche Bank reinitiated coverage with a "buy" rating and a £16 target price.

On the down side, broadcaster and programme maker Granada Media was again under pressure. After Tuesday's 9% drop, the stock fell a further 12.92%, or 65p to 438p, after issuing a warning on revenues.

Sister company Granada Compass also had a tough session, its shares falling 27.5p to 609p. Dealers attributed the move to negative comments made by UBS Warburg. Citing the collapse of Granada Media, which UBS says is the tail wagging the Granada Compass dog at the moment, the broker lowered its target price to 725p from 830p.

Lower down the corporate scale, telecoms group Thus (up 3p at 143p) was attracting attention. Market gossips claims Energis (15p higher at 510p) has made an offer for Scottish Power's (up 1p at 520p) controlling 50.1% stake. The Energis offer - believed to be around 250p per share - is said to have been rebuffed.

Motoring services group Lex Service dived 33.5p to 385p as Dresdner Kleinwort Benson took the red pen to forecasts. Citing the gloomy outlook for new care sales, the broker reduced its forecast for the current fiscal year by 10% and for the following year by 15%.

Small-cap software firm Harrogate closed 0.25p higher at 3.5p after revealing a cross-shareholding deal with ITM Communications. ITM is expected to announce a £750m flotation next year.

fields.headline: Vote him out
fields.standfirst:
Poll boycott will let Milosevic off the hook

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The Serbian opposition's decision to boycott next month's second round of presidential elections may prove to be a mistake of historic proportions. That Vojislav Kostunica won last Sunday's ballot is now officially confirmed.
fields.body:
The Serbian opposition's decision to boycott next month's second round of presidential elections may prove to be a mistake of historic proportions. That Vojislav Kostunica won last Sunday's ballot is now officially confirmed.

Even Slobodan Milosevic's lickspittle gerrymanderers gave him an eight-point lead. It seems equally certain that Mr Kostunica did indeed poll more than the 51% required for outright victory, and that this stunning result has been suppressed by systematic fraud. Without question Mr Milosevic has suffered an extraordinary reverse that he did not anticipate and is struggling to survive. And it may very well be that the end of the Milosevic era is close; for the cloud of violence now overshadowing Belgrade's streets symbolises his desperation, his utter political and moral bankruptcy. So why, when he is finally tottering on the brink, throw him a lifeline that can save him from the chasm?

For this is what a boycott would effectively do. It should be plain even to his most over-heated opponents that an uncontested second round would hand him the election on a plate. To be sure, it is doubtless true that in calling for a second round, Mr Milosevic is playing for time, is planning further subversion, and hopes to divide or buy off opponents currently exhibiting an unusual unity of purpose. Yet without an opposition challenge, Mr Milosevic will win by default and will claim, gallingly, that he has done so by the book, according to the constitution, and by democratic means.

By noisily insisting that Mr Milosevic is beaten and that a second round is, in Robin Cook's words, a "waste of time", the west encourages Mr Kostunica in his misconceived course and repeats past mistakes. It is all very well for Bill Clinton, Tony Blair and a veritable chorus line of western leaders to pronounce that it is all over. But what will they actually do for the opposition when Mr Milosevic wins a boycotted poll? Deeply flawed though the election clearly is (and nobody can pretend the fraud was unexpected), it is the only one Serbia has - but the west, having long decried the lack of democracy and urged the opposition to take part, now appears to override the process. By hinting, however obliquely, at a renewed Nato involvement, western leaders also reduce the chances that Russia, a key player now as during Kosovo, will help pull the political plug.

No, no, no, excited opposition leaders exclaim, all that is irrelevant for it will be different this time. The coming, daily mass demonstrations will now bring "people's power" to bear. The rightness of the cause is undeniable; the dictator and his cronies must inevitably fall. But in this, once more, history may repeat itself. In Belgrade, such predictions have been made again and again. And again and again, Mr Milosevic has ridden out the storm. If the police and army turn against him, if he is betrayed from within, if an assassin or a suicide pill strike ... As always, it is all terribly iffy.

To be rid of this tyrant, to bring this perpetrator of war crimes and genocide to justice, to give Yugoslavia the chance to join the European community of democratic nations, the surest, safest, legitimate way is for Serbs and Montenegrins to go to the polls on October 8 and consign him, undeniably, irredeemably, and beyond the shadow of even the most egregious fraud, to oblivion. If last Sunday showed anything, it was that a truly massive popular vote cannot ultimately be fiddled away. By all means demonstrate, by all means agitate. But above all, participate. Keep faith that even in the most adverse circumstances, democracy can triumph. And kick the bastard out.

webTitle: Money worries add to parents' pressure

fields.headline: Money worries add to parents' pressure
fields.trailText: When her daughter was four months old, Jane Andrews resumed work, leaving home at 6.30am and returning at 9pm five days a week. As a deck hand for the port of London authority, she was entitled to maternity leave of nine months but could afford to take only the 16 weeks for which she received pay.
fields.body:
When her daughter was four months old, Jane Andrews resumed work, leaving home at 6.30am and returning at 9pm five days a week. As a deck hand for the port of London authority, she was entitled to maternity leave of nine months but could afford to take only the 16 weeks for which she received pay.

"It was horrible going back to work when my daughter was so young," she said. "I was absolutely shattered working 12 hour shifts and waking up in the night. I still had to do all the cooking and cleaning."

"When I returned to work I'd find myself panicking for a split second thinking 'what have I done with the baby?' until I realised where I was and that she wasn't with me."

Although Ms Andrews's mother looked after the baby while she was at work, "I just felt so guilty," she said. "I felt that I should have been spending my time with her. I'd got so used to having her around me 24 hours a day.

"I missed her first steps, and only by chance heard her first words. It was like being punched in the stomach every morning I left."

Christine Esward delayed maternity leave until three weeks before the birth of her son to stave off the loss of 10% of her salary for as long as possible.

Ms Esward, a £10,000-a-year quality co-ordinator at Coats Vyella in Sutton in Ashfield, Nottinghamshire, returned to work when her son was six months old. For the first six weeks she received 90% of her salary and £59 for the next 12 weeks.

"Money was the only reason I went back when I did," she said. "Even being on 90% of my wage made a big difference. I was getting £142 a week. I still had a mortgage to pay and basic living and a new member of the family."

Ms Esward, 38, and her partner - who earns £200 a week - had no savings and earned just over the limit to qualify for working family tax credit.

"We stopped being able to go out. Having my hair done, having a drink became huge luxuries. But because I was at home, we put more on the electricity and gas bills."

"I didn't want to go back to work, but I had this period of time hanging over me. I knew our money would run out.

"I was just beginning to find my feet. I carried him inside me for nine months, longing to be with him and then had to tear myself away."

She breastfed her son before leaving for work and when she got home. "It was terrible trying to wean him when things were going so well.

"I would have loved to have been able to stay with my child for the first year of his life, but that would only have been possible if I'd received pay after the statutory 18 weeks. To have had £100 a week would have allowed me to have stayed at home."

fields.headline: New flights prick Iraq sanctions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Jordan yesterday became the third country within a week to send a plane to Baghdad, as Saddam Hussein intensified his campaign to force an end to economic sanctions at a time when the west is heavily dependent on Iraqi oil.
fields.body:
Jordan yesterday became the third country within a week to send a plane to Baghdad, as Saddam Hussein intensified his campaign to force an end to economic sanctions at a time when the west is heavily dependent on Iraqi oil.

Russia, Iceland and Jordan have all notified the UN sanctions committee of plans for further flights within the next two days, and flights from Syria and India are also planned. Flights from Russia and France have taken place in recent days.

The organisers cite humanitarian assistance as the basis of past and impending flights, saying that the sanctions do not apply to relief planes.

Iraq, meanwhile, is preparing a new challenge to British and American resolve over the no-fly zones in the north and south of the country, set up to protect the Kurdish and Shi'a communities from repression by the Baghdad regime.

It has completed repairs to Mosul airport in the northern no-fly zone and is expected to start internal flights from there to Baghdad soon, the first for more than 10 years.

Iraq will argue that civilian aircraft are outside the UN's no-fly rules. Last night, however, western diplomatic sources said they believed such flights would be an infringement of the zones. The French, Russian and Jordanian flights have respected the zones.

In London, a Foreign Office spokesman said Britain's policy is to "encourage organisations to provide additional assistance to the Iraqi people" but that all flights had to be approved by the sanctions committee, which must decide whether they contain a strong humanitarian element.

The committee's interpretation of "humanitarian" will be tested tomorrow afternoon when a second flight leaves France, this one carrying politicians, doctors and artists from European countries.

Sabah al-Mukhtar of the Mariam Appeal, one of the groups involved in the flight, said "humanitarian" should not mean only food and drugs: "When you express solidarity with an oppressed people, that is also a humanitarian gesture."

Another organiser said the flight was also a political statement "to show no one needs UN permission to fly to Iraq".

The organisers have not sought approval from the UN sanctions committee, though the flight has been approved by the French government. Whether it intends to notify the committee is unclear.

Britons due to join the flight include Labour MP George Galloway, Labour peers Lord Nazir and Lord Rea, BBC disc jockey Andy Kershaw and singer-songwriter Kirsty MacColl.

"Once we have regular civilian flights from Moscow, Amman and Paris, sanctions will be at an end," an Iraqi official recently told the Guardian.

But a Foreign Office spokesman said: "The Iraqis think that the more flights there are, the greater the pressure is going to be for commercial flights to be allowed. That does not necessarily follow."

Unlike humanitarian flights, commercial flights are forbidden by sanctions, he said.

In a further move to weaken support for sanctions, Iraq last week offered to buy 20 new airliners from the European consortium, Airbus Industrie.

fields.headline: Ending pension poverty
fields.standfirst:
Targeting the poor is the right course

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The good news for the poor is that Labour now has two anti-poverty programmes, not one. To its bold commitment to eradicate child poverty within 20 years, Labour has added a commitment to end pensioner poverty. It is long overdue.
fields.body:
The good news for the poor is that Labour now has two anti-poverty programmes, not one. To its bold commitment to eradicate child poverty within 20 years, Labour has added a commitment to end pensioner poverty. It is long overdue.

No other group suffers such debilitating inequalities. Second pensions have brought undreamt of prosperity to the better paid. One in six people now retires on £20,000 a year. Two per cent pay top rate income tax. The top fifth of pensioners has seen their income rise by 80% in the last 20 years, while the bottom fifth achieved a mere 30%. That is why Labour deserves credit for concentrating resources on the poorest. In a society in which the top fifth now receives almost four times as much as the bottom fifth, the progressive priority is clear.

The poorest two million will now be guaranteed £90 a week by next April through the minimum income guarantee. And to ensure the next poorest group, those with second pensions of less than £30 a week, are rewarded for the savings they have made, the government will introduce a pension credit providing extra cash in 2003. But what happens in the interim? This was the nub of the row with the big unions, the pension lobby and the redoubtable Barbara Castle. They want the basic pension protected by an earnings index, but ministers are rightly resisting. Let those who need the most, get the most. The mathematics are irrefutable: targeting the poorest fifth gives them five times as much as a universal rise. Hence the big rise in the minimum income guarantee but the low rise in the basic. The row that has followed means next April's basic rate will be bigger. That's politics. The best result of the row is not this bigger rise in the basic, nor the fudge on indexation in yesterday's successful revolt, but the rise in the minimum income guarantee - and the promise of a pension cash credit. These two reforms are the route to the eradication of pensioner poverty.

fields.headline: Netanyahu set for comeback
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel braced itself for a reshaping of its political landscape yesterday as speculation grew that the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, trounced at the polls and humiliated by a corruption scandal, was on the verge of a comeback.
fields.body:
Israel braced itself for a reshaping of its political landscape yesterday as speculation grew that the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, trounced at the polls and humiliated by a corruption scandal, was on the verge of a comeback.

The remarkable return to public life of the most divisive figure in Israeli politics could begin immediately, after the attorney general yesterday announced his decision not to indict the former prime minister or his wife, Sara, on fraud charges.

Elyakim Rubinstein said he had found insufficient evidence to try the couple on charges of stealing gifts considered to be state property, and taking bribes from a contractor.

The prime minister, Ehud Barak, is not in a strong position to resist this decision, with his minority government facing the threat of new elections after the knesset reconvenes on October 30.

The latest opinion polls predict a tight race between the two men, should Mr Netanyahu manage to overcome the considerable opposition within his rightwing Likud party. His victory would lumber Israel and the Palestinians with a man who did all in his power during his three years as prime minister to reverse the peace process.

Yesterday, Mr Netanyahu's friends in the Likud began gearing up for his return. "I urge Binyamin Netanyahu, if he wants to come back and end the time-out he chose for himself, to return to activity immediately," Reuven Rivlin, the Likud leader in the knesset, said.

The kingmaker in the knesset, the Shas party, an ultra-Orthodox movement for Jews of Middle Eastern origin, also lined up behind him. "I hope Netanyahu will now be a candidate for prime minister," Shlomo Ben Izri, a Shas party leader, said. "If Barak runs against Netanyahu in elections, Shas will 100% call on our voters to support Netanyahu and I think all the religious parties will do the same."

However, Mr Netanyahu will need to overcome the challenge of Ariel Sharon and Silvan Shalom for the Likud leadership.

webTitle: Dibley's vicar could find new flock in US

fields.headline: Dibley's vicar could find new flock in US
fields.trailText: An overweight woman vicar holed up in the English countryside cracking dirty jokes over the heads of a group of village eccentrics who believe in the Easter bunny could soon become the next US hit sitcom.
fields.body:
An overweight woman vicar holed up in the English countryside cracking dirty jokes over the heads of a group of village eccentrics who believe in the Easter bunny could soon become the next US hit sitcom.

The format of BBC1's Vicar of Dibley, one of the most successful comedies in British television history, has been bought by the stars of the US hit sitcom Frasier, the Guardian website revealed yesterday.

Jane Leeves, who plays the Mancunian physiotherapist Daphne in Frasier and Peri Gilpin, who plays radio producer Ros, are to develop a US TV version of the Vicar of Dibley for the Hollywood studio Paramount. Leeves and Gilpin's Los Angeles-based production company, Bristol Cities, is negotiating with a US star for the lead role, played by Dawn French in the UK version.

Leeves and Gilpin will not star themselves. The company would not name the star, but an obvious contender would be Roseanne Barr. The show is expected to be pitched to the US terrestrial networks.

Leeves said: "We're crazy about the show. Richard Curtis has created such marvellous characters and we are very excited about introducing the format to America."

Andrew Zein, commercial director of Tiger Aspect Productions, which made the series, said: "Dibley is a star vehicle. It has a very strong format that is very simple. The classic fish out of water. It is unique in that all the characters are nice. In the US, they will probably locate it in a cosy community faced with the arrival of a new religious leader."

Zein said he expected the Vicar of Dibley to do better than other British sitcoms whose US versions failed.

The Vicar of Dibley, which was co-written by Richard Curtis, hit screens in 1994. It rates among the country's most successful sitcoms and is now on its fifth repeat, although only three series were made. Audiences average 13m an episode.

Tiger Aspect would not reveal the price of the Dibley format last night.

www.mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: Lockerbie witness 'lied' to CIA to secure life in US

fields.headline: Lockerbie witness 'lied' to CIA to secure life in US
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: The Libyan defector who has become the key prosecution witness in the Lockerbie trial is a desperate liar who exaggerated his status as a spy and fabricated key information when a disillusioned CIA threatened to abandon him, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The Libyan defector who has become the key prosecution witness in the Lockerbie trial is a desperate liar who exaggerated his status as a spy and fabricated key information when a disillusioned CIA threatened to abandon him, a court heard yesterday.

Under cross-examination from defence counsel, the credibility of Abdul Majid Giaka yesterday appeared to crumble. The Scottish court in the Netherlands heard Mr Giaka had consistently lied to US intelligence officers in order to achieve his dream of beginning a new life in the west.

Defence counsel Richard Keen QC sought to portray Mr Giaka as little more than a garage mechanic who had over-played his position within the Libyan intelligence organisation, the JSO, and had lied about his contacts within Libya for money and to further his own ends.

According to CIA intelligence documents produced in court, Mr Giaka had claimed to know senior Libyan officials. But when questioned about these men by Mr Keen, Mr Giaka admitted he had never met many of them and had only a passing knowledge of others.

In a bizarre exchange, the court also heard Mr Giaka had told American intelligence officers he was a relative of King Idris of Libya and that Colonel Gadafy, the Libyan foreign minister and the president of Malta were all masons. Mr Giaka refused to reveal how he knew Colonel Gadafy was a mason for "security considerations".

Earlier, the court heard that in 1988 Mr Giaka's CIA handlers decided he was not up to scratch as a double agent and threatened to drop him. Defence counsel William Taylor QC said CIA cables from the time made it clear Mr Giaka knew his salary was on the verge of being stopped.

Shortly before it was due to be terminated, Mr Giaka told the CIA one of the Libyan accused had once shown him orange-coloured explosive in his desk at Malta's Luqa airport. Mr Taylor said this was a "complete fabrication", framed so that it could not be verified by the CIA.

The information, however, was enough to temporarily appease the CIA and it was not until the summer of 1991 that the American intelligence organisation put renewed pressure on Mr Giaka. In a series of clandestine meetings at safe houses in Malta, the CIA told Mr Giaka it was no longer prepared to pay him $1,000 a month and urged him to meet with officials from the US justice department for a complete debriefing. The CIA, however, refused to guarantee a future for him in the US.

At this time, Mr Giaka was said to be desperate. He feared for his life, his wife was pregnant and he had "burned all his bridges". Referring to CIA cables, Mr Taylor said: "In the clearest possible manner the CIA have told you what is going to happen to you unless officers from the department of justice think you are going to come up with something which makes you of use as a witness. It is clear as a pikestaff," said Mr Taylor.

On July 13 1991 Mr Giaka was taken to an American warship off the coast of Malta. That day, he gave his most crucial evidence against Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, the men accused of the bombing.

Mr Giaka told American justice officials that in December 1988 he had watched Mr al-Megrahi and Mr Fhimah take a brown hard-shelled suitcase, flown in from Tripoli, unchecked through customs at Luqa airport.

Mr Taylor said Mr Giaka had never before mentioned this to his CIA handlers. "This incident of the brown [suitcase] is an invention that comes up rather late in the day," he said.

The prosecution alleges that the bomb which eventually blew up Pan Am flight 103 on December 21, 1988 was planted inside such a suitcase and was put onto a plane at Luqa airport before it was transferred to the Pan Am flight at Frankfurt.

The trial continues.

webTitle: Focus on the finish (and the old shoes)

fields.headline: Focus on the finish (and the old shoes)
fields.trailText: Old shoes are back. You heard. Not just old in terms of the 1940s but old in terms of worn.
fields.body:
Old shoes are back. You heard. Not just old in terms of the 1940s but old in terms of worn.

The more avant garde option to all those shiny, pointy heels and toes seen just about everywhere this season is their polar opposite - sensible courts with squat heels in delicately punctured matt leather. Scuff marks add that all important touch of authenticity.

Shelley Fox was well up with the trend with scarlet peep-toe courts that would have taken Dorothy as far up the yellow brick road as she could get without a glitter finish. What was most interesting at Fox's spring/summer 2001 presentation, though, was what went with them.

Fox followed a thoroughly modern route with a collection of pared down separates and dresses which relied on the drape, finish and cut of the fabric to make the impact. Details were kept minimal, button stands were concealed and zippers were hidden in seams.

Deceptively simple shifts had dramatic, multi-layered, fluted collars cascading to the waist; two-tone taffeta accentuated drape-front skirts; huge origami pleated triangles of raw-edged silk adorned the front of blouses.

The colours were mainly earthy ones; gold, fawn, beige. Tomato red made a surprise appearance.

It added up to fashion design with integrity, the antithesis of logo mania; you would instantly know that what you had bought had been hours in the making.

Best, though, was some of the knitwear. There was a cardigan without sleeves - to be worn, Grace Kelly-style, with just the top buttoned - and military-style separates including a tulip-sleeved fitted shirt with matching hipster skirt in iridescent khaki taffeta, worn with a scarlet pilot's cap and those shoes.

Later, at Sheila Maloney's show, there they were again, this time in powder blue with Louis heels and laces.

Looks as though it is time to start trailing around all those second hand stores. Either that or ring your gran.

Fox followed a thoroughly modern route with a collection of pared down separates and dresses which relied on the drape, finish and cut of the fabric to make the impact. Details were kept minimal, button stands were concealed and zippers were hidden in seams. Deceptively simple shifts had dramatic, multi-layered, fluted collars cascading to the waist; two-tone taffeta accentuated drape-front skirts; huge origami pleated triangles of raw-edged silk adorned the front of blouses. The colours were mainly earthy ones; gold, fawn, beige. Tomato red made a surprise appearance. It added up to fashion design with integrity, the antithesis of logo mania; you would instantly know that what you had bought had been hours in the making. Best, though, was some of the knitwear. There was a cardigan without sleeves - to be worn, Grace Kelly-style, with just the top buttoned - and military-style separates including a tulip-sleeved fitted shirt with matching hipster skirt in iridescent khaki taffeta, worn with a scarlet pilot's cap and those shoes. Later, at Sheila Maloney's show, there they were again, this time in powder blue with Louis heels and laces. Looks as though it is time to start trailing around all those second hand stores. Either that or ring your gran.

webTitle: Gore's chance of fairytale ending lies in fact not fiction

fields.headline: Gore's chance of fairytale ending lies in fact not fiction
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Last week George W Bush surged back after languishing in Al Gore's shadow ever since the Democratic national convention in mid-August. His gains came as memories of Mr Gore's excellent acceptance speech began to fade and the vice-president seemed to trip over his feet every day.
fields.body:
Last week George W Bush surged back after languishing in Al Gore's shadow ever since the Democratic national convention in mid-August. His gains came as memories of Mr Gore's excellent acceptance speech began to fade and the vice-president seemed to trip over his feet every day.

Mr Gore has a problem with telling the truth. His embellishments, exaggerations and enhancements of reality only lead to embarrassments.

First came his claim to have "invented" the internet (he only backed legislation which helped make its funding possible). He said that he and his wife Tipper were the model for the movie Love Story (his college classmate wrote it but denied that it was about Mr Gore). He maintained that he discovered the massive pollution at Love Canal in New York state (he held a hearing about it but only after it was already uncovered by others).

Last week, Mr Gore's mouth really roared. He said that he had created the strategic petroleum reserve - the oil America saves for a rainy day. He didn't. He wasn't in Congress until two years after it was established. He said that the popular labour union song Look for the Union Label was his childhood lullaby. Unfortunately, it turned out he was 27 when it was composed.

To cap it all off, he claimed that his mother-in-law paid more for her arthritis medicine than she had to pay for identical medicine for the family dog. But the example was hypothetical, not real, and based on a congressional study, not on personal experience.

Oh well.

In a campaign that has, so far, lacked issues, these examples of Mr Gore's verbal laxity have cut deeply into the vice-president's image.

But now, at long last, Mr Gore may have found an issue to use to regain the lead - maintaining the Medicare programme which provides health care to the elderly.

Medicare is a sacred cow in US politics. Former house speaker Newt Gingrich was doing fine in his slashing of government programmes until he proposed cutting the programme's benefits and increasing premiums.

Mr Clinton seized the issue and used it to beat Mr Gingrich and get re-elected in the process.

Taking his cue from his mentor in the White House, Mr Gore has proposed spending $600bn (£400bn) over the next decade to assure the solvency of the Medicare programme. But Mr Bush is so anxious for a major tax cut that he only proposes to set aside barely $150bn for Medicare.

This week, Mr Gore is pounding Mr Bush over Medicare. It will pay off big time. Polls show that voters are deeply concerned about Medicare and do not expect it to survive without a healthy infusion of new revenues. More importantly, the Republican party is suspect on the issue because of its past efforts to cut the programme.

Instead of allocating funds to fix Medicare, Mr Bush proposes a tax cut of $1,300bn during the next 10 years, while Mr Gore confines his generosity to a mere $500bn over the same period. Polling shows that voters would gladly accept a smaller tax cut in return for knowing that their medical needs will be met in the future.

Mr Gore will begin to talk about the Medicare issue this week. As he develops traction over his differences with Mr Bush, look for him to use the issue to great effect in the first debate between the two candidates on October 3.

Mr Bush, who should see Mr Gore's punch coming, has done nothing to block it. While the Republican nominee successfully defused Mr Gore's proposal to expand Medicare to cover prescription drugs for the elderly by matching it with his own initiative, he has left himself wide open on the preservation of Medicare itself.

Mr Bush is more popular than Mr Gore. If there are no issues, Mr Bush will win. But if Mr Gore can use the Medicare issue to open big differences with the Republican nominee, he can use the issue to win the debates and win the election.

Provided he offers no more helpful elaborations of his biography and does not claim to have been the first man on the moon.

 Dick Morris was chief strategist for President Bill Clinton in his successful 1996 re-election campaign. He is head of www.vote.co.uk

fields.headline: Brighton diary
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: • That prime ministerial sweat is now being blamed on a humble cup of coffee. Bottles of mineral water fill a fridge behind the stage and Tony Blair, who wears anti-perspiration make-up, is banned from drinking coffee three hours before he speaks. Apparently it opens his pores. No prizes for guessing what he drank (milk, no sugar) on Tuesday lunchtime. Judging by the   amount of sweat, it must have been a mug rather than a cup. Downing Street yesterday denied rumours that a crate of Imperial Leather was delivered to Mr Blair's hotel.
